summary: Set on a remote island off the west coast of Ireland, THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN follows lifelong friends Pádraic and Colm, who find themselves at an impasse when Colm unexpectedly puts an end to their friendship. A stunned Pádraic, aided by his sister Siobhán and troubled young islander Dominic, endeavours to repair the relationship, refusing to take no for an answer. But Pádraic's repeated efforts only strengthen his former friend’s resolve and when Colm delivers a desperate ultimatum, events swiftly escalate, with shocking consequences.

reviews.content:
Con sobradas dosis de humor, "The Banshees of Inisherin" plantea preguntas fundamentales sobre la vida y la muerte, la libertad y la autenticidad, la amistad y la soledad.

A través de la historia de Colm y Pádraic, la película invita al espectador a reflexionar sobre su propia existencia y las decisiones que toma en la búsqueda de sentido y trascendencia. Me gustó y volvería a verla.

The film immediately launches into the relationship conflicts, without any time to develop the characters, who they are, what they want, or why I should care about them. The way the characters deal with their conflict only gets more absurd as the film progresses. This goes on for 2 hours until the film just sort of ends.
Beautifully filmed and great acting but I didn't like the story. It isn't entertaining when people do stupid things and they cannot resolve their problems.
It might be directionally great. But I guess one has to be in the mindset to enjoy this kind of film. It just dragged on building intrigue but never delivering it.
a great film, wonderful performances, incredible photography, and the story is beautiful despite being sad, a film that brings several important reflections on life.
Listed as a dark comedy.  I agree with the dark.  Comedy?  No.  Self-mutilation to prove a point is a sign of mental illness and should never be celebrated.

Brilliant acting. If a movie is slow and sad then only top performances can save it. This movie had that in spades. Yes the scenery is spectacular but that is a backdrop. Every emotion is brought out to be observed. There is some dark humor but the depth of despair grows till the movie shows the mental slide of all the main characters. Truely deserving of several acadamy awards
Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan diserve Oscars, I realy thought if Colin will kill the dog, I realy shocked, the film was Great.

Martin McDonagh writes and directs a great movie. The script is near perfect for most of the journey but tends to drift just a touch towards the end. Perhaps a little dramatic in a couple of scenes, but that doesn't detract from what is a serious story of life, connections, love and loneliness. A gripping tale. 
Gleeson and Farrell shine out with their understanding and portrayal of the two main characters. They are well supported by an outstanding cast with Barry Keoghan memorable. The scene stealer though is the donkey Jenny, one you will never forget. 
This is a movie that demands to be seen by all serious movie buffs.
The movie drags on at a snails pace and ends up going nowhere. I didn't enjoy it at all.

If film companies are going to slap "tobacco use" and "harsh language" labels on movies, perhaps they could consider "animal abuse" too? I was scarred, and turned it off. The film violated rules of allowing--even encouraging--the audience to become enamored of a lovely, vulnerable creature, only to.....If you want to be a horror film, fine, but don't violate genre conventions and inflict psychological harm on your viewers.
Like Love Island, but sad and enthralling.
This was a disgusting awful boring story with no redeeming value
Weird but two stars for scenery

A dark comedy that really lives up to the genre. It makes the audience question what's more important, being liked or being remembered.Both Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson personify these two choices in fantastic Oscar worthy performances. With not having directed a film since Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, which I also loved, Martin McDonagh does a fantastic job.The cinematography and camera work is not to be overlooked here. The backgrounds were all just exquisite and the camera shots were at times mesmerizing. This is the time of year when most Oscar nominated films come out and this is a huge contender in many categories. Definitely one I recommend checking out. It's incredibly well made, tackles some incredibly deep themes and is a truly amazing viewing experience.

Slow sad story that had little in the way of a smile, chuckle or a laugh. I had great expectations as I have seen the chemistry between the actors work very well in previous dark humour films. Its possibly the portraying the average person in the film as an idiot whilst a few are normal is where the humour is supposed to emanate from, but I did not find that amusing, really just very sad
The acting and the scenery were amazing. The story was a bit hard to figure out for me. I am not sure I truly "got it" in the end.
Academy award worthy. Artsy and all acting/dialogue. Great casting. Takes you through many emotions and discomfort. Not predictable at all. If you like this type of film it is a must see.

Even without knowing the background of the Irish Civil War, this movie is still deeply moving. The film profoundly portrays various characters' personalities in life (especially those as "uninteresting" as the protagonist) and their emotions when facing conflicts, which are magnified in this closed-off island. The ending ultimately highlights the protagonist's foolishness, but it also evokes sympathy for him.
A little weird and maybe too artsy for me but I thought it was funny and good acting

A bit slow and dull.  Great acting and scenery but the stupid fingers stuff made it so unbelievable.  Yes, I know it was a metaphor, but so what?  That doesn't make it make sense, and no one knew it was a metaphor until they read the reviews.

This is a good film. It's slow and quiet throughout but there is a lot of dark humor and a few surprising moments that keep the film interesting. It's one of those films that gets better as it goes on. The acting is great, with strong performances by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson. This film won't be for everyone, if you're looking for action or laugh out loud comedy then give this a skip. However if you enjoy quiet, dark comedic dramas then you should enjoy this.

Excellent piece about two friends estranged by philosophical differences about how they want to spend their "last" days and time. Driven to dark comedic madness, the performances of the lead actors and actresses were spot on! Recommended.

In my humble opinion the best movie of 2022, everything everywhere may have deserved its oscar but i would have been so much happier with this. I kind of think that it's underrated no one talks about it except when it apperead in the oscars, this is with out a doubt a masterpiece, it's also the most irish thing ever. Goodnight Tri state area.
Amazing cinematography! I enjoyed this movie and thought the plot was funny
Did not know what to expect... unusual story but relatable, great acting and stunning scenery... kerry condon should have got an Oscar for her performance

To start off, the cinematography in this movie is phenomenal. Some of the scenes were breathtaking. The movie is set in the 1920s on an island off the coast of Ireland. Ireland is a beautiful place, and being able to capture so much beauty in one shot is remarkable. 
I thought this movie was witty and wholehearted, but I will admit it was also strange and absurd at times. The acting from each character was great. While I do have some personal issues with this movie (ones I won't say in order to keep this spoiler free), I think this was a great movie regardless and I would definitely recommend it.

Seeing as I am only 14 (supervised by an adult)- I was not analysing the more serious subject behind this film (the civil war) However, i found The Banshees of Inisherin a very interesting film. This film explores many different genres; comedy, horror, drama, and many more. The casting is excellent- including BAFTA nominee ‘Barry Keoghan‘ and ‘Brendan Gleeson' (best known for his performance in the Harry Potter franchise as Mad Eye Moody) The film is a metaphor of the troubles of the Irish throughout the civil war hence the slight references used throughout the film. Overall an amazing film which I highly recommend to anyone over 15 (I wouldn't have wanted to watch it any younger!!)
WOW!!!  Life on an island can mess u up!!!  Sad but intriguing.

Still laughing.

Great actors, original script, comedy based the value of friends.

This is the worst movie I have seen in the past 20 years. It is a perfect storm of pointless, depressing, banal, and smug. There's literally no way they could've made it more terrible. Is there an Oscar for terrible? Well, this is a contender.
Superb cinema. Story seems rather simple but there are so many layers to discover in movie itself but mostly in yourself. Loved it!!!
Es para mí lo mejor que ví de 2022. La verdadera Magnus opus de Martin Mcdonagh. Es brillante y Colin Farrell está mejor que nunca.
Bruh.. dude cuts all fingers and the friendship in the film just kept on derailing.. also, the ending seemed random..

Scenery alone is worth five stars, the performances are grand, but the story is absolutely insane, literally. No character but the sister Siobhán Súilleabháin (Kerry Condon) and the donkey are remotely likable or remotely sane. Colm (Brandan Gleeson) is severely mentally ill, wait, everyone but the sister is that. Imagine if Van Gogh had cut off fingers rather than his ear, i.e. what he needs to keep painting. SAF. Ridiculous. Reminds me of urine-poor attempt at a Flannery O'Connor short story which talks about a brooding young girl who learns to be jaded and not care and the swindler comes and says that he was born not caring-paraphrase. Skip this train, er, finger wreck and read the amazing Flannery O'Connor for more eloquent way to tell and put forth a lesson.
Well played by Colin Farrell. Unusual, grotesque humor.
This is a perfect film. Every aspect of it was incredible. Please watch it. PLEASE.
Beautifully constructed tale of fall into despair acting by all incredibly impressive very sad but then falling outs are like that
Very slow, very odd and very enjoyable. What a strange story of remote Irish life and adult friendship. Absolutely fascinating.

Metaphoric of the Irish civil wars or not, this is a dull and dark experience that I do not seek out for pleasure watching.  Beyond assigning students essays to uncover parallels between it and the civil wars, I find it unworthy of the actors therein and the award nominations it received.
Good acting doesn't make up for it's hopelessly unbelievable plot.
I saw nothing funny and was sorely disappointed.
This is the only film worth watching among the oscar's coterie.
Best movie I've seen in a long time. Should have won the Oscar for best film

I didn't like it at all, the whole story line was absurd, I did like the location, the actors/actresses were good, but felt they were wasted on the crazy storyline, I give it out of 10 fingers, only a 5 .

I thought I would like this more than I did. I mean, it is not bad, but it's so slow and it just didn't please me that much. Although it's very smart and has a very rich dialogue, I thought it had more potencial.
This movie is a Masterpiece!

The stars are for the scenery and the accents, but the story is horrifying, cruel and unrealistic. There is no history. It does not make sense -allegory to civil war is a stretch. Really old life style with animals inside ok but since there are so few on the island -it would only make sense that they would hang out as they seem to have done before. Irish feuds are legendary, but there is no context or disagreement there. The idea that he would cut off his fingers to spite a young man he has mentored is just macabre. There are no banshees, no one dies -no plot, action or meaningful family interactions -nothing to mourn or be sad about -just a cranky old man who is into hurting others and self-harm. Even Ibsen is more cheerful. Nothing like the soulful tales of Ireland old and new. No real appeal. Next time make an actual story with actual heart and maybe even a soul with lots of interesting detail –then and only then an award may come your way…
Slow-paced, but beautifully filmed and great acting. The story is simple yet original and with a subtle humour which I thoroughly enjoyed.

Won't get that time back. Bit of a "King with no clothes on" movie - lots saying it's good when it isn't. Personally don't see how acting out tosh can be classed as great acting, and this was a front runner for the Oscars…..! Scenery lovely.
God awful movie. Seriously can't believe some people like it.
Tremendous acting, artful and clever screenplay, with a backdrop of traditional Irish culture, myths, history and coastal scenery.

Sometimes I think we've forgotten how to let a plot unfold. Not the case in this story. This is brilliant filmmaking in every 
aspect of the movie and Colin's character Padraic will stay with you days after you leave the theater. A masterpiece!
Another sad Irish movie about sad people with sad lives feeling sad.  No redeeming moments in this film.

Such an odd concept but it's executed with a lot of dedication. The small island community explored feel authentic and it's an impressive period piece. The accents and small-scale conflicts are a breath of fresh air after so many movies take place in cities with higher stakes. It's a testament to the writing that this is interesting at all. Martin McDonagh's signature humor is present in full force here, and the movie is funnier than it has any right to be. The performances are also stellar all the main characters are played to perfection. The film spells out little of its actual meaning, there's a lot to read into but also answers to find that feel satisfying. I'm unfamiliar with the actual conflict the movie references but it didn't hamper my enjoyment. It's always a joy to see a creative project with true passion behind it come to life.

This is one of the most Irish things I've ever seen. Petty Squabbles about one's pint, the beautiful music, Donkey named Jennifer and the gorgeous scenery. However behind it all is a sad story about a falling out between two close friends who deep down don't want to hurt each other, but still do so anyways. The performances in this film are deeply moving with Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell delivering the best performances of their careers. This movie is one fine Tragicomedy.
This is a ridiculous movie with great scenery.  Don't unfriend anybody or you may end up cutting off your fingers and having your house burned down.
It is bleak and claustrophobic, as it openly admits in its playing. There are humorous lines, but ultimately it was, for me, fairly pointless.
Extremely tedious, lacking real purpose.
This was depressing. Great acting but nothing about the story is uplifting.
The story is uncanny and that's what makes it so good.
Shakespearean level of tragedy. You'll leave sad but rewarded.
It was actually a good movie that brings out a little bit of tears. The acting was great but the plot was a blurry and hard to pin-point. Overall, solid movie!
Amazing acting and cinematography.
So unique and keeps surprising throughout
Breathtaking Aran Island scenery, some wonderful performances (including from a miniature donkey) and the complex, sad death of a friendship make this movie well worth watching.

A grounded, hilarious, heartbreaking tale of a guy who doesn't wanted to be friends with another guy. 

This film is FLAWLESS. So simple yet so beautiful.

Really boring.
To me at least.

I loved this movie. The simple dramatic premise, of one friend telling another friend that he didn't want to be friends any more, with devastating consequences, is pure McDonagh. It is a play disguised as a movie and because it is set on an incredibly beautiful Irish island, Mc D gets away with it. Colin F breaks my heart. Brendan G makes that tough love seem like truth. The sister, the bartender, animals, the sea, the sky itself weave the story with mythic fibers. I had to see it again right away. Big screen is best, for the scenery, though my second time was on the small screen. Good both ways.

As EngineEddie put it (on reddit):

In Bruges is a hilarious movie with great moments of darkness. Banshee is a dark movie with great moments of hilarity.
Good lord, what are 75% of you thinking? This was the most depressing, horrible movie I have ever seen. Not a single redeeming quality about this movie. Absolutely awful.
It's weird but in a good way. The acting is sublime and so is the scenery and the music. Jenny the Donkey steals the show.
A situation we've all been in

It's a movie about the desire of explanation, the need to understand. It's as much about the inexplicability of life and conflict on large scales, as it is about the awkward, ill-suited attempts of one person's mind to force itself to change to bring back the comfort zone, and failing nonetheless. Powerful and hauting both allegorically and literally.
Good movie, beautiful scenery, simple story and great acting. Loved it.

I see reviews that refer to this movie's balancing of humor and tragedy, comedy and pathos, etc. This is not a comedy. There are a couple of chuckles here and there. But this is a sad, brutal story propelled by one man's abandonment of a friendship, an action that, justifiable or not (the viewer can decide), is undeniably cruel.
Beautiful scenes and costumes, talented acting, sad and moving story - 4/5
I found nothing funny about this dark and depressing movie.  The acting was excellent, but not a story I would want to see again.
Fantastic movie with an innovative story line. Its absurdity and comedy points are just amazing.
Total and utter rubbish. To think these guys were all in the excellent 'In Bruges' defies description. How on earth could Rotten Tomatoes give it a 96% mark - are you out of your minds?
What the hell!!! What was the meaning of this flick? Glad I watched it, but once is enough.
Beautiful and darkly funny.
Slow, bizarre story. Not sure I understood the turning point correctly, because what appears to be the obvious implication didn't make sense. Pretty scenery though.

I will always be a fan of Colin; the acting great, the camera work beautiful. But..a comedy? In an age when depression and suicide is supposedly key this is a very sad and shocking movie. If you are depressed, do avoid.
The main character tells the priest a number of times he is sad and lonely.
He cuts off all the fingers on one hand. He rejects company. He never smiles or laughs and seems permanently depressed. his compositions morose. He needed major help, and we called this a tragic comedy.
It's lost on me. Very very VERY confusing and sad movie and I'm sorry to go against the grain. In the end its one man's opinion who often sees around him mentally illness go untreated or recognized.
Tried to like it as I'm a big fan of indie movies and international films but I simply didn't care about the characters, the plot, or the conclusion.
On a remote island, a man wants to end a years-long friendship with another while the Irish Civil War occurs in the mainland. A simple, moving, and sometimes funny parable.

Very unpleasant experience. References to the Irish civil war went over my head. Without that context the movie feels very depressing and left me feeling empty. I think maybe film is not the right medium for this story?
I couldnt tell you why but i realy loved this movie. Its dark, slow and at times funny.
So well done! I never thought such a simple plot....man defriends a friend....could capture my attention. It added suspense also and a realistic ending!
Possibly the worst movie I have ever seen
Really bad. Loved the scenery, but the storyline was just sad, slow and very hard to watch.

It was to be a Comedy/Drama but there was maybe 3 lines that were sort of humorous. It was very depressing. I knew the story line & love the actors so was terribly surprised at the sadness. Had I known I would never have watched. 👎🏻
Overrated and slow….I have no clue what the hype about this movie is……

Bar none the worst movie I have ever seen!!!! I want my time back- do not watch this! Go look up beautiful scenery around Ireland or anywhere if your choice! 

Most people watch movies for the following reasons: relax, get out of your head from a long day or week, inspiration, history, fun, laughter, 
date night, scary thriller, ….. anything but this!!!!

I can't say enough about how horrible it is - negative zero stars! If you want to question why life exists and goodness and purpose… and then want to cry about the lack of any trust inhumanity or loyalty…. This movie brings out the worst in everything you want to believe! 

Whomever wrote it- go get therapy and friends help you!

Seemed like a rather vapid metaphor. Relatable as a premise and that’s where it ends. Fails to explore either the literal metaphor or historical subject of interest deeper than an incredibly superficial level.
Loved it, great performances all round.

This film is absurd yet real in its portrayal of a friendship that just isn't working. It is set a century in the past in a small irish island. It has beautiful vistas with mundane, yet compelling, conversations among friends, family, and neighbors. Strongly recommend.
Fecken good movie!!!

It is hard to imagine how such excellent acting, beautiful cinematography, and interesting story line could total a viewing experience that I would sum up in one word - torture.

We all have differing motivations, but for me the despair and removal of "hope" just became too much.  

Again, the acting across the board had me all in.  And Jenny.  Ooooooooh Jenny!
Well-defined characters against the backdrop of the Irish civil war. It's sad, but poetic and smart.

This movie was hard to watch, but resonated deeply with me at this stage of life.  I can't stop thinking about it.  I have been that idiot who cut off my fingers (metaphorically) to try to leave a legacy that transcends my mortality.  I have lost a best friend or lover because I wasn't capable of giving them what they needed and felt bereft.  If you live long enough you experience the emotions of the characters in this movie.  At another level, the self-inflicted violence (Colum) and unintended consequences (the donkey's death) resonate with the terrible self-inflicted pain and tragedy of the Irish civil war.  God bless Padraic's sister who had the sense to get off the island.  Most of us stay with the familiar, no matter how painful it gets.  If you have fully lived this terrible and beautiful life we have been given you may be able to fully appreciate this movie.  It's not for those who avoid the dark side of life.  It will only make sense to those who have muddled through this life imperfectly and see themselves refracted through the lens of the film maker.
another incredible diverse and imaginative movie complete in its everything lights pictures actors and all. BRAVO!!! should have won all prizes!!!!!!!

As a viewer I felt like an invisible time traveler who got to witness a slice of the idiosyncratic "craziness" of the residents on this isolated Irish Island at the beginning of the 20th century. As viewers we are there.
It may not be up my usual street of movies, but you have to appreciate the amazing performances and the extremely saddening story.
This is a dreary mess. I was hoping for a little Irish charm and interest. Boring, slow, unlikable main characters, and a truly stupid plot.
Billed as a dark comedy.....there is absolutely nothing comedic about this movie.  I was disappointed that the cinematography was dull considering where they filmed.
Not fast-paced, but definitely poignant
Loved it. A deep movie about music, friendship, and loneliness.
What a slog. Pretty to look at but umm, yeah.
Spectacular film from Martin McDonagh exploring the end of a friendship and the foolish futility of the Irish Civil War.

If you are looking for entertainment, look elsewhere. What begins with a little humor (the trailers drew us in) descends into a depressing story of emotional and physical abuse, including self-mutilation for no apparent reason. It is a tragic, cautionary tale about settling for the inertia of a sad life you've only ever known. (I'm glad the sister escaped.) The cinematography was gorgeous, though, thanks to Ireland's pastoral landscape.

Entertain and a little difficult to watch in places. Initial reaction was confusion, but then I couldn't stop thinking about the movie for days trying to make sense of it. Ultimately really enjoying it and would recommend.
I get that it was supposed to be a metaphor, but it was really just stupid people doing stupid unbelievable things.

As the utter insanity of the Irish Civil War rages on the mainland, an island community is subtly affected by the pathological violence that has seized Ireland.  When the normal is pathological, the pathological is normal.

During the Civil War murder and violence became so normalised that the pathological became normal, which was one reason the Irish Garda Siochana was created as an unarmed force, to use its moral authority in the first, rather than force of arms, to delegitimise the use of the gun to settle all disputes, and to grab land, as happened wholesale for example in Co. Kerry, where brothers slew brothers and father sons, in an orgy of insane and vicious violence, each side driven to out-do the other in a game of rock paper scissors; where vendetta and revenge was tempered with piety and the innate compassion also of the Irish, that even when committing acts of atrocity there is still space for morality; where cruelty and the innate ability to turn a blind eye to it that characterises Ireland in the 20th and other centuries, was institutionalised and affected every aspect of life right down to the treatment of the most vulnerable.  

This film encapsulates the madness in its narrative, as two friends take it to the bridge in increasing games and levels of obduracy, bloody-mindedness, hurt, personal offence, and by the end, the sheer hell of it, wrecking not just their own lives but those of others around them. A great and indirect metaphor for the Irish Civil War, which like just about anything inconvenient and likely to 'rock the boat' is traditionally brushed under the carpet in Ireland, in line with what Michael Davitt called one of the twin curses of Ireland, the national Moral Cowardice.  

Everything just works in this film. The light (of course, it's Irish light which is unique in its magical luminescence) and the use of reflection; which is what this film is very subtly all about; the dramatic scenery, the beautiful backdrop to literally centuries of horror, exploitation, starvation, emigration, depopulation, mercilessness, viciousness, and all crammed under a veneer of piety with its roots in a religious ceremony that is meaningless in the incomprehensibility of language and ritual, once so much it had to be partially concealed behind a rood screen as were the crimes of myriad child abusers in clerical garb likewise concealed in plain sight.  As Christy Moore once sang ''Everybody knew/  But nobody said.''  Ireland's problems in a nutshell.  AND of course the acting, which is uniformly excellent.

Drink, religion, sexual frustration and abuse, combined with two-facedness, cruelty, bloody-mindedness, all the usual and well founded tropes, serve to convey a sort of logical descent into madness that echoes the Civil War seizing the country generally, in an Atlantean outpost of eccentricity and conformity, where power is abused by Church and State to maintain the population in a general state of infantilism and idiocy just as it was on the mainland, ''Christ'' ferried across on a Galway Hooker in the form of the prieshteen, fat complacent and resplendent in the power of his dog-collar, embraced by ''Caesar'': the corrupt local Garda sergeant, a former member of ''the national movement'' who was brutalised by the killing he did during the War of Independence and now brutalises in turn his son and those whom incur his displeasure..hand in glove.  

So it goes, and so it is today as well, so long as the Irish keep telling themselves and everyone who will listen convenient lies to avoid the pain of confronting the truth.  I write this as a former/ex-Irish Citizen, so if my criticism is harsh, it is also just and this film reflects better than any I've ever seen, the problems that beset this country and which only the Irish themselves can ever fix, but that won't be today nor tomorrow.  See 'moral cowardice' above.

It is a thought provoking view to the ending of a friendship by one man's decision to do away with a dull friend in order to leave a musical legacy and the other being a simple man that can't comprehend or accept the break.  The level of devastation the plot reaches is a metaphor for the real Irish Civil War that is taking place.  The cinematography/scenery is breathtaking and the acting impeccable.
Original, unexpected story, great acting, beautiful shots and scenery. Definitely worth watching, noting that it's very depressing and sad.

The brilliance was in the simplicity of the quippy and blunt script. Nothing but excellence in this all-irish cast and the roles and responsibilities of each one was understood perfectly whilst juggling the idea that their characters live in such a boring time and space of Ireland. I love this film.

I loved this movie. I had to watch with captions on so I could catch what they were saying. It was humorous and dramatic all in one. And you can't deny that the scenery added so much to it! What a beautiful Island!
Cannot believe this lost to other movies for the Oscars. Politics at play….
Hated it… content is really not funny, dark, painful and no reason to put people through this. Could've made the point in a better way. Depressing
Was not sure what to expect going in but I thoroughly enjoyed this solid and straight forward dark comedy.
Absolute rubbish. Not even the talented acting could gloss over the abysmal plot.

A todos nos ha pasado que hemos dejado de hablarle a alguien simplemente porque ya no conectamos con esa persona, pues esa es justamente la premisa de esta película. Me sorprendió por lo simple, conmovedora y lo absurdo de la trama y cómo abordaron el estudio de personajes y las relaciones humanas con diálogos que apelan a la inteligencia del espectador e invita a involucrarse es una historia aparentemente sencilla, pero con muchas metáforas y actuaciones impecables.

If I could give it a zero I would. The story started off well enough and went downhill quickly with a very depressing storyline, that did NOT make me look at friendship or life in a different way. Instead, it made me think HBO must have spent a lot of money advertising this for an Oscar. This discouraging story did have my colleagues talking around the water cooler, one said they canceled their HBO subscription after wanting 2 hours of their back. If you want to walk away from a movie disheartened about life and friendship this is the movie for you. Seriously bad movie.
Interesting movie. Funny. Intriguing. Dissects human emotion. Good performances but wouldn't say great - although all the awards seem to feel differently.
Enjoyed the film. It was very unique but not much happened. I would have liked if the meaning behind the film was more obvious (Irish civil war)
It was not what I expected. The beginning starts out a little slow, but stick with it. The movie becomes interesting and intense. Plus, the actors are phenomenal.
Its greatness lies in its simplicity and the characters.
Beautifully shot but it was a bit silly.
It was not a happy movie very depressing.  I couldn't recommend it to anyone.
One of the bleakest and most depressing movies I've ever seen. 10/10
Contrary to popular reviews, I thought this film wasn't what it was recognised for and to be.  Great cinematography, interesting location, but a bit silly.

Really enjoyed this one!  Acting is great... and the whole concept really keeps you intrigued.  I am glad I watched this movie. 👍🏻  However, I removed one star because the last 1/3 didn't feel as magical as the first 2/3 of the movie.  I would still recommend it though.

It staggers me that apparently this movie is in contention to win an oscar for Best Picture. Frankly it was boring and the entertainment value was close to zero. I didn't think the acting was anything special and there is essentially no plot to speak of.

The cutting off of fingers does not a movie make. The writer-director who normally makes terrific movies fails in this one by using a contrived metaphor that is not only patently weird but also lacking in imaginative and emotional force. Great scenery, though, and engaging subplots of love and loneliness. Overall suffers from an enervated aesthetic.

My husband and I were torn on this one.  Yes, the cinematography was beautiful.  The actors were very, very good.  The story???  After cutting off one finger a mental healthy eval would have been helpful.  OK, so it's secluded.  People who so desperately wish to play a violin don't cut off their fingers!!!
Absurd, so disappointed with both actors for accepting any part in this dismal, sad movie
The only good thing about this movie besides the scenery was the little donkey and they decided to remove that bit of good too. Didn't like it.
Erm..... a 2 hour movie where nothing really happens. Oscar winning? Not for me thanks. Battled through to the end but not worth it.
Wonderful and heartbreaking. Acting is terrific.
It's no In Bruges but it's a good movie. It's motivations are not clear but the oddity of it and great acting keeps the movie going
Awestrucking! Finally a creative, impecable movie from beginning to end. The balance between every element fully transports us to that awkwardly captivating time and story.

Way too slow..yes, I know life was slower in those times but this was really like pulling teeth. A great story, don't get me wrong but I feel it could have been done a tiny bit quicker, more fluid. This has the whole 'art film' vibe.
If you're hugely chill, patient and into historical Irish history, this is the movie for you.
Excellent fil making with two great actors. A slow moving but powerful story. I would watch it again.

This was advertised as a dark comic view of a friendship. Unfortunately the comic part missed the mark. The one star was for the acting of the donkey- the rest was just tedious and depressing. We seemed to have entered an era where good writing, acting and film making has gone. Instead the shock value of depressive and torturous relationships is celebrated as art.
My daughter says it's Rubbish, she knows what I like that will do for me.
Not enjoyable. Don't ever want to see it again.

Made NO sense.  Maddening, cuz nothing was explained.
Also inexplicable is why so many praised this stupid movie.
Giving it an irritated 1 1/2 RT stars... 'oof, rotten'
Saw it in 'lerton, AMC, Dec 3,2922
Too symbolic for its own good. In order to be a dark comedy. You need to have some comedy.

Good acting, but stupid plot: an aging man wants to achieve a measure of immortality via his music, and he considers his best friend to be "dull" and therefore somehow inimical to his desire to reach immortal greatness, so he cuts off his own fingers to separate himself from his erstwhile friend but in doing so makes it impossible for himself to play his fiddle. Really??
Fantastic acting. The storyline takes a bit to get going and then BOOM and then it ends. An unfulfilling ending.
Acting was great. The film was very dark. Scenery was very good.
I rarely don't finish movies but this was one that I was happy to not watch and it's not a comedy. There's nothing funny about it. Stop calling it a comedy

One of the worst oscar nominated films for this year.  Who would think someone cutting off fingers to break up a friendship would be nominated for an oscar.  Who are these people that pick these films and vote for them. Really, really bad film done with good actors.  Don't spend any money on this one. Stinks bad
"Stink, Stank, Stunk"   If I were a suicidal person and seeing a bad movie could trigger me, I would not have made it alive out of that theatre seat. This movie went nowhere.
I thought the actors were good and the  scenery was  beautiful,  but the story  was   too bizarre for me, like it was in the other Colin Farrrell movie The Lobster.  The subtle plot was lost on me.
Quirky, original, dark. Loved it.

This would have to be one of my favorites in the list of movies nominated by the Academy for best picture of the year. The world-building is simple and direct. The characters are believably nuanced. I loved the humor sprinkled into the dialogue.
I couldn't really get into it, but will give it another try.  I found it rather dull and boring, but we all have different opinions.
as dull and boring a movie as you will see, the two quality actors could not save this
Unusual story told through exceptional acting.

A quirky low budget movie that delivers with cinematography, great acting and a strong story line that has you enthralled till the closing credits.   Ironically we watched the history / myths of the ireland banshee   Without understanding the backdrop of this myth you would find it difficult to understand the full background/character of the myth of the Irish banshee.  An absolute must see movie.
I don't understand what the fuss was about. It was too dark and not comedic.  Couldn't finish it.

So this is what passes in Hollywood as an Oscar contender? Hollywood has not only alienated it's fanbase, it's completely detached itself from reality. I'd rather have a tooth pulled without freezing than ever subject myself to a movie like this again. The tooth being pulled would be far less painful...
So many funny one liners and so dark in places. Loved the acting and absolutely loved the movie.

It is not for everyday or for everyone but if you don't mind a slow burn and a dark story this is one of the most atmospherically dense and well acted movies of all times, with some very strong themes.
Strangest movie i've seen in a long time.

I found this really painful to watch.  The characters are stupid and act that way.  The movie should have been the story of the protagonist's sister, the only person in the cast with a brain: she leaves the worthless island to find a life.  It is reasonable to speculate that the story is intended to be a metaphor for the silly conflicts occurring in the Ireland of the time (and continuing), but that doesn't make it worth seeing.

This black tragicomedy directed, written, and co-produced by Martin Mcdonagh is set on a remote island off the west coast of Ireland, and follows two lifelong friends who find themselves at an impasse when one abruptly ends their relationship, with shocking consequences for both of them. It is a unique story with an original rare screenplay that invites to think about the sudden terrible changes a war can cause on a group of people, although the war itself is not seen. Themes such as friendship, ambition and loneliness are present in the story, which might feel slow at times, but it is elevated by the incredible cast performances: Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan are just outstanding. Some scenes are plain funny, while others are quite melodramatic, which makes it a nice balance. Also, Carter Burwell's score is hauntingly beautiful! The gorgeous cinematography and the compelling screenplay will surely make it a memorable and unpredictable movie.
Xcellent setting and good acting but depressing plot.

trying to catch up on the Oscar nominees.  Hard to believe I've watched two of the worst movies ever that are top picks.  Watched "Everything, Everywhere..." a few nights ago and could barely sit through to the finish.  Now, hoping for something better, watched Banshees.  Just awful.  Can't believe the reviews that say "excellent acting"..."beautiful scenery" and rate the movie highly.  At the end of the day the story has to be interesting and the movie should entertain...this was plain, mind numbingly stupid.

I'd give it -5 stars!
Waste of everyone's time tbh.
Not even worth 1 star and definitely not a comedy.

I don't understand how this film can be categorized as a comedy?  From the very beginning, you know that it's going to be one of those deeply despairing, dread-filled Irish movies, like "Calvary," "Lamb," "In the Name of the Father" & others ~ involving a confluence of the Catholic Church, alcohol, a suppressed & unemployed people, and music/poetry/dance, and animals.  I was filled with similar despair by the end of it. Yes, beautiful scenery & acting.  And an interesting metaphor for the Irish civil war when the Irish Free State was established, separating Northern Ireland to remain in the UK.  Just so, so, so bleak ~ for numerous reasons.

Ele te surpreende do início ao fim, te deixa angustiado, ainda mais com o Brendan Gleeson cortando os dedos, o que vc achava que era uma metáfora no começo! Um filme doidão, e os atores tão de parabéns!
Superb acting and incredible scenery for a quite slow storytelling half comic and half tragedy.
Amazing all around. Great writing, acting and directing.

No-one would ever do the fingers thing - even less a fiddler!!!
Totally spoilt the movie!!!
I really liked the film, and the performances are great.  It's a weird film with over the top characters.   This is not a negative.   The characters are interesting and endearing.

A decent into madness, in a breathtaking setting. First off, the cinematography is gorgeous, highlighting the beauty, loneliness, and mystery of living in a coastal Irish village. The acting is superb. Not only the two main characters, Padraic and Colm, played by Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, but the supporting cast as well. What I really appreciate about this flick, is a totally original take on a friendship taking a turn for the worst. This is not your mama's Lifetime movie, this is a twisted and disturbing trip down the rabbit hole,  which decent into madness only goes deeper and deeper. The only reason I did not give this five stars is how unbelievable and crazy Colm reacts in Padraic's refusal to believe their friendship is ending. Veered a bit too much on the deep end, to make it a believable scenario.
Fantastic cinematography. Good acting. I guess it is supposed to be some form of noir relationship movie. Too weird of a storyline for my taste.
I wanted something on par with in Bruges but I think I was asking too much.

Not sure how anyone can stay awake through this snoozefest.  Also, couldn't get past the age difference between the two main characters who are supposed to be lifelong friends.  I mean Gleeson is 67 and Farrel is 46.  At the very least better casting should've been considered.
The Banshees Of Inisherin = fucking masterpiece
Fantastic acting, but dark.  Once the donkey died, I was upset. Don't like animals being killed off as a plot device.
Well written and acted. Irish countryside was magnificent! Sad story with moments of offbeat humor.

It was an odd movie for sure.  What the Brandon Gleason character did midway thru was quite inconceivable for sure.  Makes you wonder about when you or someone wishes to end a friendship/relationship and the other person doesn't get it or doesn't want it to end.  The cast was great.  Loved the little black donkey.  Colin Farrell was great in a very different role for him.  Gleeson was great as usual in a very unusual role.  Love his fiddle playing, he is quite talented.  Kerry Condon was superb as Pádraic's sister.  And Barry Keoghan was quite the surprise and did a great job.  It wasn't the happiest of movies and my wife and friends who watched it with me, were like, 'this is so weird'!! But we talked about it for two days after, so it had an impact.

Another ‘23 film looking to make a point, or teach a lesson, or something. The film takes you on a boring emotional rollercoaster that eventually leads to gut-wrenching sensations of "why?!?" It doesn't take the entirety of the movie to make its point, but does take the entirety to make you rethink why you expected the movie to pick up at any point. Its clear that Gleeson and Farrell continue to be a match made in movie heaven, I just hope they go on to collaborate in a film that isn't as dreary as the Inisherin countryside.

Visually stunning. A must see on a bigger screen, if you can do so. Acting is outstanding. At first I was frustrated by what seemed like a slow "art film". Then I realized that this whole story is a multilayered metaphor for the Irish Conflict. Then you realize that it is really the story of so much of the fracturing of society. It can just as easily be about the division of American society. Hey people…..what are we doing???
Wonderful, unique movie due to great acting demonstrating the juxtaposition of Irish tragedy and humor, all in a gorgeous physical setting. I'm not feckin' jokin'.
It’s a critic’s movie. Great acting. Comedy? Maybe if it’d been a cartoon. No, not then either. Is absurd a genre? Two hours of my life I’ll never get back.
Worst movie ever. Chopping off fingers, killing a donkey .

i ended up liking this much more than i thought i was going to - i don't think i'd call it a comedy, but it *is* quite funny. maybe "dark comedy" suits it. it's an interesting combination of sad/silly & heavy/light-hearted. great cast & good performances from all - i was pleasantly surprised. if you like quirky, you might like this too.
This gets two stars because it's Oscar nominated.  If this is the best the Academy can come up with for 2022 we're in pretty deep sh*t!
In Bruges is slightly better.
Feels like there is some greater symbolism that we're supposed to pick up on, but don't. Even if there isn't, it's a simple if unrealistic story that strikes with biting emotion.

One of those artistically beautiful works with tour de force acting that critics go gaga about, but at the end of the day is a depressing tale about what happens when only ten people and a donkey live on a remote island, and then you go bonkers and cut off your fingers because you suddenly realise you loathe your ex-best friend. Art, they say.
This film was excellent 👍🏼
The first half of the movie isn't bc but then they really cross a line. Couldn't get through the last 20 minutes and deeply regret what I did see. Do not watch this movie.
Top level acting by the entire ensemble. The story moves at a pace that some won't enjoy but the funny moments, the heartfelt moments carry and shine through.
Wonderful movie, really gets you thinking about the sad nature of people.
Es una película de esas que te dejan pensando por horas de que trato y buscándole sentido sobre que quiere decir y como es la vida, las actualizaciones magníficas, aunque un poquito lenta
A story of a dreary life in Ireland. Kind of a weird movie centered around two ex friends and one having fewer fingers as the movie progresses.

Magnificent acting, scenery, music though I found it annoying how Colm's mental overreaction did not get called out but was treated as quite well, normal. A dark comedy that's both a lesson in rejection and a study in friendship
The scenery was gorgeous and the acting was good- but the story/plot was seriously lacking. Tempted to give a third star for animal actors 🤔
Unfortunately, nothing happens in this movie that's entirely devoid of plot.
wow. so many great reviews for an absolutely horrible movie. could not sit through it. unbelievable and full of cruelty. the 'critic' reviews are just pandering. avoid this like the plague.
Kinda weird and uninteresting.

Well it gets half a star for the location and the acting, but calling it a comedy is miss- selling in the extreme.  A few comedic lines do not make this into any sort of comedy. Great for those with a decapitation fetish I suppose. A  long winded tragedy more like.  Do not go to see if you at all depressed it might tip you over into the suicidal,  especially if you like donkeys.

I must be uncultured cause honestly this went over my head. I waited and waited and waited for something to happen. Then it did, the rolling credits. Now fair play, good acting from the main characters but otherwise I was so bored I took up knitting and now I have a really nice scarf, its red and it will go with the jumper I am going to do. Exciting stuff, well worth the investment on thread and knitting books. Overall I give knitting a 8/10....oh and the movie, emmm it gets like a bare 5/10.
bizzard in a good way
Some great acting in a very dumb theme. Not sure if that means pick your nose before you lose your fingers. Comedy?? I don't think so, too morose.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was a layered story with beautiful music and beautiful scenery. The character development and arc of Colin Farrell's character was really good. I could truly feel the sorrow and despair of the characters as well as the loneliness. Despite the sadness of the movie there was a lot of lightness and comedic elements to the story. I recommend it and would watch it again.

Only reason I gave more than 1 star is that the acting is good and nice history lesson of Ireland. But I don't like a movie where I have to look up what it's about to understand it. It's an "allegory of the Irish Civil War". As an American I didn't know what they were talking about! I gather the Irish Civil War is different than the "Troubles". OK, well how about a movie that's educational about that, not allegorical! It's depressing, sad with a muddy point.

Didn't know what to expect. What I got was certainly not a comedy. I was very happy to have watched it. It was a long time ago I saw this sort of quality movie. I hate spoilers, so I won't get into the story, but I would highly recommend it. And as always... don't read anything in advance. It diminishes every movie.
Intense character study. Watched it twice (so far). As much as I would watch Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell read the phonebook anytime, Kerry Condon is a standout gem.

Impecable acting and extremely original.
Must see!

Touched me deeply! An incredible storytelling on human struggle to remain relevant and liked. If the filmmaker had chosen to tell the same story in current social environment , most probably I would have kept my ears shut. Yet he chose to place his narrative 100 years ago, only to realise that human nature evolves with a remarkably slow pace. When the movie finished I was left in deep thinking, full of emotions. Amazing screenplay, exquisite acting MUST see! A great thank you to all contributors!

As a metaphor for the pointlessly tragic Irish civil war, it's still not worth watching for two hours. The entire film boils down to two points: one is a conversation wherein Gleeson's character says "you've not said anything, you've not done anything, I just reckon I don't actually like you." The other is both characters losing something they love to prove a self-destructive point. The dark humour doesn't serve a purpose beyond trying to make the film palatable...and then it beats you about the room by addressing actual cannonfire from the mainland. Rubbish.

Perfectly weird. Hilarious and heart wrenching. Brilliant.

This stunning masterpiece illuminates, "Man shall not live by bread alone,"
(Deuteronomy 8:3).  I fear that additional comments might diminish the brilliance
and stark beauty of this film.
Beautiful storytelling that doesn't rush the plot. The eerie nature of the story builds to an addictive need to see what happens next. A beautiful slow burn. It's an absolute must see.

Great scenery of an Irish island (the scenery itself makes the movie worth watching). Taking friendship and isolation to the extreme, but weirdly resonating. Acting is of-depth, loved every single character in this movie.

As a huge Brendan Gleeson fan, I may be a touch biased but this film will entertain and haunt you in equal measure. Barry Keoghan was outstanding as Dominic, and deserves his Oscar nomination. His costars Colin Farrell and Kerry Condon are equally brilliant! The scenery which is filmed in Ireland and not CGI is enough of a reason in itself to go watch this film. Enjoy!

Not impressed - and I'm usually into stuff with interesting characters and good stories. It's supposed to be a dark comedy, but it's not at all funny, or even particularly dark. Farrell plays a not-very-bright rural Irishman who sleeps in the same room as his sister and connects with his animals far more than the also not-very-bright, often cruel, occasionally violent people around him. Gleeson is his really not-much-brighter mate, who thinks he's going to leave a musical legacy to rival Mozart if only he can get away from his dim mate. It would all need to be saying something much more worthwhile, or perhaps just be a lot funnier, in order to rise above the obvious and awful stereotyping. The scenery is stunning, of course.
Definitely not an action film, but I did find myself shouting at the tv. I really liked the show, everyone was great, no bad actors or miss casting.
Fecking confusing. The guy really doesn't like fingers.
Hated this movie. Does not make sense. Dark and depressing

Worst funking ending to a movie ive ever seen. A lunatic who cuts his fingers off, they kill a man's best friend and then this pile of shite just ends. I hope whoever made this shite dies in a house fire.
Definetly a "must-see" movie. Great performance by leading and supporting actors, all wrapped in stunning views of Ireland.
It was slow and sad. The acting was great and the scenery was beautiful.
So odd at times it's great.  CF should get the oscar

This dark story with compelling characters, expertly embodied, is set against the beautiful and bleak landscape of a remote island off early 20th c. Ireland.  A sure mark of a good movie, the film stays with you. You will be thinking about it and talking about it for weeks. A few amusing scenes, one in a confessional, allow the viewer to forge on despite the pain and darkness, the bewildering and heartbreaking actions of the two main characters, Pádraic and Colm.

Would love to see Kerry Condon and Collin Farrell win Oscars for their roles here. I thought they were incredible and wouldn't mind seeing them pull off an upset. Great writing too. Oh and loved Gleeson and Keoghan!
Had some funny moments but if one of the characters was willing to go to such extremes he needs help it ain't funny. Sad

The acting, scenery and music are all superb. The telling of this spellbinding story becomes unbelievable when Colm goes to the lengths he does  as a result of Padraic's repeated attempts to repair their friendships.  And there's a few other scenes that just don't ring true.  A good idea gone a bit wrong.

Yes, it is beautifully filmed and acted.  Why is this considered a comedy when my only smile was at the kindness of Farrell's character fawning over Jenny, the small and adorable donkey who follows him around and prefers to be in the house. Irrational darkness does not a comedy make.  I was not buying one bit the entire premise of this movie; the interest of the main character's friendship feud,  the eternally sunny Ireland, the lack of shock by the locals seeing Colm's self mutilations, a donkey chocking on a human finger (aren't they herbivories?). Yes, we all get the story's allegory of the Irish Civil War, but come on.  man.  I kept looking at my watch multiple times wondering when it would even get interesting. Or when it would be over. Dreary and dull.  Will anyone tell their friends they just have to see this movie?  Will anyone ever watch this movie a second time?  I doubt it.

Overall, Banshees of Inisherin is a well made and acted movie. It wasn't particularly enjoyable to watch and my biggest beef with it is that it IS NOT a comedy and yet it's being heralded as one, even winning Best Motion Picture- Comedy at the Golden Globes. A tragedy with a few funny lines does not become a dark comedy. It was a wonderful metaphor for the pointlessness of the Irish war but don't go into it thinking you're going to walk away feeling anything but upset.
The irony of watching a man cut off his fingers because the lead character is so boring has not been lost on me.  Wear gloves when you watch this film!

I don't want to spoil anything for people who haven't seen the movie yet, so I'll speak in generalities here. 

On the face of it, this is a story of two men, one-time friends, who take actions that sabotage the very things they each want most in the world: connection, respect, peace, acceptance. 

Exaggerated to the point of shocking, this story points to something universal in humans: we can be our own worst enemies, undermining the possibility of mutually caring relationships, which we all need.

Colm and Pádraic's fighting has been called a metaphor for the Irish Civil War that's going on on the mainland. Gunshots are within hearing across the water throughout the movie. As one reviewer sums it up, "Through their in-fighting, they destroyed themselves." We've all seen and maybe even been in relationships like that between people and between peoples. A visitor from another planet at any era in our history might shake its head at our folly with dismay—"you all make no sense"—just as we do while watching this movie. 

Watching with compassion for the characters—and the excellent acting does invite empathy—I'm left longing for all such stupidity and unnecessary misery to end once and for all. 

Any great tragedy has a similar impact. I'm left looking into my own heart. In this case, I might ask, Where do I sabotage myself? Where do I undermine my own chances to experience happiness and contribute to the well-being of others? In what ways have I been blind to being my own worst enemy, and what has the impact been on others?

If even a few people come away from the movie with that kind of soul-searching, it deserves whatever prizes it may get.
Great acting, slow and sad at times, funny at others, must watch.
While it certainly is a sad movie, the acting is terrific and there are some incredible visuals of the scenery. It does a good job of keeping you hooked throughout the entire  movie.

Terrible movie, just awful. Do not see this. Incredibly boring and pointless. Acting was okay and definitely not as awesome as all of these "critics" say. Are there really people this dumb? I don't believe anyone would act this way. No redemptive value. Terrible ending. My wife and I absolutely hated this and want our 2 hours back. The Irish accents and dialogue was fun in maybe threes scenes, that's all tge good I can say about this movie.
Such a weird film!!! I watched it because collin pharrell is nominated for an Oscar, but honestly, this was really bad.

Something about the slow pace of a small island place people's story that turns for the worse with, still, humor aspects in it makes this a great movie to me. Not to mention the mesmerizing sceneries which fit perfectly to the sequence of events that build up in the movie. Very refreshing with astonishing acting!

I never found it interesting. I was never able to finish watching this movie. I'm saddened by the fact I couldn't like a movie liked by most, but I guess that is what happens when you watch a Bri'ish movie.
I DO NOT CARE WHAT AWARDS BANSHEE GOT OR GETS, IT WAS EXCRUCIATING TO SIT THROUGH. MY WIFE AND I EMERGED FROM THIS FILM WITH INTENSE HEADACHES.
So much of this film is a metaphor and the more you think about it it is a very philosophical film.
Very slow and fairly boring it's just about two guys having a pointless argument that barely goes anywhere. Acting was good though with some pretty cinematography.

Two of the most basic human desires are the desire for meaning and the desire for belonging. In The Banshees of Inisherin, these desires are personified by two of Ireland's best actors: Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell, respectively.

But these desires, real and present in everyone, can kill us if they take over. And they do take over here. Every character in this movie is somewhat of an island (ironic, because they are living on a small, isolated island!), left to search for meaning and belonging on their own, and some fare better than others.

It's a dark comedy, emphasis on dark, with plenty of tragedy thrown in for balance. Gleeson's and Farrell's characters resolve for the paths they have chosen are well balanced by more hopeful characters placed around them, played by Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan.

The conflict feels like an eternal human conflict, yet also feels timely and pressing for today, as isolation is so present in our searches for meaning and belonging.

The fictional isle of Inisherin provides a beautiful, threatening, lonely backdrop for this story, heightening the emotions our characters feel. And the banshees - well, they're not real. But their presence looms large regardless.
Excellent acting performances and beautiful scenery counterbalance the slow pace. Thoughtful graphic depictions of mutilation and painful mental struggles kept me immersed in this film. Well done!
Was it beautifully painful or painfully beautiful?

Slow moving, quirky, and darkly humorous, this movie wouldn't be for everyone, but I personally enjoyed it. There's even a moral lesson in it - don't waste your life with people who do nothing to enrich it when you have other more productive things to do.
Miserable, slow pace, awkward and boring movie that critics love.
An absolute must seen. Incredible scenery and outstanding performances. I simply love it.
A friend of mine couldn't watch it saying it was too sad. Yes, life is tough. Friendships, siblings, love, death can be sad. But beautifully portrayed, shot and acted. Loved it

Contains spoilers - Brendon G. is one of my favorite actors and I try to watch most things he is in.  I won't be watching this again.  The premise is completely ridiculous. One of two long time friends decides the other is boring and taking up too much of his time that he would rather use to write violin music.  Instead of doing the reasonable thing, telling his friend he needs to give him some time to write music, he tells his friend to never talk to him again or else he'll start severing his own appendages.  When his heart broken friend can't stay away, fingers start flying.

It takes place in a make believe world where someone can chop off all their fingers on one hand without much pain, bleeding to death or getting a life threatening infection.  Its a crazy place where people exist that think chopping fingers off of their violin playing hand is the best way to end a friendship.  Its also a place where townspeople aren't really shocked by self-mutilation.
Absolutely brilliant! Great movie. Funny but yet emotional.

The acting is top notch throughout the entire cast.  The movie was a letdown considering the critics rave reviews.  Overall, a film worthy a viewing but probably not two.  Check out "In Bruges" for a more enjoyable dark comedy.

A truly depressing movie.  The cinematography was good, the acting was good, but I just felt sad for everyone  involved.  Kept hoping for a ray of sunshine in this storyline but there just wasn't one.

Yes the scenery is beautiful and the film is charming and intriguing all at once but I found myself waiting for something to happen, which I guess is kind of the point of this film, nothing much happens, so then when something does it seems more tragic and shocking than it might have been in other movies.  A Sunday afternoon rainy day watch.

I thought it was awful. Dark, gruesome and depressing. The 5 of us walked out after 4 fingers were cut off.
The part star is for the scenery of Ireland.

The day i've started watching the movie my friend called me to say that her bf left her for a younger girl & i was thinking that i can't think of a single good book or movie about when it happens to a woman & her perspective on it.
Watching this movie that evening it was very close to the situation- what happens when your best friend just decides to drop all communication with you? How do you feel about it, what are the thoughts that are going through your mind & what 'stories' do you tell yourself to make sure you preserve your self esteem?
All of these questions are really well dealt with here (not to say they are solves as if the director would solve them it'll be a shit movie). Another very interesting aspect of this movie is that all of this happens in a very small community. It's very common for us to live in big cities today & if we don't like someone or he/she involves painful memories we can easily not see that person anymore but in that place & in that time one has to deal with who they have around them & it's not much to say the least. Beautiful movie about friendship, loss, loneliness & relationships

While the performances were exceptional, what the actors were performing was rotten. Dark, bleak, a few weird laughs, and while you wait for some growth in the characters and a positive message from the story, it never comes. In fact the opposite is true. The characters regress and the message is just more bleakness. The movie leaves you feeling like crap. The actors deserve praise for their performances, the movie is awful.
Outstanding acting. Beautiful filmography. But unfortunately the story doesn't work…at all.

The script is really well written and the acting is fantastic. I really loved this movie. It made me feel like I did back in school sitting in the library and listening to the librarian read a very exciting fable out loud. You'll get pulled in to this story.

Let's not get carried away by scenery, actors and all things Irish. It was okay but wasn't 97 out of 100 great. The story started with an interesting premise but ended up in the most ridiculous end of folktale horror. Don't expect Citizen Kane; this is a movie about some daft people living on a small island.
Sad, sad, sad movie. Oof. Very hard to watch and doesn't get better.
One of those slow movies you can't turn off, it was great dark humor with great acting!

It was a lot funnier than the synopsis suggests. Down to excellent dialogue and outstanding acting from not only the main characters but also the minor characters. Cant understand why it didn't do better in the BAFTAs. Definitely go and see it

It's well-made. It's a stream of consciousness film without any real idea, other than the exchange of angst between a few folks on an island. Not to mention, there's some  spectacularly unpleasant sequences thrown in with very little cause. The idea that THIS ever beat "Everything at Once" in any award show is ridiculous.

This film is not for everyone (as with most best movie nominees). It is slow and features a lot of talking and Irish slang. But I appreciated the humor in this dark comedy. Not laugh-out-loud funny, but smiling every 10 minutes sort of funny. More importantly, the 2 main characters played great opposite each other. It's not easy to make "not wanting to be friends anymore" become a dramatic story. And most clever of all was how this fight between best friends over nothing was symbolic of the Irish civil war going on in the background.
A nice blend of sad humor, angst, and thought provoking parable. Performances were all great and the cinematography was good.
Banshees is a miserable but well filmed movie. It is not entertaining and is quite sad with mental distress and self harm and suicide.
I thought I would hate it....I didn't. it is one of the best this past year

Fecking dull, fecking dull, fecking dull!!!!!

Set on an idyllic island off Ireland, Martin McDonough's black tragicomedy opens with an abrupt end to a long-standing friendship, proceeds to intrigue with a development hinted at existential crisis and closes with an esoteric ending coming to grips with the vicious cycle of loneliness and depression.

Original, beautifully filmed, powerfully acted masterpiece with an extraordinary screenplay! Colin Ferrell, Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan give powerful performances! There is so much greatness and layers to this story! Another winner for our very best writer, Martin McDonagh.
A strange movie that kept me on my toes. Can't say it is my favorite but it was something new with amazing points.

This is a perfect film. We don't think Ben Davis cinematography or Carter Burwell score get enough credit. But the awards keep  pouring in for Best Picture, Best Actors, Best Screenplay and Best director, so I think that tells you why we think Banshees is a perfect film. It's certainly McDonagh's perfect screenplay. The master of dark comedy takes it deeper into tragicomedy with this one. The story is profound. One viewing only takes away one layer.  The dissolution of both men comes  to a gut punch at the end. Fans have filled YouTube with debates for weeks now about the layers of meaning here. The metaphors, the foreshadowing, the symbolism. It's wonderful to read all the interpretations.
If the tragedy of the story gets you down, you are not seeing the gallows humor peppered throughout. We saw it twice in a theater and the audience 😆 as the hilarious scenes were weaved into the sorrowful ones. This really is a masterpiece. And the 4 performances are absolutely extraordinary. All four nominated by every awards groups. As is McDonagh for directing and screenplay. This is truly a must-see. At least twice. The Irish brogue is much clearer too.☺️ We've streamed it four more times since November and are still chewing on it.  Best film of 2022.

I hated this movie with a passion. With the world as it is, no one needs invented misery. I wish it had never been made and I want those hours of my life back.
Not the jolliest film you will see, nor the most uplifting, but an original, very believable script, beautifully performed. This is what stood out for me.

I honestly cannot believe that this movie has garnered so many award nominations. It made absolutely no sense to me. The plot line is so dumb and to think anybody would cut off all of his fingers because he doesn’t want to be friends with somebody is ludicrous.

Many people will recognize the scenery or the performances, and idk. I just kinda feel like a compelling story is a pretty compelling ingredient when it comes to making a good movie. Was is strange and different? Sure. Were there scenes that made you think or feel? A few of them. But fundamentally, at the core of this story, one man decides he no longer wants to be friends with the other. It just doesn't hook me. And it takes so long to escalate the conflict and advance the story, that by the time you get to any sort of payoff, I just don't care. It's a boring story.

Acclaimed playwright and director Martin McDonagh delivers another masterful ensemble piece to audiences with his latest film "The Banshees of Inisherin". The black comedy reunites leads Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson with McDonagh, who directed them both in his 2008 Oscar-nominated film "In Bruges". After it's world premiere at this year's Venice International Film Festival, the film went on to receive a rapturous 15-minute standing ovation, five minutes longer than McDonagh's previous film "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri". 

The film takes place in 1920s Ireland, against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, on the fictional island of Inisherin and tells the story of two friends Pádraic (Farrell) and Colm (Gleeson). One day, Colm decides to abruptly end his long-running friendship with Pádraic, claiming the man is ‘too dull' for him to spend the rest of his life around. An escalating battle then begins between the two friends, and it soon becomes the talk of the village, with many just as confused as Pádraic with Colm's decision. As the growing tensions between the two grow, it's not long before it boils over and results in devastating consequences for both feuding men. 

Colin Farrell leads an uber-talented cast comprised of some of Ireland's greatest talents like Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan, all delivering knockout performances. Farrell's work is almost certain to land him a spot in this year's Best Actor line-up as he plays Pádraic, the harmless easy-going farmer, until he finally snaps and becomes a ruthless man out for revenge, and perhaps that's what makes his performance so fascinating to watch unfold on the big screen. The friendship Farrell shares with his co-star Brendan Gleeson elevates both performances making them feel much more authentic and believable. The pair share a hilarious back and forth that's embellished by McDonagh's screenplay. Gleeson's role as Colm, a man who finds himself in the later years of his life wishing to be more creative, and have more interesting conversations with those around him, is terrific and perfectly compliments Farrell's performance. The film's other standout performance, alongside Farrell's, comes from Kerry Condon. The Irish actress, probably best known for voicing ‘Friday' in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, gives a marvellous turn as Pádraic's sister, Siobhan. Condon ends up acting as a mediator between the two men, trying to keep them apart to prevent Colm from resorting to drastic action. Condon boosts every scene she's in to a whole other level and she ends up being one of the best parts of the film. 

Director Martin McDonagh pens a screenplay that balances side-splitting hilarity with tear-jerking emotion and reminds you exactly why he has two Oscar-nominations for writing under his belt. It's sharp, witty, and brilliantly tells the story of what happens when a friendship turns sour. McDonagh does a skilful job blending the comedic tones at the start of the film with the tragedy and drama that becomes more dominant towards the end. This balance, combined with McDonagh's sensational directorial effort, makes "The Banshees of Inisherin" such a unique and entertaining film. Perhaps what else makes the film so good, and sets it apart from a large majority of this year's awards contenders, is that it isn't an intricate biopic about a famous figure or some overbearing think piece, but is instead a rich, amusing film about friendship. 

"The Banshees of Inisherin" brings some delightful visuals to the screen alongside the engaging narrative and likeable characters. Cinematographer Ben Davis, who worked with McDonagh on "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", uses the scenic Irish coastlines to his advantage to effortlessly enhance the natural beauty of the film.

Not even close to "In Bruges".  It could have been a well made film with superb acting, photography, scenery.  But what was the point in that plot? Was there an allegory that I may have missed? Don't know.  Coulda, woulda, shoulda...

This film has a gentle pace and pleasantly ambles through a pretty odd tale of two, hitherto friends. The acting from all the cast members is amazing and the setting is beautifully simple. I'd describe it as enjoyable overall. For some it may miss the mark and be a bit of a head-scratcher, for others it will be a master-class.

If you were a fan of In Bruges, then this is an absolute must watch. Gleeson and Farrell hit the freaking bell with their chemistry again and it's so good!!! 

Kerry Kondan delivers a masterful performance which commands every scene she is in. Barry Keoghan likewise sends it in this movie. He will wrench your heart out and you'll thank him for it. 

Every bit of dialogue, let alone conversation, is expertly crafted to extract the most out of what needs to happen. Expect laughs and tears in equal numbers. 

The setting will also have you wide eyed the whole way through. The stark expanses of the Irish islands are breathtaking. 

All in all it might not be for everyone if you aren't looking for a dialogue heavy dark comedic drama, but if that's your thing.... watch it yesterday.

It's a boring movie, about the boring life of boring people in a small boring island in 1923.....Simply the most pointless movie I have ever watched. It's not brilliant, it's not insightful, it's not touching, it's does not make you go into deep personal reflection... it's just plain boring!

Beautiful to behold and beautifully acted, this film doesn't reveal itself to you unless you really sit and let it wash over you. If you do, you will be rewarded.

In the truest sense it's a different spin on 'cutting off your nose to spite your face.'  It's NOT a comedy - it's a dark dramedy.  Colin Farrell is heartbreaking, Barry Keoghan is a revelation as the town 'gom'.  Kerri Condon is the perfect sister/foil to Padraic and Brendon Gleeson is amazing as the no-longer-friend.  Cinematography is first rate, beautiful.

Absolutely a genius piece of art.

Another triumph with a fantastic supporting cast in Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan and a perfectly written screenplay. I hope to see more from Gleeson and Farrell in a similar vein. A fall-out between two mates, in an island community, with unimaginable consequences.

As "The Banchees of Inisherin" (2022 release from Ireland; 114 min) opens, the Colin Farrell character, a guy named Padriac, stops by the Breandon Gleeson character, a guy named Colm who is Padriac's best friend. That is, until that moment. For reasons unknown, Colm wants nothing more to do with Padriac. "I just don't like you anymore" Colm offers. The calendar shows "April 1, 1923", and Padriac doesn't take this unexplained change of behavior by Colm very well... At this point we are 10 min into the movie.

Couple of comments: this is the highly anticipated reunion of writer-director Martin McDonagh, and lead performers Farrell and Gleeson, 14 years after the now classic "In Bruges". I too was eager to see how this reunion would play out, but then something completely unexpected happened: I found the Colin Farrell character to be irritating and off-putting, to the point where it was almost too much to bear or see. Without spoiling anything, I will say that things are somewhat better in the movie's second hour. But I could never get into the proper flow of the movie, let alone rave about it as many others have done. I completely understand that my viewpoint is definitely in the minority. And that this film has been hailed critically (it's currently rated 97% Certified Fresh on Rotten Tomatoes). The most striking thing about the movie for me was the strong performance of Barry Keoghan (who starred in "Dunkirk" a few years back). This is a subjective opinion of course.

"The Banchees of Inisherin" premiered at this year's Venice Film Festival to universal acclaim, and opened in theaters in November. The Sunday early evening screening where I saw this at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati was attended okay (I counted about 15 people). If you are a fan of Martin McDonagh's earlier work of or Colin Farrell or Brendon Gleeson, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.
It's advertised as a comedy but it's not funny it's more of a drama and when I finally got invested it ended not bad but in my opinion the pretty mid 5/10

These, Oscar nominated films, do not live up to the excitement of what the award was created for. These films are aren't based, and more of a low budget miss for the audience. We not only as an audience member want to see the movies we love on the big screen, but we also enjoy the chances that the film industry take on these type of films.
