Great acting and filming couldn’t rescue this story. After watching this film I felt like the victim of an assault that I unwittingly agreed to.
I LOVED this movie. I NEEDED this movie.

What a dreadful, brutal, pointless piece of faux satire. I've seen reviewers claim it's a metaphor for the centuries long conflict between Irish Protestants and Catholics. Rubbish! However misguided, both sides made the source of their grievances crystal clear. "I just don't like you any more" is a flimsy excuse for two hours of violence, animal cruelty and graphic self mutilation.

Well this is just about the most depressing movie I've ever seen in a while. First I get taunted by a friend that I wouldn't like it. Then it wins 3 golden globes awards including best picture , best actor and best screenplay, the trifecta. Probably is going to win the oscar too. Then. Rotten Tomatoes has almost 8. Well. I hated it. I gave it a 1/10. Gets a 1 because I actually finished it. Worst movie I've ever seen in a while. Just left an awful after taste in my mouth. So depressing. Gheez On HBOMAX
First hour was very deep, beautiful landscapes, interesting characters. After that just unnecessary violence began. Very cheap tricks to capture attention of the viewers. Disappointed.

The story portrays 3 aspects of life through 3 characters. It beautifully depicts the pain, suffering of loneliness and that strong sense of ever present longings within every human being. it has some good dark humours 
and Sometimes it's sad and gloomy.sometimes it felt like a horror in the given scenario. But major problems with the film are- its slow, like dead slow. There is no motive behind the story. It has some suspense/ thriller/twist elements present in it but that's not enough. I was always left wandering with two questions "why?" and where is the going. Its an average movie experience.

This is a film which features a lot of space in both a timing and metaphorical sense. Kinda ironic considering its about two friends who have issues when one wants his own 'space'. Brilliant acting, stunning cinematography and dialogue make this a fascinating film to watch on a big screen. One of the best films in years.
I loved the doubling down on revenge and bitterness - no saccharine ending here. A wonderful study of toxic masculinity and beautifully shot too.

Oversimplistic and naive. I don't believe a movie should be just an allegory and nothing more. Some of the metaphorical details have been already used in other movies and the camera was so unoriginal that I don't remember a single frame. Even the acting is not really what I expected. I'd call this a "thin movie", not really bad, but too void of content if you love a more complex cinematography.

Original premise, incredible acting, gorgeous filmography and funny dark humor. So cool to see three Irish actors who typically play American roles in their natural form. The humor reminded me a bit of Coen Brothers, or the director's other work "In Bruges." Yes, it's "slow" for some but if you don't have the expectation for immediate gratification and action, it pays off in the end. Makes you think a lot about expectations in friendship, how you spend your time, and recurrent depression.
I don't like to have to think that hard when I go to the movies for entertainment.  Drippy, downer of a movie. Excellent acting and cinematography.
Interesting but it was too exaggerated.
Naw, not worth the effort. The idea was good, but so far over the top and with a pointless ending. Lots of talent here, but a poor direction was taken by the creators.

Horrible story!  RT should have a 'disturbing violence' rating.  
Yes, the scenery.  Yes, the acting.  But, really?!
Beautifully shot, but boring depressing storyline.

The Banshees of Inisherin is a stunning dark comedy/drama feature that stars two of the best Irish actors ever to grace our screens with their presence. And that is what this film has in abounds, presence. 

A strong character piece is what holds this film together in that the characters are so well played that you almost forget the surroundings or somewhat lack of them since the island is very barren. 

Colin and Brendan play off each other perfectly and their natural accents just went hand in hand with the vernacular of the time it was set (1923), ending half of their lines with '...so?' Was a good example of the attention to detail when it came to making the speaking parts as authentic as possible.

The most noteworthy part about this movie, for me, is Colin Farrells unexpectedly brilliant performance. Not unexpected because I don't expect brilliance from him, but he was outstanding in this role and as someone who wasn't too hot on 'In Bruges', that came as a surprise. 

Gleeson is equally great and menacing with his own peculiar intent. The whole mix gives you an idea of small island life in the time of the Irish civil war, although it doesn't play much of a part in the film.

I give this movie 91%, I'd say 95-96%, but I think I'd have gone with a slightly different ending which could have perfected it for me.
Great acting and interesting story. Started as a dark comedy, but second half turned into a dark and sad film.

Exactly the kind of strange movie that critics fall over themselves for as great "art" while the audience says, "huh?"  The behavior of the character Colm makes no sense whatsoever in context. It's an outrageous reaction to nothing to speak of and drives what began as a lovely movie down the weirdest path. The movie seemed wonderfully enchanting until it wasn't. Bad trip for all concerned. To the critics who say this is an allegory to the ongoing (circa 1919) Irish civil war, continued rule by Great Britain seems much more compelling than what Padaric did not do.

Andy Wharol'15 minutes of celebrity for everyone has been reduced to 3 minutes on Tik Tok for everyone, but no one leaves a trace of her/his existence.

This is the futile struggle of a man, Colm, isolated in an isolated tiny world, where echoes of big facts are just very far noises. 

And in this little civil war he lost all, mainly the possibility to give the joy of friendship to a simple good man.

Very good direction and acting.
I loved the film.  Almost a masterpiece.  I imagine it's not for everyone but it certainly touched me.  Wonderful cast and glorious scenery (and animals!)

Despite the sad theme, the acting and scenery were outstanding!  Collin Farrell deserves a best actor award.  The screenplay, casting, music, everything was the best I've seen in years.  Yes, it's theme is dark and brooding, but hurts so good.
Apenas bom, não consegui me conectar completamente, A fotografia e as atuações são muito boas.
Although the cinematography and scenery are incredible, it just didn't live up to the accolades being handed out.  The story was confusing and illogical.  Acting was great but the story wasn't.
Reaching for susbstance and under achieving.  Boring movie about depression, rejection aspiration and nothing.  Slow as hell.
The Golden Globes had this in the wrong category. There is nothing comedic or musical about this film. It was a beautiful film. Well acted. Donkey, heartbreaking. Watch it.
Horrifyingly slow and sad. Ruin your whole day kind of movie.

Cards on the table, I'm Irish so have a somewhat jaundiced view of how film world has often portrayed 'Oireland' in the past. Needn't have fretted though, in McDonaghs very capable and safe hands all was well with this wonderfully shot jet black film, delivered with warm comedic touches that explores so many themes quite close to Irish hearts. The scenery and cute critters aside, this was more Shakespeare or Greek tragedy than Hollywood, with Trojan performances by the 2 leads, especially Farrell and incredible supporters, particularly Barry Keoghan who should never have to audition for a part again after his astonishing playing of the village 'gom'
In short, it is beautiful, tragic, funny, sad, dark and should NOT be missed. See it with an Irish woman's blessing.
Excellent acting across the board & Assured directing and Cinematography. Won't be everyone's cup of tea but I really enjoyed it.

It started off with an interesting premise and went quickly into the toilet.
My husband wanted to turn the movie off before I did because of the gory content which seemed really unnecessary.  There were so many other ways to convey the
content than the gory method employed.  So disappointing, lazy and dim witted.

I am still thinking about this story today.  What is friendship and how does it form and remain vital?  What is one's responsibility to one's friends?   Is being nice more valuable than being important.  What is the meaning of life. What does one do when a friend is clearly depressed and is there anything that can stop it?
I loved the characters and the scenery was stunning.

Although the backdrops were stunning, i felt the film was very slow and never really got going enough to grab your interrest ! Dark comedys dont exacly grab me in general, i find them depressing ! Comedy should be funny not dark !
OMG this was hilarious! Another one I put off watching and really enjoyed it.
For Gods sake just leave the man alone!!! Like watching a riddle that’s never explained and you don’t care enough to try to figure it out.

What the heck did  I just watch and who on earth thinks this is a comedy? Just a sad slow slog. The only redeeming quality is the beauty of the country side. Just watch it with the sound off and enjoy scenery. Terrible story unless you enjoyed your close reading classes in grammar school where everything has some other hidden meaning .

The most beautiful film i have ever seen. Truly. Cried out so many tears as it is not an easy one to watch (though the funny light-hearted moments help to go through!) But in the end, it revealed such a deep, profound message about humanity; our fears, hopes, anger that leads to wars.... A masterpiece. Excellent roles, music, screenplay, pictures, EVERYTHING. You must watch it!

Banshees of inisherin is one of those movies you watch, it doesn't blow your mind or anything of the sort, but it deeply affects you in its  themes and in its perfect execution. 

Mcdonagh once again pulls off a great comedy with a deep exploration of human nature. Here we explore the fear of loneliness. Something we all fear, but something we all eventually have to experience. 

Everything flows so naturally in this film, the jokes  are well executed and balanced. The movie doesn't try to make you cry or make you feel sorry for someone.

It's far from a must watch, but It's a good piece of film that will leave you thinking about you, your relationships and leaves you wondering "Am I lonely?"
funny and sad movie, got deeper and darker as it progressed, which just gave it more impact.  Great performance from Gleeson, Farrell and the donkey.
Nah. Not for me. Too dark and actually didn't get the reasoning for some of the plot.  No character explanations. Also I felt too many Irish stereotypes going on.

I give this four stars because nearly every aspect of this movie is about as close to perfect as can be . . . it's missing a star because of the story (though not the story-telling). To say the movie is dark and depressing is an understatement. These are about a group of Irish living on there small island off the coast of Ireland, where there's not much to do except go to church, hit the pub, usually at 2 p.m. every afternoon, and talk about the same things over and over again. Or talk about trivial things over and over again . . . so much so that one character simply ends a friendship because he no longer can listen to the man's palaver. In fact, he's willing to cut off a finger at a time to convince his ex-friend (Colin Farrell) that he no longer can stand his company. These are people who are stuck in their loneliness and do not have the "inner resources" to deal with their isolation from one another as well as themselves. Even some of the farm animals, particularly a miniature donkey, get  caught up in the darkness that seems to be everywhere. (Also of note, at least in terms of the way the film uses a Bergmann-like symbol in the dress and speech of an old woman they call the Ghoul; a Fellini-like symbol comes in the occasional explosion of cannon fire to the east of a "war" or rebellion that is due to cease any day now.) I did like this move, though honestly I doubt I'll ever sit through it again. Just about every aspect, great or small, about this movie rings true in most of our lives. Loneliness, the inarticulation of isolation that leads to rage--or the quiet moment where you either go mad and harm yourself . . . or take it out on anything you can get your hands on in the moment.

Not funny, slow, morose and ultimately a depressing outing. At the end of the day, entertainment should be at the forefront of art, and Banshees failed to provide the opening that spurs interest in seeking hidden meanings. Sad to see this from such a brilliant cast and director.
I do not understand the buzz for this movie. It was not funny and it was not entertaining. It was depressing and tragic in a bad way.
It's long past time that Colin Ferrell was awarded with an Oscar.
Boring and just a bit pointless

I kept waiting and waiting for something to happen. The storyline is wish wash pointless. Grey, sad characters with very low IQ's. Odd yet intriguing just wished for more emotion and intensity and even conversation between characters. Overall feeling of ‘this is odd'. Hmmmm

A sad tale told through amazing writing by Martin McDonagh and the masterful acting performances of Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson and (IMHO the show stealer) Barry Keoghan all taking place on the small Irish island of Inisherin. An amazingly beautiful location to shoot, and the cinematographers do well to show you it all from the cliffs to the beaches, to the small town square, to our 2 best friends local watering hole. All taking place in the early 1920s on the outskirts of the Irish Civil War, that can be seen raging just over on the mainland.

This film has a bit of Irish folk music throughout, as the story is partly centered around Gleeson's character writing a new song, as well as some of the fecking drama that 'potentially' could encompass the people of such a small Island community, told in a dark comedic way.
Hit my soul to be honest. Every word is worth thinking. Beautiful scenes.

Or a perfect movie, but a really, really good one. Excellent acting. Original story. Beautifully shot. Good, complex characters that develop and change. This won't be for everyone. There's no action, but there is some dark comic relief. It's mostly a slowly developing drama about people living on an island off the coast of Ireland at the end of the civil war there in 1929 (?). There's a lot of sadness. it's gripping and dark. If you like this sorta thing, you'll definitely like this movie.
A great student film at best…

As an irishman i can't help but think I am biased in my review but this movie tells such a genuine story. I am no patriot to my country nor do i even agree with half of it but this story feels so distinctly irish, an absolute must watch in my opinion a truely beautiful film with an incredible cast easily one of my favourite movies of the year
Beautiful scenery, great acting, slow very sad story. Not sure what the message was. Respect boundaries, loneliness can kill you?

I know that humor is subjective, but calling this grim tale a "comedy" astounds me. Critics called it "remarkably hilarious" ; "often very funny";  "shot through with bristling humor"  Really? What part? The bleak island life part? The loneliness part? The self-mutilation part? That sad soul washing up dead part? The ending (spoiler alert) when you realize that it's not over until one of the two is dead?

The LOL incident with Colm and the priest going at it in the confessional is entirely out of character with the movie. About as jarring as a stand-up comedian on the train in "Schindler's List" would have been.

Though, as for that, if people can see "Banshees" as a comedy, it wouldn't shock me to find out people somehow found humor in THAT movie . . .
Great performances but too preach. This is like one of those bad ‘Christian movies’ with its blatant metaphors and boring speeches.
Wickedly funny, dark and bleak. The countryside is morose and beautiful and you're left feeling empty in the best way.
fakey cutie deedle-dye leprechaun Lucky Charms Irish -- overacted, overwrought, patronizing -- faux-gritty -- couldn't stand this cartoonish tomfoolery and buffoonery
A fantastic movie, the Irish countryside looks incredible.

Absolutely terrible!  Wasted time I can never have back. This year has been the worst year in movies. Tell the writers and producers to pull their heads out of each others asses and make something worth our time
How! Why? Remember, just one man's opinion..but that was bloody awful!! (Pun intended)

Well it's not a comedy. It's one of the saddest movies I have ever seen. Pure heartbreak and just makes you feel lost. It touches a part of every person who just wants to be loved. Well written, great acting, but not uplifting. Watch it and forget it or you will end up eating a bullet.
Extremely underwhelming

Visually engaging and Farrell is kind of funny in parts. What really amazes me is how something like this can gain so many positive, praising reviews. Did they watch a different film from me? Don't these people have capacity for boredom? I was bored out of my mind. I think it was trying so hard to be clever and funny. You could see all the seams real well. So much better out there. Watch 20 mins then snap-decide if you want to dedicate 2 hours of your only life to this.

Went in expecting a light-hearted slice of soap, but it's so much more. Brilliantly funny to begin with, then heartbreakingly sad as it goes on. Wonderful performances from all, and although I had to read up on the allegory, it works just as well without knowing it. Recommended.

Story of imagination.  Start with one friend who won't talk to his former friend.  Add in his rage because his friend continues to want his friendship .  Rage becomes his self mutilation. Even worse because he destroys his ability to play music.  Then make it sad by having the guys pet die.  Throw in a witch that predicts everything because after all it is Ireland.  Next have a fire.  Save the lovely dog . Yea!  Add in magnificent scenery!  Interesting but I could have written it.  No maybe not.  I don't think I would have thought  of the self mutilation part.  That was unique!  But not realistic because if you did that I'm sure the pain would be out of this world pain.
Amazingly dark but funny film. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson are so good. One of my favorites of the year, and I hope it does well in all the awards shows later this year.

A VERY VERY DARK comedy, beautifully acted. It's worth watching just to see an incredible acting job of Barry Keoghan....it's so nuanced and beautifully acted it's worth watching just for him. But really all of the actors are brilliant. It is a bit squeamish in a few parts...the build up is very tense too.

I have to give this movie all 5 stars.  The script... omg so good.  It feels like the movie would be slow but no, every scene is so great and fun to watch.  Amazing film.  Stellar acting and such an interesting story.

Love all McDonagh's movies with the exception of this movie. Bewilderingly, RT gives this movie McDonagh's highest score. It is watchable and gets just a passing grade from me. It moved along far too slow. After the first 10 minutes you find out Gleeson's character no longer wants to be friends with Farrell 's and an hour later that is still about all you know. Dark humour that is one of McDonagh's strengths as a writer seems absent here. The symbolism of the broken friendship and the war on the mainland is weakly connected. It is the type of movie critics give best picture to but less enjoyed by general audiences.

Banshees of Inisherin is definitely not bad. It's got good writing. Let me rephrase; it's got great writing! It's the writer's ability that creates a two-hour drama out of such limited cast and locations. However, it fails to go beyond its great script and become a great motion picture as it fails to convey the greatness of its story (assuming it is) through meaningful cinematography. Evidently, the author is aware of this shortcoming as he (assuming it is) repeatedly throws footage of beautiful natural features such as landscapes and animals with little to no relevance to the plot development.

Apart from that, good acting and mise-en-scene are top two contributing factors to the enjoyability of the experience of watching this movie.
Loved the actors but hated the tale.  Too weird, too disgusting, too sad.
What was the point of this movie?

Charming. Whimsical. Metaphorical. Timeless. Hilarious in places but terribly sad in others. A tale of friendship, relationships, aging, and broken dreams with the canons of a civil war across the water punctuating. Wonderful performances from everyone in the cast but a brilliant, heartbreaking turn from Barry Keoghan and Colin Farrell at his very best sit atop a cream filled crop. Martin McDonagh is an excellent and prolific writer who never strays too far from the simplicity of "you killed my cat, so I'm a kill yours" although "You can choose your friends but can't choose your family" seems to be the major theme here, (with a little of the former). Loved it.

Always interesting to see lifestyles and this film certainly did a good job in showcasing the Irish island regime. Additionally it is a pleasure to see the fine cast of assembled do their work. However unlike "In Bruges" where Gleeson & Farrell clicked so wonderfully, the characters they portray in this movie are so pathetic it is hard to watch. Makes anyone with a backbone want to do some punching.

It for me was in 3D: 
Dull, depressing, and demented. 
So much so I think I need to wash out my brain.
The smart one got off that forsaken island, 
the rest were a bunch of "nut bags."
How does that make a good movie.
They say it was at least scenic, 
but even the island itself was depressing:
Who was the sad soul that had to pile all those rocks.
A superb film. The writing, the performances, the cinematography, the setting are sublime.

Watched most of the movie with a friend. We got tired and called it a night. He told me to let him know if the movie got good. I finished and sadly, it didn't. Great acting and setting! Although, a 97% on rotten tomatoes is baffling. Makes me wonder how some of these critics have a job. Extremely misleading score. It's a slow burn, doesn't leave a lasting impression, the hidden meanings they weren't very obvious to the average viewer, overall not worth the watch. You're not missing much other than Collin Farrell's versatility when it comes to acting.

I understand the low audience score...but I agree with the critics: this is a very good movie.  Tired of the same plots being used over and over again in Hollywood?  THIS is definitely a unique story!  You must remember: this is a comedy.  Well, it's a comedy, a tragedy, a drama.   I did laugh several times throughout the movie...it's so...ridiculous!  And of course, I felt the heavy dramatic feelings as well.

Finally, somebody made a new movie! Not just the same old recycled themes over and over and over. It gets a bonus just because of that. Excellent acting. Top 10 movie of 2022 which isn't saying much because of the lackluster movies this year but this one is very good.
Brilliant!! A Best Picture in my book!

I am baffled by the positive reviews. A bleak movie about a not so bright guy and his  seemingly normal friend. Clearly the seemingly normal guy is mentally ill based upon his actions. If you are into scenes of self mutilation and the death of an adorable miniature pet donkey, all set against a backdrop of impending war, this is the movie for you.

Dark, thought provoking and profound, interspersed with laughter and sadness. Amazing acting and amazing backdrop. It's a movie not designed to entertain in the usual way but more to take you on a journey. Leave your expectations behind and let the movie take you down its dark, humorous road.
Wonderful performances, but every time we start to feel a little hope in Colin Farrells' character, another massive heart break occurs. Great storytelling albeit depressing.
Funny, unrelenting, focused comedy and fable. Great acting, writing, film making. Great score! Don't miss this one.
Loved this one. Gonna be a strong awards contender.

It's ok to say fuck off and get on with your life.
See you at the Pub
Not really my cup of tea, but it's an original idea,  filmed in beautiful settings. I can see why some will love it. Story is just a bit weird for me
Not an upbeat film but more interesting than most. Wouldn't say it's much of a comedy except at the very beginning. excellent acting.

I created an account just so I could rate this - it is so.... depressing.  Positives:  Stunning cinematography, excellent acting across the board - each actor in this small cast gave a great performance.  But... Negatives:  Incredibly sad.  Look at the stills/images again on the main review page... notice not a single smile - what you see is what you get!  For two hours, endless forlorn looks of sorrow.  I don't understand how this is categorized as a comedy... it's anything but.  I wanted to stop but kept watching, hoping for a revelation or an inspired ending.  Instead it just went deeper into the well.  It's as if the movie wanted to immerse the audience in the despair of the characters - make them physically and mentally feel the depth of sadness themselves.  If you like overcast skies, rocks upon rocks upon rocks, somber looks, mental illness, self-mutilation, cruelty, loneliness, rejection, dead animals, suicide, and the most miserable set of people one could imagine... this movie is for you.  You will probably see this as "art".  If you are like me and had Ireland on your bucket list to visit someday - beware that this movie may make you think again (or go grab a pint... by yourself).

The first half is intriguing, with great acting and spectacular scenery. Then halfway through it suddenly turns into bloody melodrama with little reason or motivation, and the whole thing loses all credibility. They say the Irish are all half mad - well this confirms it.

Beautiful film, both visually and in content. A story of what we'll do to hold onto what little we have and what happens when it all goes away. 

The entire cast is brilliant but Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleason are extraordinary. Both give powerful performances as their characters circle each other and their lives circle the drain.
A nearly perfect movie. Demonstrates the power of a great screenplay. Laugh-out-loud funny and deeply moving with fantastic performances and beautiful cinematography.

I had seen Bruges and loved it, so I had high expectations of this movie.  In the first 10 minutes though, I knew it would be a film that the critics would drool over, but the audience would be divided.  Put me in the disappointed category.

Yes, the cinematography is amazing.  Much of the acting (Kerry Condon as Siobahn in particular) is superb. But the story starts dark and just gets darker, with little context to support the basic premise.  And spare me the parallels with the Irish Civil war, which are touched on briefly and again without context.  

Yes, there is a theme about mental illness and depression, which could be meaningful. But other than Siobahn, almost everyone in the story seems to be on Colm's side---even though he's clearly out of his mind and is a man who goes out of his way to be cruel.

The movie could have gone broader with the humor, or been a more serious examination of the issues above.  Instead it dropped dead for me in the middle.
a very powerful story that has no winners or anyone to claim victory .

Worth watching for the great scenery and cinematography. It's about a small depressing story, but the nature is wild. I like the remote and timeless setting, it looks like something in the past, no phones nor internet, but could be now.

1 star for cinematography - 1 star for acting (including the animals!) - 1 star for the dialogue - 1 star for the score - but that last star not given is for the terribly downcast feeling this film leaves you with. Which perhaps also deserves a star, perhaps that's what it's supposed to do.

The scenery is gorgeous, long quiet shots, perfect for a grey Sunday afternoon in January. The score is elegant and unassuming, not at all pushy into your ears, but comes in assertively at exactly the right moments, ranging from traditional Irish folk music to opera and 1920s jazz. You're eyes or ears won't feel full, too full, visuals and sounds are just right, tactful.

The dialogue is as sparse, but as just right. People say the things need saying, although as a 21st century person with a couple of years of therapy under your belt you want to prescribe everyone a few months of group therapy to just learn how to talk to each other. But that's not the point of the film of course. There's charm in dysfunction to (if we don't have to experience it).

The acting is amazing, doesn't feel like acting at all, and Farell's hurt face that shows the pained bafflement of his character who just doesn't get what's going on, why his world is falling apart -- it's deeply moving. There's also some gentle comedy of manners with the worldly priest, evil policeman, gossipy shop owner, witchy old woman. All this is fun and deserves the label of comedy. But mostly this is *not* a comedy.

Apart from the allegory/allusions to the Irish Civil War  -- which I didn't entirely get as a non-Irishperson with limited knowledge about the post-1916 Ireland(s) -- the film shows how depression leaks into life poisoning those around you. If you don't do anything about it. That said from someone with medium depressive symptoms. The character of Colm projects his fears of death and despair at a meaningless life onto his former best friend, punishing Padraic for his own inability or unwillingness to engage with his issues. Padraic feels like a rug has been snatched from under his feet and refuses to accept his best friend's rejection. It's like a sudden unexpected break-up and it's insanely painful to watch Padraic's world unravel, and him lose his core kindness. 

Padraic gives a lovely speech on the value of kindness before everything, and this was touching and precious. People are also extremly bonded with their animals, which also offers some saving graces to this bleak and depressing film - yet enjoyable! If you know it's going to be emotionally tough, slowly unfolding, and leaving you feeling miserable and glad that it's over, you can actually enjoy it, and allow yourself space to experience difficult uncomfortable emotions.

We came out discussing the film, both feeling it was very good and very terrible at the same time. We still keep talking about it, and I've never been on rotten tomatoes but came here to talk about the film. So. It's a good film. In the manner of old, of greek Tragedy. It's work. Entertainment and work. As it should be

Beautifully acted, shot, directed... BUT!
You will absolutely not enjoy watching it.  Nothing in the story makes you feel good about anything in life, and you certainly won't watch it again.  If you recommend it to anybody you will 100% have caveats regarding watching it.  You won't say "oh yeah it's great..." and leave it at that.  You will say "oh it's well acted, but..."  

If you're looking for a movie that makes you depressed about life.  This is a good start.  You'll also look "artsy" by saying you liked it.
Totally depressing and not at all what I expected. Wish I had the two hours of my life back! This was billed as a comedy! Beautiful scenery is the only thing good about this weird and very sad movie.
While the dialogue is sharp and witty, the movie is just too slow and unexciting. I wanted to like it, but I just could not get into it.
Weird, sad, hard to even understand what they are saying. Worst off, it's billed as a "comedy"? There's nothing funny about it.
This is the worst movie I have ever seen in my entire life!!! I don't understand how that's a comedy? Maybe it would get funny if the guy started to cut his toes too! Come on this movie is stupid!!!
Brilliant acting but a great cast of actors was wasted on a terrible story line which was absolute rubbish. I don't know what all the fuss is about.

A promising odd couple comedy of manners is ruined by a disturbingly dark tonal shift into nihilistic revenge. This film sacrifices its first half of charm and wit for a too-clever-by-half civil war allegory which no doubt will have highbrow critics in spams of delight, but left me feeling cold and cheated.
I saw this in the theatres and it really touched me in a way no movie has in a few years. Colin Farrells acting is phenomenal and the overall message is incredibly simple yet profound. I loved it.

This wonderful movie serves as a simple metaphor of the cause of so much human suffering and war. Set in the background of the Irish civil war. One person gets their feelings hurt and before you know it homes get burned. Great acting and cinematography!
Brilliantly wring, acting and directing. A must see!
My Irish-American blood wasn't enough to make this more than average. Scenery hard to beat, some funny moments, outside of that? Bleh.

This was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I loved In Bruges. This film seems to have no reason to exist. I don't understand how anyone would like it. The critics must all on drugs. You have been warned.

This is a flawless film for those that understand its underlining metaphor in relation to The Irish Civil War and a stellar one for those who do not. Either way, all the performances are fantastic with Barry Keoghan being simply perfect. It's slow-moving but so full of life and substance, comical yet despairing. Like all true Irish Art.

This is one of the few times I completely agree with the top critics. This movie is outstanding. Over the top exceptional acting by the leads as well as the supporting cast. Beautiful filming location and cinematography. Cannot recommend this one enough.

I was actually very disappointed in this film. It received high praise from film critics that I watch. I just can't share their opinion on this. It was the most depressing, bleak film I have seen in a while. Sure, there were some nice laughs. I also don't mind a movie evoking strong emotion. However, this story was just a lot of cruelty. It entered such a ridiculous turn that I didn't know what to feel afterwards. I understand the destruction that depression causes, I do. This film... I don't know. I felt that I never wanted to see it again. It confused me on an emotional level.
Aside from the scenery, this was feckin shite.

Character-based movie—tons of attention to detail for them all and great acting. Some interesting touches you might notice.

Sad.

I saw this movie in a theatre. I was surprised how much I liked it. There's alot of good humour in it and a nice small cast. By the end of the movie I came to realize that with the amazing soundtrack as a backdrop, essentially an opera, that I was in fact watching an opera! It was great. A few good actors, only 1 that I new of, that grow on you, lots of laughs, but then a deep drama unfolding.

Last night I finally watched The Banshees of Inisherin and what a strange but fantastic movie it was. I really can't explain why I love it so much. Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson work so well together which is ironic because it's a movie about them not working well together. I mean what a great way to tell a story of depression and mental illness. This movie is a lot funnier than I was expecting until it takes a dark turn and then continues to take dark turns as you go on. The levels of escalation to the friendship issue are absurd. Kerry Condon is just as good as the boys if not better, really making a large part for herself in this story. Barry Keoghan really knows how to just melt into a role! His character is so different from any role of his I've seen before and a great role it is. Gary Lydon and Jon Kenny are wonderful supporting actors who give so much life to this island where it would be otherwise "dull". Sheila Flitton plays such an interesting character that adds a great level of mystery to the story. I loved seeing that the animals got an acting credit in this, the animals of the movie are fantastic and interact with the actors and the environment so well. And they're just so darn precious. I get why I've only heard good things about this movie and I'm really excited to see what Oscar nominations this will have and what it can win, this is going to be a very tough year because it's been such a great year. The Banshees of Inisherin is definitely going to be the top of a lot of lists for very good reason. From the acting and score to the excellent directing and the execution of that direction. This film is a beautiful story of mental illness set to the background of the Irish Civil War that just works on every level. I would definitely recommend giving this 10/10 of a movie a watch, I currently have it ranked at 6 for the year but we'll see what happens. Hop onto HBO Max and decide for yourself though. -Tyler.
So this is quite the change of pace. You'll get lost in the story. An immersive one at that in which keeps you interested until the final frame. Refreshing and odd. Love the combo
Colin Farrell and Brendon Gleeson are wonderful in this film.
Really really disappointing and emotionally fatiguing. First 20 minutes was decent then only grief and griping. I love In Bruges so even more disappointed by this mess.

Beautiful scenery, interesting characters, enjoyably portrayed. By turns, strange, humorous, ridiculous & finally, _disquieting_. My wife and I both agreed we'll be talking about this one, for awhile (a bit like we did 'Midsommer'). It's a journey, it just doesn't arrive quite where you'd expect.
Another masterpiece from director Martin McDonagh. What a director, and especially what a writer. Quirky, funny, dark, spellbinding. One of the best film of the year.

I found the story confronting, basically the story is about severing of a relationship, no explanation, the sense of abandonment from one's community, compounded by the lost of his beloved pet, the main character tries so hard to be accepted by his friend, however the shift in power comes and there is no return .
The cinematography is truly beautiful,  the script is witty with black humour, as in all small communities,  the local busybody is present and the symbol of death is represented by an old lady.
Collin Farrell is truly convincing , in my opinion he deserves an Oscar next month , he is able to be convincing in displaying all human frailties but he has those deep black eyes that are quite intimating.    Please go and see the movie , I guarantee you will think about the value of respect and empathy.
GENIUS! A masterpiece for those who dare to watch! I haven't laughed out loud during a movie in quite a long time.

The Banshees of Inisherin is simple & perfect. I ain't first to say this & definitely not the last.

I "fecking" love the dialogues & accent.

Kinda like The power of the dog which scored many Oscar nominations. This will too

Самый худший и унылый фильм года. Не представляю как с такими актерами можно было снять такой маразм. Персонажи вызывают только отвращение, весь фильм ждал что начнется хоть что-то интересное, но этого так и не случилось.
Havent laughed so hard since death of Stalin.
Fabulous human story!

must see
 i'm afraid that we have already now the best movie of the year 2023

The Banshees of Inisherin is a stellar film with fantastic cinematography, tremendous performances, and an intriguing plot that will stay with viewers long past the credits. The stories set up does a fantastic job at engaging the audience, we feel for Padraic, truly wanting to know why his lifelong friend would "ghost" him. This sense of despair soon leads to horror as the plot progresses, creating some uncomfortable moments for both our main character and the audience. Overall, there is just something about this movie that is able to hook me. I had many laughs mixed while feeling completely heartbroken for Padriac. It is a slow burn film, with not much action, but the performances and dialogue are able to carry this movie to completion, resulting in a very unique experience.

Score: 88%
Verdict: Excellent

I truly believe Mr. Mcdonagh has genuinely captured the spirit of Irish island life in this beautiful, yet stark representation of the Aran Islands. The performances of Gleeson, Farrell, Condon, Lydon and Keoghan were as expected, flawless. Now I acknowledge that this tale is dark, and a bit quirky at times, but so is Ireland. That is some of the absolute charm of the country. Many valid questions were raised throughout the film, such as what lifelong friendship and the pall of mortality do to an individual. So, if you’re looking for a Hallmark movie, this will not be your cup o’ tea…but for dark Irish comedy, this offering is spot on!
What a great movie. The actors were perfect, the story is weird and interesting, and the photography is phenomenal. One of the best I have seen in a long while.

Brilliant. Wonderful characterizations. Remarkably atmospheric. A tough story of sundered friendship with a thread of humour in it. The occasional cannon fire in the distance and the wise woman add to the sense of menace. The violence of the garda officer reveals the truth of the community.
Simply put "Brutal" worst movie I've seen in a long time and everyone that I've spoken to agrees . Gleeson should hang his head in shame.

The Banshees of Inisherin grabs you right from the start with its gorgeous locale, excellent cinematography to show it off, and great music. It then immediately proceeds to pull you in further with its very human characters and believable and snappy dialogues. The core story itself isn't especially exciting, but it has heart and is presented in a way not many movies can come close to.

The accolades are proof of the human need to extract some kind of meaning out of pure pablum. Take my advice (or warning if you like): if you continue this film to its pointless end, hoping for some deeper meaning, convinced that the hidden reason driving one man to simply cut another from his life will be revealed, you will be sorry. You will know as little at the end as the beginning, and the only thing profound will be your disappointment.
Subtle humor in the first two acts, unexpectedly insightful in the third act.
A black comedy without much comedy. The acting was great but the blackness of this movie means I won't be recommending it to anyone.

The Banshees of Inisherin is a near flawless film. A film of great substance, humour and insight. One of the best films of 2022. Martin McDonagh makes films of greatness and this one might be his best yet. Set in 1923 on a remote island off the coast of Ireland it follows 4 people essentially. Padraic, a farmer, and his sister Siobhan. Colm, a musician and the younger Dominic, a dim lad from a troubled home. One day Colm tells Padraic that their friendship is over, instructing him to not speak to him again. Padraic is naturally bewildered. Even more so when Colm threatens to start cutting his fingers off if he is spoken to. It transpires that Colm is bored by life and Padraic's conversation. He wants more, he needs more. Set against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, this film is about internal civil wars. It's about depression and loneliness and the tenuous bonds of friendship. Like McDonagh's other films, and plays, it is wickedly funny but also incredibly moving and at times desperately sad. Not a frame is wasted and even though it can be bleak at times it looks truly magnificent, showing off the beauty of the island setting. The score aids this beautifully too and the performances are just superb. Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell are in career best form, whilst Kerry Condon is special as the sister who also desires more. And Barry Keoghan steals every scene he appears in. A film that rewards in every way possible.
There was a lot to like about this movie but I couldn’t get over some of the gruesome parts of it. It’s ultimately very depressing, the acting was very good though.

I had heard such great things about this film and I was excited to be able to see it.  For me it just didn't deliver.  I didn't really connect to the characters or understand them.  Also the story just didn't have enough there to keep me engaged.  I hate to say it.. while they call the characters boring in the movie... the story was just boring to me.  I guess that is by design.. but for me it wasn't worth it when watching this film.

The actors certainly did well and did the best with the material.  I just didn't feel like they had enough to work with.  The story and the characters just didn't go anywhere and it really felt flat for me unfortunately.  I had wanted to enjoy the film.. but it just didn't work for me.
There wasn't much that was good about this movie. It was tripe
I couldn't stop thinking about the movie afterwards. It lingered in my mind for days. The two main actors are brilliant.

The acting? Stellar. 
The scenery and cinematography? Top notch.
For whatever reason this movie was not written for me and I acknowledge that. The idea that it should have run on for as long as it did is preposterous, this was a 30 minute idea padded with fluff and glacial pacing. Haiku time:

Join me in accents
The plot is baked with absurd
Prepare to go 'Huh?'

Mak D.
Well acted. Interesting plot but very depressing. Would not recommend to anyone who does not love dark films.

Impeccably acted by everyone, beautiful shot but really it is a movie about nothing. At best this might make interesting bar/pub small talk. But this is dullness disguised as art because of how great the actors are and the scenery is. Paint drying.
Like a lot of critics darlings, great acting and character nuance, but narrative story is meh.
Colin Ferrell was excellent and deserves recognition, but the story was not captivating.  It's subtle and somewhat interesting, but not great except for Colin.
I quote myself as the credits rolled "well, I'm not sure what that was all about but I loved it"
Honestly, who in their right mind would think this was a comedy!  This was the darkest and most disturbing movie I've watched in a long time.  Hated, hated, hated this movie.
Why did they have to give so much camera time to the stump?! Eek! Great characters, gorgeous location, engaging story. I appreciated the philosophizing about art and what makes a meaningful life.
Amazing performances. An accurate war metaphor so melancholic and bizarre as humans. Great animal message.  I absolute love this movie.
A beautiful film you can discuss for hours.  Everyone has a different take on the main theme, the virtues and vices of the main characters, the biggest surprises and saddest scenes.

Tremendously funny, and equally sad, this is a wonderful movie to watch. The scenery, the language and the depiction of the times and place was stunning - it had my complete attention for every minute. All of acting and the characters were bang-on.
Fresh story wonderfully acted. Enjoyed it!

Maybe the lesson about making sacrifices for art was a little too much for me. Acting was great, especially the donkey, but I was bored. Bored, confused waiting for the magic that just didn't happen. Maybe I'm just too flu ridden to get it. Depressing.
A fascinating look into irish culture with an unique take on it.

As a huge fan of "In Bruges" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", I was excited to see Martin McDonagh's "The Banshees of Inisherin". The film exceeded my expectations, not only because it feels more mature and focused in its storytelling than McDonagh's previous works, but also because it is more character driven and strikes the perfect balance between tragedy, human foibles, and acerbic, laugh-out-loud humor. This is quite the dark, cynical story to be sure, but at times I was cracking up at the behavior and motivations of the characters.

Two life-long best friends, played by Colin Farrell (in what might be his best performance to date) and Brendan Gleeson, live on the small Irish island of Inisherin and hit up the local pub every day at 2 p.m. Life is rather dull and everyone is privy to everyone else's business - you know, the typical small-town mentality and lack of boundaries. When Colm (Gleeson) decides to abruptly end his friendship with Pádraic (Farrell), the two become slowly disheveled and destructive.

The movie explores the deterioration of a friendship, but more so the reasons why people will self-destruct, and is a metaphor for the Irish Civil War. I loved the allegorical undertones in the movie such as the personification of Death in one particular character and all of the death motifs throughout. It's a movie that seems simple at first, but once you peel back all the layers, it's deeply poignant, sad, and packs an emotional wallop.

I loved this film, the cinematography, the music, the performances, were all exceptional. I finished this film feeling extremely emotional. I am also extremely happy that nothing happens to the dog. I recommend it to everyone.
Boring. I was disappointed since this is the same director as In Bruges. That movie is much better.
Great acting, but the script was totally unbelievable. I'm sorry I watched it.

I liked this movie a lot. Good script, good acting, a seriously black comedy where most of the humour was in the language. The portrayal of the Irish Catholicism was handled well. Even the Donkey was good.

This was my introduction to the work of director Martin McDonagh and I have now watched all four of his films. Though this was not my favourite, it was an incredible film and really hit home as I was going through something similar (though not as extreme) with a former friend wanting nothing more to do with me for no reason. 

Overall, I think that this was a funny, yet thought provoking film and McDonagh shows that he really does excel with dark comedy
Great acting beautiful scenery.
Weird weird depressing story. A comedy?? Yeah right...       Loved the scenery but that was all.

This movie was honestly really dumb and I really don't see the point of it. Perhaps my expectations were way too high since it is a nominated film, but the characters actions make no sense and I don't find it very funny like everyone is claiming it to be

Without a doubt "THE MOST DEPRESSING" movie I have ever seen!!!!  I have seen bad movies and sad movies; this movie's lighter moments and excellent cinema photography do not overcome a long depressing spiral.  NO clue how anyone can rate it higher and I watch too many depressing movies.

If there was an option to give this movie less than one star, I would have done that. After two years of pandemic, with the war happening in Europe who would want to make such a depressing movie! How much more depressing it can get. Left the theatre without watching the grand sad finale of this endless torture. Enjoy (not!)
A refreshing film that isn't science fiction, horror, fantasy or super hero based. The film has many great moments and makes you want to visit the island it was filmed on.
A quirky, coming-of-age comedy anyone can relate with. 4.75/5 Stars

Great Acting by the ensemble cast, the performance that stood out to me the most was Barry Keoghan as the Island idiot Dominic, who was deep down a kind person who was abused by his father and sought out other kind people to love him and we could love back. Great soundtrack and Cinematography as well.
Despite the star power involved it doesn't compensate for the slow pace of the script or the sparse humour, not one for me.
Nice scenery. The acting was fair enough but this story is dark and sad and has no redeeming qualities. Not worth the time.

Maybe the saddest movie, start to finish, I've ever seen. At the same time, completely engrossing. I am baffled by IMBD tagging it as a comedy; there is comic relief, some of it utterly hilarious, but it doesn't make it a comedy. Waiting with bated breath for Oscar nominations so theaters will bring it back and I can persuade friends to see it with me. (If you stream it, consider turning captions on. The brogue is true.)
Great directing and scenery but very dark and disturbing
A quality production of a sad story.
Incredible film, very dark humour and genuinely sad. You'll be thinking about this one long after the credits role

Beautifully shot movie with a gripping storyline, exploring the pain and shame of abandonment.  It starts off light hearted and becomes incredibly dark. Unexpectedly dark. No doubt the Irish Americans will demand Oscar recognition.

Martin McDonagh weaves a tapestry of emotions, seamlessly blending humor and heartbreak in a way that's simply masterful. You'll feel like you're on a rollercoaster of emotions, but don't worry, Farrell and Gleeson are there to keep you strapped in with their hilarious duo act. And can we talk about the cinematography? It's so gorgeous, you'll want to frame every single shot. But don't let the pretty visuals fool you - this is a gritty, real-life portrayal of the inner demons that plague us all. McDonagh's men-gone-wrong fable hits hard, leaving you with a sense of existential dread that'll make you question everything you know. All in all, this film is a state of mind - one that's sure to leave an indelible mark on your soul.
Couldn't finish. Too disturbing and not funny.

No bones about it, this is a very, very, dark, dare I say, somewhat twisted comedy? You cannot fault the acting, the characters and the cinema photography. Its superbly done. There's a few gruesome scenes that can be hard to watch, and stomach. I'm still shaking my head at what was going through their minds! Some might say stubborn, beyond belief! 
This may not be for everyone, there's a couple really complex characters in this movie and themes abound. Like, who really is the Banshee?
This will be a a winner at the awards, not sure its a winner with everyone though.
Going to extremes to get rid of that boring friend who rambles, on and on!

December 2022: 74%. Music was good. Acting was strong. Liked the setting. Story was boring. Colin Ferrell's character is just annoying as hell. Then both guys go to stupid extremes as retribution like the one dude cutting off his fingers. Wouldn't rewatch.
The sadness of this "comedy" is inescapable. Story was not believable and did not offer any explanations. Great actors, great scenery wasted on this terrible story.
Horrible. This movie is slow and the content is awful.

Really enjoyed how this movie had me in the first 10 minutes, and the absurdity, but somehow emotional events that play out.  I had to feel for each character and hung on to hope they would rekindle their friendship.  There were humorous parts that made the movie more sincere.  I really liked this one, because it was unlike any movie I've seen before.
The acting and the script were superb , but the movie was hard to watch, because it was incredibly sad. Definitely a movie to see though.

There is so much to like about this film: the casting was exceptional and all the performances, not only the leads but also the supporting characters of the sister and the village 'outsider' were very impressive. The scenery and cinematography were beautiful and memorable and the vibe of the film was hypnotic. I described it to my friend as an Irish yarn that someone might tell as a local story in a pub crossed with a bit of Fargo. I'm eager to see more from this ensemble, especially the director!
I really wanted to love this movie but in all honesty it was not that good.

An intimate exploration of an otherwise simple and absurd conflict between two friends, juxtaposed by the beautiful yet brutal landscape of an isolated Irish island, this film is a must-see for those who appreciate the dark comedy life often brings with immense tragedy. Set in a time period with little of today's distractions, our main characters have no choice but to confront the challenges set in front of them. If you enjoyed In Bruges, you'll enjoy Banshees.

Haunting, atmospheric piece that stays with you for days. Farrell and Gleason are spectacular and play so well off each other you forget you're at a movie. Tightly shot, brimming with emotion and pathos,  No CGI, explosions or special effects. So powerful.

It pains me to write how disappointing this movie was. Between living In Bruges and the reviews for Banshees, I was so excited to finally sit down on NYE to this. Well, that was a mistake. 

I'll be brief. In the movie, various characters are worried about being "dull" yet this movie is exactly that, "Dull" with a capital D. The scenery is stunning and you can't fault the actors who are all simply brilliant but a boring script left them with nothing much to work with. 

I felt little sympathy or connection to any character (other than Declan) and when Shobian left, I wanted to go too. 

I'll re-watch In Bruges to forget this one and hope the next collaboration of this stellar team is better.
Nice scenery & decent enough acting, but a slow, extremely thin, and rather pointless plot.

The Emperor wears no clothes. I cannot fathom how this movie is on "best of 2022 lists." 

It is dull as cold dishwater. Pointlessly cruel and gross. Self-mutilation, child-beating, etc. 

Colin Ferrell is one-note. Gleeson is terrific, though, and the other actors are very good. It is beautifully filmed. But all is wasted in service of a needlessly disturbing story line. I don't mind movies that are upsetting, IF there's a good reason for it. But in this movie, it just seems abusive to the viewer.

I loved the first 2/3 of the same writer's "In Bruges." Then it was ruined by another needlessly cruel and traumatizing plot development, the graphic murder of a young boy.

Life's too short, people.
There's certainly lots to like about this movie, but the plot hinges on people doing things that people just don't do, so I found it unbelievable and, ultimately, unsatisfying.
Stupendous. Provocative and deeply intense view of what it is to live well. Gorgeous to watch and impressive performances. Fantastic film.

The full spectrum of humanity is captured in McDonagh's microcosm of 20th century Ireland. Farrell and Gleeson reprise electric chemistry and there are standout performances from Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan.
For me personally, top movie of 2022.

Not my cup of feckin tea. The only reason I give it one star is because Colin Farrell does a good job. Not quite sure I understand the thought process of the Colm guy. Just doesn't want to be friends one day? I can think of a lot better ways to handle that situation. The movie is just kinda stupid.
Loved it , acting masterclass , makes you think , unsettles your emotions . Second viewing even better .
original tale. great character acting. love seeing movies that surprise and make you 'feel'. this one ticked all the boxes. i think was colin farrells best performance ive seen.superb!

To understand this movie it is vital to realise that the pettiness, the unforgiven offences, and the disproportionate responses to grievances between the principle men on the island is presented as a analogy for the Irish Civil War on the mainland. 

This war, between the Irish who supported the Irish-British treaty and those who opposed it was also a self-destructive and banal conflict where grudges were created and sustained. 

When viewed through the micro-prism of squabbling and rancour on the island, the macro-prison of hatred and bloodshed on Ireland makes more senseless sense.

I hope this helps. 
Kind regards to all, 
John
It's beautiful, well acted, well filmed, and feckin depressing. It sent me into a dark emotional spiral, I regret watching it.

It's a hard lesson done up in good acting and a decent production. But, who wants to spend a couple of hours watching a hard lesson? Points of levity are drowned in the depression of the premise. And this in itself is enough for me to discard the subtext and move on. Which happen to be the lesson anyway.

Halfway through I would have given this a higher rating but it failed to deliver anything interesting, insightful or entertaining and instead left me feeling flat, disturbed and angry for wasting my time. Skip this movie. Freking awful.
Animal death. Abuse. Inane and unnessary conflict.
MM still has the magic. Fantastic cast and script!
Something is missing, but not in the bad sense.
Heartbreaking, thought-provoking and breathtaking

Beautiful Irish scenery...worthwhile story, but hard to understand broad Irish
accent at times. Animals, and the characters' devotion to them,  play a large part of the movie: as they would be
for the era.  Good acting skills...make characters very believable.
Overall, a sad but worthwhile movie.

The absurdity of the outcome of this quarreling makes the movie unwatchable. After dismembering both hands digit by digit the editors had allowed for the smoking fingers intact as well as the petting of his frenemy's dog; read Irish Poems and have some pints with friends, leave this move on pause. Mark my words, watch something else.

Not quite the perfect vessel that In Bruges was, but MM, cast and crew are an excellent formula and while metaphor here tends to beat the story down a bit, it's highly enjoyable and proves character is far more enduring and attractive than CGI.

Irish mates fall out big time on a small island where blokes arrive at the pub in the early afternoon. Not sure why it all had to get so nasty. Probably too much drinking and too little to do, though this is not explored. There's some humour but the self mutilation is appalling. Just talking about it as one of the mates does before actually getting out the shears is a sign of something terribly wrong. What a downer!

This film is a work of art! Everything from the screenplay, the direction, the incredible performances, the score right down to breathtaking backdrop of the west coast of Ireland was spellbinding! A mesmerising must see!!

Gripping. If you're in the mood for melancholy it's a fine companion of a film. Not a popcorn and friends flick, more of a wee dram and solitude watch. 

Immersive acting from the entire cast, felt as though the characters were real people not just actors playing a part.

The story is refreshingly different, if you're tired of Hollywood nonsense, this is a nice palate cleanser for the mind.
Somehow this film managed to be both the funniest and saddest thing I've seen all year...more films like this, please!!
Don't understand how everyone can say this is the best movie of the year when the story is so vanilla and slow and uninteresting. It's pretty awful.

"I just don't have a place for dullness in me life anymore."
"But you live in an island off the coast of Ireland, Colm."

Feckin' loved it. This is such an interesting project when it comes to tone, a tragicomedy in a pastoral setting that deals with one man's sense of purpose and accomplishment clashing with another's contentment with simplicity; neither of them are necessarily wrong or unreasonable in their desires by principle alone, but their beliefs are now fundamentally irreconcilable, leading to conflict. The acting from both Gleeson and Farrell is so sincere, it really conveys what we don't see (the supposed years of sincere friendship, and the resolution of Gleeson's Colm) through the reactions that each deliver to the slightly absurdist premise - there are moments of great humor as Farrell's Pádraic tries to mimic what he thinks Colm wants to see, some emotional authenticity or sophistication that he has never had any use for, only to be faced with metaphorical doors being slammed harder and harder in his face. The dog dragging the shears out of Colm's house is brilliant, a moment of almost slapstick levity in a scene that has a guillotine hanging above it in terms of potential self-harm and Pádraic's inevitable desolation. One of the most character-driven films to come out in 2022. 

It's a bit funny seeing Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell back together again, because In Bruges also had the pair opposite one another with one threatening himself with bodily harm to deter the other. Instead of a gun, this time it's sheep shears. (4.5/5)
What a pleasure to watch. Every scene is perfect on its own, thanks to perfect directing and a stellar cast. The two leads and the two supporting roles are simply incredible. Must see.
Fantastic film, dark, deep and a total masterpiece....Oscar winning...

Great cinematography reminiscent of Roger Pratts Chocolat , warm colours,  wide angle sweeps and detailed framing . Top class acting as to be expected however a weak storyline leaving me underwhelmed and unsure what it was really all about .
Slightly daft if I'm honest and somewhat dreary for me. Really wanted to like it more as was hoping it to be another ' in Bruges' or ' the guard'  I guess but just couldn't get it.
I'm not sure how and why this movie is rated so highly.  I didn't find anything enjoyable about it at all.
Really depressing, not funny at all.  Do yourself a favor and skip to the Secret of Roan Inish.  Same scenery, great director and you won't need a bottle of prozac to get through it.
This was the biggest surprise of the year. Absolutely incredible film. Kudos to Martin McDonagh and team.
An overrated movie , its boring lacking an atmosphere and the story is dreadful - definitely avoid !!!

For a film with a good cast and lots of hype, this one fell pretty flat. The story has some initial appeal -- an older man who decides that he has been wasting his time hanging out with a simpleton friend and abruptly breaks off the friendship. Since they live on a lonely island, it's hard to avoid each other. The jilted friend pushes back and wants to resume their relationship, but the older guy cuts off his own finger as a symbol of how serious he is about never speaking with his old friend again. It goes downhill fast from there and devolves into a mess of stupid scenes and idiotic dialogue, culminating in an incomprehensibly moronic ending. Add in the heavy Irish accents and incessant local folk music and it's very hard to sit through. Do yourself a favor and skip it, even if it somehow garners awards nominations for the acting, which was pretty good, but totally wasted in a movie without a good story.

Amazing performance by Colin Farrell! Brendan Gleeson is inscrutable and obviously mentally ill and the wonderful ensemble cast of regular village folk has no idea how to deal with someone who has gone off the deep end. It is charming at times, cringing at others, but always fascinating and engaging. I drove 45 miles to go see it and don't regret it a bit, it's a wonderful film and I'll be sorely disappointed if Colin doesn't see multiple nominations for his fine portrayal of an innocent soul who learned to be heartless through the pain of betrayal.

strange, dark, funny, thoughtful and very well acted

don´t expect any wild action scenes in this one, it is all done inside the mind
Not sure what all the hype is about. The characters are unrelatable, and the plot is disturbing. Yuck.
I just don't get the rave reviews. Just an utterly pointless film. But then again, I don't think the movies this director creates are for me.

Caveat: I'd recommend it to SOME people I think would take to its rather dark, slow moving, and action-less script. But, I enjoyed it because of its originality, fantastic performances, humor, and some of the subtle themes and philosophical debates it undertakes (like the human condition). With that said, it was very sad, and very slow...so just be prepared.
Nice scenery but the this movie was just plan awful.  Should have been advertised as a move about mental illness and it would have made more sense.  Love the actors normally but this a must avoid.

The movie (IMO) is a microcosm of The Troubles on the mainland. There is blood-letting antipathy but it's hard to explain. How can people living on a lovely small emerald island harm each other? There's a glimmer of hope, but it's small. It's a brilliant movie.
Beautiful, enthralling, and unique.
One of the best movies of 2022. Its a must-watch.

Story telling at its very best - against a gorgeous background - with dream casting and every actor delivering their A game.  We laughed, we cried, and we talked for hours about all it had to say.  This film will reside in your top ten list til the end of time.  Don't miss it!
Well written, well acted, well staged ode to stupidity. It becomes tiresome.

Crazy, funny & sad all three. This is a movie that sticks with you & you think about it a lot - even days later - after viewing. Or at least it was that way for me. I might have to watch it again because the first time through, I didn't necessarily appreciate all of the humor because I didn't know what was going to happen next. I also think some of the metaphors went over my head.

Overall, this film has impacted me significantly. The performances of the leads and side cast members are touching, gripping and comedic. The Banshees of Inisherin delivers a cinematic experience filled with unpredictability and moments bound to shock its audience. Visually this is a stunning film; everything on-screen is glorious to look at, whether it's the scenery, costumes, houses or even just how well scenes of tension are captured. It's certainly a film I wasn't expecting, given Martin McDonagh's previous work. The Director continues to impress movie lovers with an unforgettable journey and a storyline filled with freshness and heart.
I enjoyed this. Thought I wouldn't, but gave it a chance and came out the other side, entertained.

It is a tough show to watch...but everytime I thougth I knew what was going to happen next, I was wrong.  The most surprising screenplay of the year.  Acting was very good.  It's the first time I forgot I was watching Colin Farrell.  He dissolves into his character.  He amazed me.
Performances are unbelievably breathtaking! I am so relieved that the sister escapes that hell.

The is movie has a lot of great reviews so obviously I am not the target audience in this case. The characters spend a fair bit of time deciding who is 'dull' on the small Island it is set on. And for me the story was 'dull' unfortunately. 
'On a more technical side the movie is well shot and has a lot of atmosphere. The main cast is good and everyone pitches in with what they have to work with. I just dont believe the story line, its not credible. It's all rather slow and ponderous.

Very disappointed by this super depressing highly over-rated, simple allegorical story about someone who decides to shun their friend, but then harms himself to make a point... and I guess the point the movie makes is that our resentments or self righteousness really end up hurting ourselves as well others. But why does SUCH A NEGATIVE movie need to be made to make such a basic point. The acting was great, but sheesh, I did not enjoy that AT ALL. I would not recommend this movie to anyone as it seems pointless. It is well constructed, well acted, but the metaphor/allegoric vessel is just so ugly and unnecessary.
Summary: Tedious and depressing, makes one simple point and takes 90 mins longer than necessary making it.

Absolutely stunning! I'm 56 years old, and this is one of the best movies I've seen. The cinematography, music score, location and most importantly the acting was second to none, a totally  mesmerising unforgettable film. It has it all.
Brilliant! Brilliant! Brilliant!
Exceptional acting by Farrell & Gleason & supporting actress/actor!  Beautifully filmed. VERY DARK tho.
Wild film. Definitely not what I was expecting, but in a very good way. Thoroughly enjoyed it!
Time I'm never getting back.
Boring! Don’t bother.

This film is well made and ultimately almost totally unlikable, full of sadness, "despair," and violent self-mutilation. The only truly likable character is the donkey, Jenny, and perhaps Mrs. McCormick, the local witch who is actually right most of the time. Any point of the plot is entirely unclear. A friend of mine (who's of Irish origin) remarked that it's an allegory for the Troubles -- the wars in early 20th C. Ireland. Maybe so, but I'd find it impossible to explain how that is the case. Skip it, you won't come away from watching feeling anything but depressed.

Laughed and cried throughout. Such a beautiful and strange story with poignant underlying historical references. 
Farrell and Gleeson were fantastic.
Colin Farrell was amazing in this, and so was Brendan Gleeson. Also, the scenery makes me want to visit Ireland lol.
This is what movies should be. Impeccably acted and scripted and performed.
Dull. The movie has no content worth watching , incredibly boring and predictable.
Story is dark but has so many fascinating layers. Colin Farrell is absolutely remarkable. Cinematography is beautiful.

Spoilers: It happens on an unreal island, so that tips the hand. And it devolves into a black comedy, with self-mutilation, suicide, farm animals inside the house, arson, police brutality, and people with no apparent means of support, like jobs. At first, we think it is a better place, this island off the Irish west coast, a hundred years ago during the Irish civil war, enough so that they can see the mainland and hear explosions and even see smoke, so the war is raging. But the irony is that these off the beaten path people find ways to get into mischief and trouble maybe more than the more warlike, just a short haul across the lake. The key seems to be a raft of adults who feel the ennui, boredom of this insular place, to the extent that show-stealer, feisty but wounded Siobhan, Kerry Condon, finds a way out, more in a search for love than a new mainland job she is going to even with war raging nearby. The centerpiece is her brother, Farrell, Padraic, which the Irish pronounce like there is no "d," and Gleeson, Colm, who are longtime friends who stop drinking together starting at 2 p.m. daily, because Colm, a fiddling songwriter wants to stop dealing with him because he doesn't like him anymore because he's boring, as he wants to focus on writing songs that live on. When Padraic starts bugging him about changing his mind, Colm says he will cut off his own fingers if Padraic won't leave him alone, an old Irish trick, if you don't do what I want or don't stop doing what I don't want, I will harm myself. Soon, the fingers start flying. When Padraic's prized miniature goat tries to eat one and chokes to death, they don't call them the fighting Irish for nothing. Padraic says he will burn down Colm's cottage tomorrow at 2, and if he is in it, well that's OK. And thus burns the home, but Colm lives. It is Barry Keoghan, a great young actor playing Dominic, the slow son of a drunken cop who beats him, and who had fallen for Siobhan, who is older than him, who tells her "there goes my dream" after she gently rejects him, whose remains are fished out of the lake.  Another key is that the priest asks Colm in confession how his despair is going, and Colm says he's pretty well lately, praise be. Siobhan had said all along that Colm is "depressed" and that all the men on the island are "boring," which is more why she left than for a library job, a library symbolizing culture, learning, art, not superstition and tribalism. Banshees are spirits of Irish folklore who predict when someone is going to die, often in loud wails. An old lady on the island plays this role, accurately predicting a death. The point is that some Irish people had trouble adapting to change, losing friends, dealing with rejection, or just finding love and contentment, in this remote, rural place. Seems Colm really was in despair, depressed, though don't expect any Irish people of Inisherin to admit it. May the wind be at their back. Great acting, good production values, many funny lines, a dark look at life of some Irish or just people, and that black comedy is just a bit over the top, and it drags a tad. Kerry's Siobhan is impatient with not just foolishness but dark ages mores mostly of the men, and is very good. An Irish-American, my father, bless his soul, used to quip, "You don't have to be dumb to be Irish, but it helps."

Probably not good enough to be one of the frontrunners for the 2023 Oscars, but it's still a great film that induced laughter and sadness from me. Excellent performances from Collin Farrell and Kerry Condon made the film a more enthralling experience. The best thing Banshees of Inisherin does is turn a seemingly empty premise into an unexpectedly gut-wrenching story.
Collin Farrell did a fine job with his role, he was worth seeing the movie.

This slow-burning, well-written drama is worth the watch for the acting and sense of place and time it creates.  But if you're expecting the level of dark humor in line with McDonagh's other films, you won't find much of that here in this aching allegory about the pyrrhic cost of leaving a righteous legacy.
A disappointment compared to In Bruce's. Fine acting but a lacklustre plot.
Performances and dialogue are brilliant. The scenery is beautiful but story is downright stupid
It's good as a metaphor, but what literally happens is too preposterous to take seriously.
The death of a friendship in a meandering and emotional, richly detailed allegory.

Great film, thought provoking, sad yet funny in turn. Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell brilliant as usual and impressive performances from Barry Keoghan and Kerry Condon.
Then there is the setting and scenery, beautiful, desolate and moody, all beautifully shot. This film lives up to all the accolades. It is simply superb.
Amazing actor duo, must see. Beautiful Ireland.
Dark, unenlightening, uninteresting after a few digits (let the reader understand!), and unsatisfying end.

This is a beautiful movie set in the Irish countryside in the 1920's. The premise is almost entirely one note - one member of a longterm friendship seeks to end things with the other. Things progressively get more grim from there on until each of their lives is essentially ruined. It's a strange and ominous film with great acting from Ferrell and Gleeson whose chemistry is as good as ever. It was a little trying on my admittedly short attention span, but that doesn't diminish its overall quality.

I laughed aloud multiple times throughout. Definitely worth the watch. Interesting film, beautiful cinematography, excellent acting, but ultimately, I didn't believe the characters. I won't get into the specifics but some things that they do just don't make sense.

Personally, I blame Jordan Peele.

Ever since Get Out, every would-be-auteur filmmaker thinks they have to include multiple scenes of gutwrenching horror in their comedies.

You'd think an Irish comedy set on an island with a front row seat to the civil war of the 1920s on the Emerald Isle would have some Saving Private Ryan close-up of the horrors of war, if it was going to pull this Peele trick, but no, it has to be multiple self-amputations and a pet miniature donkey choking to death on one of the amputated body parts.
