I suppose there was some saving grace in the wry theological conversations through the screen of the confessional about just what was, and what was not, a sin in the eyes of the Roman Catholic Church.

The Menu was a mortal sin against the gods of comedy. The horror in this one is just a sin in the original Greek meaning of the word: it missed the mark.

Barry Keoghan's talent really is next level!

Colin Farrell's ability to convey more emotion than most actors have in their entire career really is unparalleled.

And special shout out to Jenny the Donkey - a true star making performance!
Dark, hilarious at times, and beautifully performed, a standout movie of 2022.

Firstly, the movie has outstanding acting, direction, scriptwriting and scenery. The cast as a whole is extraordinary. Dominic, for example, is an incredibly moving and memorable portrayal of a nobody, with finesse and sensitivity. Even the animals become characters, without taking over. More than that, in a time when islands like Rathlin still preserve their own distinctiveness in relation to The Island, McDonagh nails the island life where 'word gets around' and news is ranked from 'news' to 'shite news' to 'no news at all'. 
The only issue is that in a film set up for redemption, none ever quite achieve it. It does have an extraordinary beauty in seeking and finding the parity that can rescue a relationship's balance. However, as it does so we realize there is nothing redemptive in both descending to the same base level. Perhaps that is the one of the film's messages -- that by burning down your friend's house in revenge, one can rebuild nothing; in cutting off one's nose to spite one's face, there is no new path to lasting peace to be discovered. 
The film's core tenet, meanwhile, that people are worth loving for their own genial banality, and that the appreciation of beauty is an indication that the same beauty resides within us, is one that pierces to the heart of all arts and debates and makes this movie soar. Two scenes in particular stand out (** spoilers***). One presents this point via the most simple yet scathing critique of the human construction of Catholicism, when a confessional priest asks Colm whether he thinks God gives a flying feck about little dead donkeys, and Colm answers that he fears He does not and that that is where it all went wrong. The other, after a long build up of the fear that Colm's music will be lost with his fingers, comes near the end, when Padraig encounters him in the pub jiving along as usual to the music circle, proving that limitations are often a product of the imagination and that all along, the music was actually within his soul.
Here's to village elegies and to filmmakers who make a donkey's sudden decease cut far deeper than a human's inevitable culmination of suffering -- may we next have a comedy, please?!

This is a beautifully constructed movie, but Colm's extreme response to Pádraic confronting him (the 'desperate ultimatum') is totally unbelievable and because of that, it's a dealbreaker that ruins the experience of the movie. More effort should have been put into writing a more believable script.
Could not watch ,turned off after 15 minutes

Same as what the other less favorable reviews here said. Great acting and beautiful scenery, but so pointless. Not sure what the meaning was. Also, you won’t talk to me so I’m going to cut my fingers off? What?
Fantastically written and acted.

A strange and depressing movie.  Trust your gut… if you watch the trailer and think “seems strange” go with that feeling and save your money.  This is one of those movies the critics rave about, but us “less insightful” people leave the theater thinking “I have no idea what that movie was about”.

Typical movie that the critics like way better than the audience.  Great characters and a great story world, but expect neither the delightful mysticism of 'Into The West'  nor the charm of 'Waking Ned Devine'.  A dark Bergenesque dwelve into the very depths of the Irish soul.  For the serious Irish aficionado only.
Funny and charming, but not a good movie season for donkeys.

A very simple, yet very complex movie that makes you think what it's all about, and what it's REALLY all about. On the forefront, it's about a two lads. They used to be friends, but one of them decides not to be friends anymore because, well, they're boring. The other friend though, isn't gonna give up. Despite them growing ever further apart, one is still desperate to hold on, even though the other is starting to sacrifice himself to trigger a discontinuation of this whole thing. Now it may be obvious to some people at the very start the symbolism this film is pulling off, but me being me, it didn't kick in til the very end. WOW! It may SEEM like a lot, but it isn't, the film is RICH in RICH dialogue, Sort of like a Gaelic Fargo (but not really) where the language is a character in itself. Can we give all the acting awards to everyone in this?

quirky, peculiar, provocative with an underlying sense of sadness and darkness; the acting is superb, stand outs Farrell, Gleeson, Condon & the sublime Barry Keoghan (reminded me of John Mills performance in Ryan's Daughter), and the wild beauty and remoteness of Achill & the Aran Islands (Ireland) a fitting background.
Quite depressing, however some great lines in it

wow it's good!

dark and slow and almost perfect.

I'm glad I read these reviews as I thought I was the only one who thought this movie was shite. Beautiful scenery and great acting but pointless, depressing and a stupid plot that reminded me of two little boys having a playground fight with the smarter one telling the other he didn't want to be friends any more and the other not taking no for an answer and keeping on with trying to get the other to be friends again. Threatening to cut off your fingers when the most enjoyable part of your life is playing the fiddle and then following through on the threat is beyond crazy. By the end, I was ready to cut off my own fingers so I could never press play on the remote again in case I end up watching another movie this stupid.

I don't think I have ever seen a movie where at the end I can't explain why I liked it.  But I did enjoy it. A very odd little movie, certain worth a view if you are snowed in on a winter day. There is something profound and lasting about this movie. Is it in the the way it transports us back to a rare place and time? How wonderful it was to see the rich recreation of a place only a unique clique could ever know had existed. 

I have seen this movie described as tragicomic. I did not hear a hint of laughter in the cinema or find a moment funny myself. Neither in the story's trajectory could I find meaning, just a vague desperate grab at some deeper mythology and a stab in the dark to find a point. I did not leave confused just sad so much effort and real honest emotion went into something that never found a way to matter

This is a unique and engaging movie that is instigated by the simplest and, in some ways, highly unusual plot. That plot is the spontaneous decision to end their friendship in the 1920's on a remote island in Ireland.  Brendan Gleason is the composer who decides to end his friendship with Colin Farrell.  Farrell does not understand, or accept, Gleeson's decision and this creates the volatile, tragic, and sometimes laughable chronology of events that unfold in this movie. The movie is beautiful and thoughtfully shot.  The small cast is all terrific. Barry Keoghan, of The Killing of The Sacred Deer, steals every scene he is in   This is a usual movie that keep you thinking and guessing throughout.

Very entertaining, the plot evolves around the small island attitude. Where life is boring during the Irish civil war. One friend stops talking to another so he can concentrate on his music composition. Very entertaining and thought provoking.

So many laugh out loud moments with a depth to the story. Really enjoyed this film. The performances from all the cast was superb. The scenery stunning. Strongly recommend. Should do well at the Oscars.

I cannot explain why I loved this movie so much. I'm notoriously hard to please. I'd have to give most of the credit to Colin Farrell's sublime and affecting performance. Beyond that, it was the commentary on people's inner lives and what they are enduring, which no one else can see. And the lovely cinematography. And Irish accents--that were actually comprehensible without subtitles!

Offbeat and timeless, this beautiful tale is a future masterpiece. The scenery, the cinematography and the excellent support gel seamlessly. The eccentricity of the Irish is pitched perfectly, without resorting to parody, as is the perfect minimalist direction. Heartbreaking, humourous and tragic in equal measures. The two protagonists are perfect, as is the whole production. 10/10.

I've enjoyed McDonagh films well enough in the past but this is the first of his to connect with me on the same level as those on the highest end of the reception curve. My biggest issue with his work prior has been the tendency to generally view humanity as largely apathetic and cynical, our problems and despairs hopeless for true resolve. He weaves stories of that brand much better than most I'd usually call out for that sort of thing, however, I think Banshees of Inisherin is his best film on account that it uses that apathy and cynicism for a much more admirable cause of examining the ways in which those things manifesting in people can set off chain reactions of destructive and self destructive behavior. It's a film that greatly speaks to our inherent need for connection, friendship, and community and the things we're capable of doing to ourselves and others without it. Very witty, Irish as they get, subtle and tender in its depiction of depression and isolation, but even at its most tragic still manages to squeeze in a few good laughs. One of the best films of the year.

As a big fan of 'In Bruges' and 'Three Billboards', I was really looking forward to this film. Particularly seeing Farrell and Gleeson together again, so many years after their the quite excellent 'In Bruges'.  Their acting, did not disappoint. Moments of lighter relief were few and far between in this dark tale of a mans battle with despair/depression and his fixation on his remaining years being only spent with people that might enrich his life, having decided that his best friend would not ! Quite how self mutilation and remaining on the island would achieve this was a mystery to me. That said, any film that leaves me pondering its meaning long after the credits have finished is not all bad !

Jeez, I'm probably gonna get nuked for this review. I was really excited to see the movie. Sorry, didn't get it at all. Found it a bit thick and dull. Perhaps I'm a psychopath. Can I have my $20 back?

Brendan plays a want to be Van Gogh trying to make a lasting legacy for people to remember him bye and Colin is the village idiot who loves his donkey. I love in Bruges absolutely nails dark comedy, this doesn't hold a candle and yet the scores push it into obscurity that should clearly push in Bruges as Martin Mcdonaghs best movie not this

It's all about expectations. So many wanted a feel-good comedy and ended up disappointed. It's a dark (very dark) comedy at best, lots of internal struggles. Expect to be sad at times, maybe disturbed at some scenes.

I'm puzzled by all of the great reviews, as if the movie was some kind of miracle. Expecting something great, I watched the excruciating progress of a majestic ship steadily sinking on the horizon. As one of the other reviewers wrote, maybe a film that includes the beauty of Ireland, with prominent actors, just gets an automatic pass.

At the start, the picturesque beauty of the pastoral setting, and quaint characters promised some intricate character development. Maybe even some poetic revelations on the relationships, the joys and the struggles of the Irish in the 1920s. That expectation was slowly and steadily dismissed as the story progressed.

The actors all performed their roles effectively, where the sister, Kerry Condon, was by far the most nuanced of the other, fairly monotonous characters. Barry Keoghan also added some personality to the story. The setting delivered with its sedate beauty throughout the film. But the culprit was the writing, or lack thereof. It may have just been that they wanted a vehicle for the ambience of the Irish country side. But that would have been better served by excluding what grew into progressively inane dialog and then some sadly deranged plot turns. I'm not sure what spark of inspiration prompted the film. It had an auspicious start, but it seems that about 1/3 of the way into it, the writer lost his way and just said feck it.
'The Banshees of Inisherin' is a wickedly funny and nerve-rattling comedy that perfectly blends humor and tragedy.

The cinematography and setting in this movie are truly beautiful and Barry Keogh definitely deserves all of the major awards this season, for his absolutely brilliant performance. I refuse to believe that the stereotype is accurate, even when applied to people from the past.

This was a horrific film that we all wished we had not seen. A musician who cuts off all his fingers, for no good reason, denying himself his one pleasure. Not sure why this is so highly rated, very few scenes of comedy and they're all canceled out with the horror of Gleeson shearing off his fingers. The scenery was very beautiful and very good casting and acting, too bad about the script.
This movie was VERY well acted and one of the best movies I've seen this year. For a simple story line that could have easily gone wrong, this movie REALLY did an amazing job.

A slow build, with stunning scenery. Fantastic movie

On one fine beautiful day in 1923, on an Irish island, Pádraic Súilleabháin (Colin Farrell) visits his friend Colm Doherty (Brendan Gleeson) to call him to the pub just like any regular day. There he comes to know that Colm doesn't want to be friends with him anymore. Clueless Pádraic didn't understand the reason behind such a massive step and tries to dissolve the situation by apologizing and talking to his dear friend. Contrary to his efforts, the more he tries to talk to Colm, the more the situation worsens, and that further leads to devastating events in both of their lives.

The Banshees of Inisherin is an extremely beautiful film, both from a story as well as a scenic perspective. The screenplay is so smooth that one doesn't even realize the passing minutes of the runtime. The cinematography is brilliant. The wide-angle shots of captivating landscapes with cloudy sky and seashore give a soothing experience.

McDonagh's direction is top class and he has masterfully created a mesmerizing world around us in this film.
On one end, the story's simplicity gives a touch of authenticity to the film; on the other hand, the diligent character development & careful writing, make the characters more real than fictional.
Every moment and conversation has been used efficiently to develop the story and take it further. Everything happening on the screen makes sense. Since McDonagh himself has written the film, he embraces the characters with the utmost care, and it's evident, too, throughout the film when as a viewer we can relate to the characters and the situations. Even smaller role characters are written with interesting character arcs.

When such a talented cast is onboard, you can expect top-notch performances. Colin Farrell once again gives an Oscar-worthy performance with an extremely powerful portrait of his character. You can literally feel his anguish and emotions. Brendan Gleeson is equally outstanding with his marvellous dialogue delivery and character portrayal. Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan are the scene stealers and make their characters memorable even with limited screen time.

This comedy-drama, under the carpet, is actually more of a tragic tale. There are metaphors, but one doesn't need to dwell too deeply to understand them. They have been laid out in simpler ways here. There are plenty of scenes that would make you laugh, but at the same time, there are many that would make you sad. The film explores various underlying themes like loneliness, sadness, love, and friendship under the umbrella theme of human relationships.

At the end of the day, I see The Banshees of Inisherin as a film that everyone would appreciate in one way or the other. It's smartly written, brilliantly directed, and passionately portrayed. It's a fascinating piece of cinema and every frame in it is simply admirable.

Follow me on Instagram/Letterboxd: m_movie_reviews
Rating: 8.3/10
A genuinely funny and genuinely original film for adults.  How refreshing.
Some funny moments, great actors and performances. Storyline got quite silly by the end.
This movie has just the storytelling that is missing in almost all of Hollywoods' creations these days

I thoroughly enjoyed this film. The performances are honest and thoughtful and bring complexity to an otherwise simple story. At its core this is a breakup story between two lifelong friends, much to the relief of one and the chagrin of the other, with very serious consequences for both. If you have an appreciation for dark (very dark) comedy and a well developed sense irony this film is for you.
A beautiful and heart breaking film that still manages to make you laugh.
A dark, metaphorical tale that weaves its way between gentle comedy and brutish violence.  A distinctly "Irish" feeling film with great performances.  Kerry Condon is always refreshing to watch.
It seems like with each of his films, McDonagh is actively trying to make the world a little better. And he does, reader, he does.
A lot to unpack. Particularly Irish in many ways. Definitely global in its ideas. Needs a rewatch.

I loved this movie. Such a great metaphor for wars, all of them, not just this one they deliberately referenced.  I cried over Jenny. Very good acting all around.

I have never felt so sorry for Colin Farrell, and I have felt sorry for him most of his life. His facial expressions were at times quite heartbreaking. I think he probably should do that for every acting role he has and he will continue to win awards. He has such a tragic face. Brendan Gleeson was also very tragic, as was mostly everyone on this god-forbidden island. But all that tragedy added up to a very entertaining and thought-provoking movie about the human condition, and why can't we all just get along, that was even very funny at times.
damn that's depressing as hell
Malísimaaaaaaa… lenta y tonta.

Banshees of Inisherin is one of the most beautiful films of 2022. It features incredible acting performances from the entire cast, but most notably, Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan. The story is fairly simple but complexes at the same time. I loved the scenery and the time period this took place. It also was paced well throughout the entire movie. Overall, this is a very good movie that holds a lot of deep meanings.
Utterly bleak and pointless.
A must watch movie that showcase the beauty of Ireland landscape

It treads a line between being funny and serious, but veers too much into amusing territory. So much so that when it does get serious, it doesn't really follow the plots trajectory. A film that critics love but fans will be split on
The scenery in the film is gorgeous. The plot is a disaster. Had I any inkling of what the film was about, I would have skipped it entirely.
The worst. Who cares. Why bother

It feels like it was written by Camus, an absurd tale about life and its futility. A fresh new take on absurd combined with excellent acting, outstanding photography and great soundtrack makes this a rare jewel.
Objectively it is well done but it is profoundly, unremmitingly depressing to no apparent purpose.
Funny, sad, what the hell did I just watch kind of film!

This was a beautifully filmed and well acted movie.  But it is a depressing parable with a simple and violent point, that is too maudlin for me.  The point (that pigheaded stubborness can lead to self-destruction and self-sabotage) was made in an overly exaggerated fashion that resulted in a flawed movie.
Gory but a good watch
A terrible depressing movie!  What was the movie's plot or purpose?  Colin Farrell's talent was wasted in this movie. Would not recommend this movie.
A great dark comedy with deep themes that will keep you contemplating for days.
Cast a cold eye on island life and death,gobshiites pass by.

I literally had a car accident yesterday where I almost died, like very close to death. This movie made my experience yesterday seem fun in comparison. I know I don't get it its just too deep.. It's easy to be deep when its' just misery you're dealing out to your audience. The actings good and the landscapes gorgeous but this movie made me miss when was flipped over in my Honda CRV thinking I was going to die.
Just because a story exists doesn't mean you necessarily need to tell it. Fine acting and a solid soundtrack leaves you with what you began with. Nothing.

As in his previous movies(In Bruges and Three billboards outside Ebbing Missouri) Banshees has an intricate plot that the actors each take turns at looking at life and it's pitfalls in their own ways. There is a deeper theme here so if you want explosions and laugh out loud entertainment this is not your type of picture. Gorgeous landscapes and top notch acting is what this amazing film is all about
The beauty of Ireland steals the show in this feckin hilarious dark comedy.

Not a fan. I love the actors and clearly the shots of Ireland were amazing but the premise and storyline was not what I was expecting, the trailers made it seem like this would be a comedy about the ending of a friendship but it was a clearly dark and sad plot instead and just wasn't into it.

I enjoyed this movie on several levels. It seems to be a metaphor for the civil war there. At the same time there were questions about what makes life meaningful and other themes. It was funny and horrific at the same time. I am going to watch it again…and probably again.

Excellent film. Novel storyline: a man’s best friend suddenly, one day, no longer wants to be friends. And he’s not at all diplomatic about his change of heart. This crushes the heart and soul of the tossed off friend (Colin Ferrell). They’ve both lived on the tiny island of Inisherin their entire lives. The castoff loves animals and lives in a house by the sea with his sister. He lets his miniature donkey, Jenny, into the house at all times, rankling his wiser, more self-aware sister. The man who no longer wants Ferrelle’s company (Brendan Gleason), lives alone in a house by the sea, in a place filled with opera music on an old gramophone, and carved masked and other art items. The story progresses as the island’s other denizens watch the strange twists and turns as each day passes. There is blood, gruesomeness, and dark comedy. There is a malignant cop who molests his teenaged son, a priest with a foul mouth and an arrogant attitude, and a shopkeeper who lives to gossip. It’s great entertainment and a thoughtful story, a challenging “what if?”

One of the best films of 2022. Martin McDonagh's phenomenal screenplay is matched equally by incredible performances from Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell and scene stealing Barry Keoghan. Like McDonagh's other films (In Bruges, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri), it's both funny and tragic, low key disturbing and provactive. He takes a simple yet rich setting and turns it into a grand social experiment. The entire production is award worthing from costume design to cinematography. McDonagh's direction is purposeful yet subtle. The dialogue is so brilliant and watching the actors tackle it is like watching a boxing match of powerful, endless punches with neither side yielding. It's a thinker and the film's charms probably allude some but if you're game, it's quiet a surprise gem amidst a lot of noise out there.

A dark and sometimes funny tale that is brilliantly acted throughout, especially Kerry Condon. About friendship, loneliness, music and wonderful pets. In parts, told like the an old Irish fairy story. Beautiful & stunning scenery. A movie that makes you think about the fate of the characters long after it's finished.

Overrated here!!! stupidest film ever!!! Critics love McDonagh's work. It depends on who they like as a director and bash who they don't like. Shameful!!! I recently saw Sam Mendes's Empire of Light which is such a beautiful film, and this one got hammered with bad reviews from the critics. They don't like Sam Mendes.

It is a slow movie but it's also quite charming thanks to the gorgeous locations, the cinematography, and the engaging story and performances.  Every moves along fine until, unfortunately, the ending happens in the middle of the story causing a huge unresolved hole that doesn't suit the rest of the narrative.  Even the last words uttered in the film have no wisdom, no depth.  It's just suddenly, THE END.  A quality film that ends in nothing important.
Terrible movie. Good acting. Beautiful scenery. Bad premise. Bad story.  We stuck with it in hopes of redemption, but it just got worse and worse.

A great tragic-comedy. This movie made me feel pretty bad (depressed) and I think that is a good thing. I think the point of the movie is exactly this, it should not make you feel good. I interpreted it as a metaphor for the Irish civil war and I think it did a good job at that. Great performances from all involved.
Dull from start to finish..great actors in a not so great film...

The acclaim this film is receiving is a bit over the top.  But the performances despite the unlikable characters are well executed. The talent and pedigree of Farrell, Gleason and Condon are evident every step of the way.  The rest of the characters are also well played.  This movie moves as slow as Ireland in the 80's and 90's and the views are as majestic as ever.  The laughs stem mostly from tragedy and cruelty but the Irish are best at making fun of the Irish so it really lands accurately.  If you want a feel good "Quiet Man" experience this wont do it but its certainly worth a look into island life in mid 1920's.  Not much different than living in Wisconsin, Nevis, or New Orleans on a Monday.  Sit back, relax and enjoy the ride because this isn't to be taken too seriously.  As for Condon, she is a gem and a sweetheart and she kinda saves the film from its slow burn gloom.  The witch is also an interesting character and her ability to see the future is indicative of her intelligence and observational skill.  The story is really her point of view and it helps add that touch of magic and lore that is omni present on the Emerald Isle to this day.

I am mystified by the positive critical response to this movie. Agonizingly repetitive, with no one to root for except maybe the donkey. I watched it with industry savvy people and some "civilians' and we turned it off, actually got up en masse and left the viewing room after the digital mutilation. A soporific for those having sleep issues.
Could've used Pozzo and Lucky to liven things up.
Beautifully written & well acted.  My attention on the screen never wavered.  Excellent movie!
What a heart moving movie, original, and casting was perfection.

Loving both the director and the lead actors, I was anxiously anticipating the release of this film. And I was hugely disappointed. It wasn't terrible, it just wasn't very engaging or believable. None of the narrative genius and character development that defined In Bruges is apparent here. The two central characters live in a small island off the coast of Ireland, trapped in small mindedness which the film illustrates appropriately. It was pretty boring, and there is no payoff at the end for the time you spend waiting. But props to Barry Keoghan for a sensational supporting performance.
A strange, depressing movie, but so well acted.  Colin Farrell deserves every acting award possible for his performance.  And the Donkey and him always made me smile.

I quite liked it, though McDonagh has yet to equal "In Bruges."  Weird premise, but that's pretty much McDonagh's brand.  It comes off as some sort of re-telling of an Irish myth -- because of the title, for one thing -- and maybe it actually is, but even if it isn't it has that vibe.  However, "The Secret of Roan Inish" it definitely ain't.  It's not for everyone, and there are some really gruesome moments, and if you're looking for an upbeat happy ending look somewhere else, but I enjoyed it thoroughly.

By the way, I play fiddle myself, and up until this movie I don't believe I'd ever seen a violin played on-screen where the player was actually playing what was on the soundtrack.  Brendan Gleeson, however, absolutely was.  It wasn't necessarily him playing; it could have been another fiddler bow-syncing to what he played, or him bow-syncing to a previously made recording, or something like that, but there's no doubt at all that he plays fiddle well enough to play those tunes, some of which were pretty up-tempo.  Small thing but it made me happy.

A well acted stupid movie. If you find your friend too boring to spend time with anymore, maybe threaten to punch him in the face instead of cutting off your own fingers if he doesn't leave you alone. He didn't even hate his friend. 4/5 acting, 2/5 story. I was unwilling to give it a meh, making people thing it was worth watching.
I like an arthouse film as much as any, but this is the emperor's new clothes.

I certainly understand the gap between the critic and the audience score.  This is a tragedy plain and simple.  It is brilliantly acted and I would say well written.  The characters are all interesting and the casting was spot on.  Obviously this is not every everyone and not recommended for early morning viewing as it is kind of a shite way to start the day, but it is a fine piece of cinema nonetheless.  Love how Farrell and Gleeson work together.

A genius script that comes to live with brilliant the performance from Collin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson and more so with the added input of Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan who in my view plays the best. 
A simple concept carried out brilliantly allowing the audience to really experience what Ireland was like and still is in its remote places.
Martin McDonagh positions himself again as for me the best script writer to portray Ireland.
Stunning. Full spectrum engagement.

Beautiful film.  A+ cinematography.  Just the right amount of charm, odd performances, sadness, and bizarre character choices that make an indie film stand out.  I wish the "war" stuff would've landed a bit more.  I kept hoping it'd be woven in a little better.  Maybe it was and I missed it.  Just a thought.  Great film.
Typical Irish play…..depressing.  Wake Ned devine for better show.

The movie started out great. It was funny, smart, and filled with great characters. Though, the movie ended with too many unanswered questions that made everything that came before it quite pointless.
A great dark comedy.  It went from funny subtle comedy, to very dark comedy.  Scenery is amazing, and great acting.  Captures some of the stubborn Irish temperament that's well known for a reason.
This movie is slow, and in the end pointless. The plot inspires disbelief. Awful.
I thought Colin would

This was an excellent movie, beautifully filmed, very evocative of its time and place (the Aran Islands, off the west coast). As a modern American, it's easy to sentimentalize Irish country life, but Banshees shows that in any small town, there'll be hidden (sometimes horrific) sins, scandals, pettiness, boredom and frustration. Gleason is a perfect picture of depressive malaise. Farrell's character evolves from shallow, happy fool to sadder and not-so-much-the-wiser man, caught off guard by the darker sides of life in close quarters. 

Also: BEST. DONKEY. EVER.
Intriguing at first but doesn't quite go the way you think or hope it will. Really enjoyed Colin Farrell's performance. Definitely worth watching but won't be for everyone.

Was definitely getting a Three billboards... vibe at times, and I was absolutely loving it!

The biggest surprise for me was Barry Keoghan! I mean we all know he's good but he's really great in this one!
The first hour is pretty quiet but then the second hour kicks in, and that's where it picks up force, and McDonagh goes full swing!

The writing and acting was absolutely top-notch, and Colin Farrell gives one of his career best performances.

The acting was great by all involved.  The first part of the movie was like the trailer, and I was having a great time with it.  Then something happened and the darkness came on, I mean it REALLY came on.  I didn't know that there was going to be anything like that in this story.  So after the tone changed I hated the rest of the movie.  I was just mad when it was over.  Depressing as all get out.

I'm not at all surprised that critics reviewed this movie appreciably higher than "civilian" viewers. It's a critic type movie.
 
I thought the acting was fine, the scenery was great, but the movie itself was simply boring.
Excellent dark comedy on friendship gone wrong.

Phenomenal, but heartbreaking. I didn't expect to be as sad as I was by the end. As such, I almost don't recommend it as you'll probably just feel awful after. Though the writing and performances are fantastic; Colin Farrell continues to show that he's one of the finest actors of his generation.

This was in my opinion the best movie of 2022. Absolutely fantastic, especially given how well the movie is a representation of Irish history. Don't get too caught in the dreariness of it all, and try to see what the artist is trying to convey in this masterpiece
I'm baffled by the positive reviews, I regret my time spent with these sad, boring characters and their barren outpost.

Wow! Ok, I am a fairly hard core movie buff. Character driven movies are a rarity and sometimes hard to pull off in these days of CGI/VFX and action movies. I was almost put off by the high critic rating because many times I disagree (see Everything, Everywhere, All at Once... ). This has it all in spades. I really like Brendan Gleeson (ever since he played Mad Eye Moody in the Goblet of Fire, for which he should have at least been nominated for an Academy Award! Really, go take a look at that character - he's playing a VERY quirky character who was ACTUALLY someone else!). The chemistry between him and Colin Farrell is sublime and the whole story, village, characters is extremely well protrayed and presented! The ending was mildly, very mildly disappointing. But that is just the typical shallow me wanting it all tied up in a bow. There are just so many things going on that are subtle yet not that it really makes for a very compelling, well done, nearly great, film!! Highly recommend it....
Super boring but the actors did a phenomenal job..
Sublime, emotionally challenging, brilliant acting and direction.

I feckin loved it.  I saw it twice in one week.  I laughed so heartfully and cried when,,,,,  Well, I'll let you figure that out.  It was 100% perfect in every way.  EVERY single performer was PERFECT.  One byproduct is, I used to be a little ashamed of the US's democratic party mascot, the donkey.  Now I see it as a true, tried and true badge of honor.  Thank you for making this beautiful film.

Instant classic.
They did it again.
Refreshing. I love those two. Their chemistry is awesome

I'd watch these two in a soap commercial. This movie is achingly funny in parts, poignant in others and utterly brilliant in the performances. Yes its slow. Yes its incomprehensible to American ears. But to watch these two play off each other is pure joy and the supporting cast is perfection. Let this movie transport you back to 1923 Ireland.
Simple movie with great writing, dialogue, acting, and cinematography. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.
Photography is very beautiful. However, it was not a chronicle that pleased me, because it was absurdist.
A great examination of life in a place with limited inhabitants and how they can all go slowly mad.
Normally I am quite forgiving of slow, folksy foreign movies. Unfortunately this one adds very little new illumination on rural Irish life. I felt like this story has already been told.
Quirky, sad, mad, poignant, beautiful.
It's a somber, beautiful movie, All around Oscars, for worthy performances from its stellar cast. Definitely one of this year bests film.
Excellent acting and plot!!!
Interesting and quirky Irish film with some great performances.

Some will watch this movie and simply say what's the point. There's an obvious metaphor between the two main characters, but also a statement being made along the way related to how much we rely on friendships for our own sanity. 

All of the humor really lands, but I can't help but think a little more of it would have made the movie more digestible.
Devastating and gorgeous

Wow. What an amazing film. Beautiful cinematography, but a fantastic story about what happens when friendships change, when we change, or when we don't; about rash decisions and their fallout, stubbornness and forgiveness or not forgiving. Life on an island community not caught up in terrible mainland events, sees residents caught up in the goings-on of others, as would be expected, but also leads them into routine and complacency that only now and then a few realize and try to awake from or break free of. Gleeson and Farrell, of course, are amazing, but Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan deliver amazing performances too. I'm still thinking about this film days after having seen it.
I sobbed in the movie theatre. Very well made.
Finally!!! Best movie I've seen in a long time. Please, more of this.
Slow and depressing.  Sorry I saw it.  The preview clips were the best parts of the film. I suppose if your feeling too happy this movie could balance out your life.  If you stay awake.
Probably the best film I've seen when cutting off your fingers to get someone you don't like to talk you as means to get them to stop talking to you
A great Actor's movie.  A little odd, but if that is your jam, you will enjoy this.

I loved In Bruges. I loved The Wonder, one of the strangest, darkest Irish films I've ever seen. I love most of Colin Farell and Brendan Gleeson's films. But stg I don't understand how Banshees is getting raves and how the eff is it described as any kind of COMEDY???? Sad, very very slow, very dense, and then the chopping begins and then, poor Jenny. I have no clue what any of that symbolism means and I'm sorry I put  this film into my brain.
I hated this movie and wanted my time back. Scenery is breathtaking but the story was confusing and disjointed.  I DO not understand why it is nominated for so many awards.
Never got to see buddy try and mash his potatoes with the stump and that got me right peeved. The rest was *Chefs Kiss*

Slow and depressing.  Why would anyone chop off their own body parts to get back at someone that simply speaks to them? Terrible movie and unrealistic unless it's supposed to show mental illness.  Don't bother.
Weirdly wonderful. Never seen anything liked it.
An ultimately sad (what else could it be) allegory on the Irish Civil War of 1922. Well written and brilliantly acted. At times it is very funny, and at times heartbreaking. Well worth the effort.
Wonderful acting, beautiful scenery.  The movie gets a little slow in the middle but the ending more than makes up for that.
While the acting and location is incredible, the story is so sad there is no redemption.

Should not be advertised as a comedy. It is more horror and very small comedy. Greatly disappointed, as were others I know who saw it. Be forewarned, it is NOT a pleasant movie to watch. I am Ok seeing movies simply for performances but the story should be innocuous, and this is anything but innocuous. Whatever point was being made is done so in an extreme and gratuitous way. It was gruesome and depressing, and I am someone who thinks Chinatown is one of the greatest movies ever made. Stream The Guard instead.

Incredible performances all around. Not a movie for good vibes, but a movie for unique storytelling, beautiful cinematography, subtle performances, and one that keeps you thinking and wondering long after you leave the theatre.
Sad story that fails to connect

McDonagh his darkly comedic timing is on point here, with a terribly funny and sad story about regret, lost friendships, death and loneliness. Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Barry Keoghan and Kerry Condon give the most humaine performances of the year here !
The critics really over-hyped this one.

Haunting, superbly acted by a talented cast, set against beautiful scenery, a community of monstrous people live out their lives, relationships are non existent, friendships flitting amongst sad and lonely people, what sometimes felt like an episode of Father Ted quickly turns so much darker, set against the backdrop of the 1922 civil war, this is a fitting metaphor of Ireland troubles.

I am a huge movie fan and buff. I go to the movies with an open mind and like to be challenged and enjoy seeing someone trying something different. For the life I me, I DO NOT understand ANY of the accolades this movie is getting. I love the two leads (in other roles), but the ENTIRE audience was left shaking their heads and muttering to themselves. How is it this rates so high when for the life of me it was a horrible nonsensical movie. Holding that fiddle and jumping up and down with that bloody stump of a hand in the bar was the most ludicrous scene I've ever seen. Anyways...my two cents and the entire theatres.
Worst film ever! Bleak and unrewarding. Layers of boredom unredeemed by the scenery or the characters.Was there a point?  2 hours of my life I can't get back.

It is such a shame that the audience score for The Banshees of Inisherin is only 76%.  While I wasn't fully on top of watching absolutely everything this year like I will be starting January 1st, out of the movies that I have seen this year Banshees is my #3 as of right now.  The only two I have higher are The Batman and Everything Everywhere All At Once.  While I feel like Banshees deserves so many Oscars and The Batman doesn't, I still think The Batman is a slightly better film.  But this was a movie that really resonated with me personally and the performances from Colin Farrell and Brendon Gleeson are some of the best of the year.
One of my favorite movies this year.

Deeply depressing metaphor for the Irish Civil War mirrored in the sudden dissolution of a long friendship.  Inexplicable actions lead to alienation, disintegration, and overwhelming sadness.  Feels like Theater of the Absurd.    A beautifully shot dreary film with terrific acting and a gilded rope tying the anchor around your neck.  Not for the depressed or those at risk of emotional turmoil.
Very dark at times but great story.
A masterpiece. Plain and simple!
A story about getting banned on the internet.  "The Bannedshee's of Internetisherin."

Beautifully bleak, darkly comical, unquestionably poignant and moving. Farrell and Gleeson are absolutely excellent on screen, with Farrell delivering an Oscar contending performance. 
I love McDonagh for his ability to take a basic premise and create a feature length, brilliantly balanced story, which really manages to fire on all cylinders.
Absolutely amazing acting and story
This film is dull, not funny and very slow. I got bored. No idea how it's been nominated for so many awards...
Excellent acting, and spectacular scenery. An enjoyable, imaginative original story. Funny at times, heartbreaking at others.
Good modern Irish fable that is allegory for the troubles in the Irish history. Great performances from leads and Kerry Condon was marvelous!

I suspect I'll be swimming against the tide of opinion here, but I didn't like The Banshees of Inisherin. It's grim in subject matter and in being like a dark fairytale. At its core is the depression of one main character and his melancholia. His actions are extreme. The rating I've given it is for craft work as it's really well done.

This is a dark and nasty film! I went expecting some comedy, but there was none.
It was a relief to get out of the cinema!
I gave it 3.5 out if 10, for the acting, the scenery (made me never want to go there!) and the donkey. You have been warned!
Not funny. Grotesquely violent.

I always have loved this writer, director and these two actors, until now. For the love of God, you can all do much better and please do!
The character Colin Farrell played here was Happy Jack from Tropic Thunder. An absolutely ridiculous premise, script and dully as a doornail. A very bad idea for a film and tortuous to sit through. I truly want my money back.
This movie is great! Its a captivating story with subtle comedy that does make you laugh out loud. I did. Every actor was great and the movie is beautifully shot. I enjoyed very much.
A beautiful, ultimately tragic film with consequences that did not seem necessary.  Excellent acting and a beautiful setting make this well worth watching.
Dont be afraid to laugh out loud even though the movie has a laid back feel to the characters and their behavior, which slowly intensifies through the film.
A must-watch for Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson alone.
Brilliantly written and acted. The supporting cast are stupendous.

Fantastic film. Long after it was finished, people were talking about the issues raised in it in a nearby restaurant. People at the office were equally delighted with the movie. It might be a little too much for other audiences, but it did speak to the Irish in a deeper level.
Such an amazing movie. Very emotional yet funny
Weird but very entertaining!

A brilliant, brutal story. It can be hard to watch at times, but you'll see those times coming. No cheap tricks here. 

Colin Farrell deserves an Oscar for his performance.

Bleak, tragic, hilarious..... the film asks questions that it leaves with you to ponder. But worth seeing, in any case, if only for the magnificent setting, beautiful photography, excellent musical store and masterful performances from all the cast. My outstanding film from 2022.

Loved the actors, storyline, creativity of the script, and the setting in that order.  This director has created some of my favorite movies.  I love that Colin and Brendan were appearing together again after seeing them In Bruges.  I think Colin Farrell is so funny and his facial expressions (and those eyebrows) are genius.  I had some good laughs and amusement watching this movie.  Some people may not like it, but if you are ready for quirky youll love it.

Feeling a bit lonely and isolated around the holidays?
 Looking for an inexpensive way to push you over the edge into a depression for which there is no return? 

 This is your movie!! 

Not only does it resolve the age old mystery behind why the Irish are known for being alcoholic, you'll wish to get totally hammered just to make it through this cinematic gem of self imposed depression and hopelessness. 

The most redemptive aspects is the movies climax when main characters best friend dies chocking on another friend's finger that he had just cut off. 

The cinematography of this scene alone will haunt your nightmares and guarantee to leave deep scars of emotional trauma and years of counseling. 

The theater was completely empty except for Kanye West who was literally laughing out loud thinking it was a comedy. 

Oh, the seats were very comfortable.
Story and scenery  and Colin Farrell
Beautiful, funny and often dark.  Amazing actors.
Great acting, great storytelling and great surprises, but it's a depressing story that is slowly paced.
Toxic masculinity is real and no man is above it, even if he is as nice as Colin Farrell character. That's the real red pill
Absolutely the worst movie ever.
something different. really enjoyed it

Beautifully shot, amazingly acted, occasionally hilarious. In the end it was a movie with a very bleak outlook on life and humanity, left me feeling sad and a bit hopeless. Now that might be a weird thing to criticize since the tedium and pointlessness of the characters' lives was very much intentional but it left me drained.

Given a choice between sticking needles in my eyes and watching this movie again I’d go for the needles. The acting here is fine; these are skilled actors. The story and script are mind-bendingly boring and depressing.

Outstanding performances all round, beautifully filmed and edited, with a screenplay and OST that complete a magical experience. See it in a theater. There are Academy Awards all round or no justice in this world.

Life is lonely and good friends are hard to come by on a small island off the coast of Ireland. Hanging on to family and friends is a matter of life and death. When his best friend Colm (Brendan Gleeson) "divorces" him so that he will have space to create something lasting with his music,  Pádraic (Colin Farrell) desperately tries to get him back. It features bleak landscapes, funny Irish characters, and dialog that sounds like music. It seems like a good fit for the stage.
Heavy and dark movie but excellent acting, beautiful scenery and very moving.  Very glad to have seen this.

Poor story line, gratuitous pointless deaths of an innocent animal and of an endearing young character, wooden acting, threatened violence towards a dog, scenes of fingers being chopped off - all with absolutely no deeper meaning whatsoever. What a waste of a film resource. However, lovely scenery and sailing craft but I should have walked out.
Very slow moving and depressing

Loved the acting, the characters, the beautiful scenery, the Irish music and witty jargon.  But was not expecting just how depressing it would be.  And it certainly didnt end as I expected either.  But it was well done and still recommend.
Best movie Ive seen all year

HahahahahaaWAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!

That is me laughing and then bursting into ugly tears at the end.

Me. Bawling over Colin Farrell, because he is that good. I mean, obviousy, Brendan Gleeson is. Everyone is. The animals give beautiful performances. It's just so heartbreaking! Gleeson's character destroys the purity of Farrell's, and UGH.

John Donne wrote the line in a poem that no man is an island, well this is the embodiment of those words. Set on an island off of the coast of Ireland in the early 1920's, a time of struggle on the mainland , that appears to have little effect on the smaller isle's inhabitants. One man struggles with his own depression and feelings of time coming to a close and attempts to cut himself off from another. The other identifies him as his only friend and cannot come to accept  this new order in his own non existence of a life and the situation spirals into violence and loss. A well crafted film but bleak . A few laughs along the way , but also issues of child abuse, loneliness, depression and isolation to counter those odd lighter moments.

In 2008, Tony award-winning Irish playwright Martin McDonagh demonstrated how effectively his skills could translate to the big screen.  The film was "In Bruges" and it starred Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson.  In "The Banshees of Inisherin," the two actors are again paired together.  But "Banshees" should offer a disclaimer:  Not all items are as interesting as they initially appear.

In this film, McDonagh has traded the iconic Belfrey Tower of Bruges for an imaginary island off the coast of Ireland.  The date is April, 1923.  Early on, we learn that Colm (Gleeson) wants to sever all contact with his longtime friend Padraic (Farrell) because he finds him terminally dull.  (He has a point.)  Colm says he wants to spend his remaining time on earth building a legacy by writing music, not engaging in trivial conversation with his friend.  He's so serious about it that he tells Padraic he will cut off one of his own fingers with a set of shears the next time Padraic intrudes.  Because this is a McDonagh film, one townsperson observes, "Would you not want him to have to do the one finger, to see if he was bluffing like? ... He can still play the fiddle with four fingers, I bet you."  And because this is a McDonagh film, violence is always simmering just beneath the surface.  Friendship isn't the only thing that eventually gets brutally severed.

I attended this screening with high expectations, having deeply admired "In Bruges" as well as McDonagh's other films "Seven Psychopaths" and "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri."  I've seen each of them more than once.  "Banshees" tones down the violence of McDonagh's previous films, settling for tossing verbal rather than literal grenades.  But while it examines Colm and Padraic from every possible angle, these central characters are too profoundly depressed (Colm) or too lacking in self-awareness (Padraic) to be deeply interesting or to represent some larger point.  There's a lot of morose moping in search of a purpose.  Some critics have pronounced in authoritative tones that the relationship between Colm and Padraic is a metaphor for the Free Staters versus the IRA during the Irish Civil War.  If that's the case, McDonagh needs to sell the idea with more than occasional gunfire in the background.  Turns out, this historical context ("1920s Irish History for $200, please, Alex") is not a strong point for some moviegoers.

There are a few bright spots.  The lingering aerial shots of the Irish countryside are spectacular.  McDonagh's masterful writing skills are on full display.  The dialogue is densely clever, when it's not being cleverly dense.  And there is a small ray of hope: one character, Padraic's sister Siobhan (a scene-stealing Kerry Condon – "Better Call Saul," "Three Billboards," "Ray Donovan"), has the good sense to pack her bags and leave for the mainland and a chance at sanity.  She writes back to Padraic reflecting amazement that her new locale includes townspeople who smile on occasion.
 
But for the most part, the characters in "Banshees" seem intent on manifesting every possible sign of clinical depression (although, in fairness, some characters shift to a generalized sense of despair, just for a change of pace).  "The Banshees of Inisherin" is not a sojourn to an idyllic isle.  Ultimately, this is Brigadoon with minimal singing, no dancing and no Cyd Charice.

All of a sudden a friend "doesn't like" his best friend any more and not until 2/3's in do we learn why - spoiler alert - he now considers him boring. THE BANSHEES OF INISHERIN from writer/director Martin McDonagh (In Bruges), re-teams Brendan Gleeson (Colm) & Colin Farrell (Pádraic) in a dark comedy set on an island off Ireland at the end of the Irish Civil War in 1923. Colm's abrupt decision to end his friendship with Pádraic creates upheaval in the ordinary lives of the islanders. Colin Farrell steals the film, conveying BANSHEES themes of kindness, isolation, importance of human connection. Features cinematography by Ben Davis, shot along Ireland's west coast, equal parts bleak, ominous, breathtakingly beautiful.

Review: Banshees of Inisherin (BoI)

Maybe it's just me but this movie enthralled me. Something very rare. I'll try to make an argument that you might feel the same way. 
In a nutshell this BoI is the deepest of dives into the heart of friendship, with more than a little Heart of Darkness. It aims at and hits an unerring bullseye at small town life on an island just off the coast of Ireland. Never having visited the emerald isle myself the seascapes and breathtaking vistas matched all my expectations of what an Irish isle I thought would look like. In fact, I would posit the location set in 1923 used throughout the film is a character as much as any of the actor portrayals. It's a rough, isolated place to live.

At its essence this is the story of the sudden, seemingly inexplicable breakup of a friendship. And while it is filled with heartbreak, it's a heartbreak we can all relate to. Everyone of us, if you dig down in your memory lane there undoubtably has had some rocky roads in friendships. In fact, many have had to make the decision on whether to continue with a dubious friendship. It's that decision around which this film turns. But don't be misled this is merely a dour and depressing film, far from it. I haven't laughed out loud in a movie, along with the rest of the audience in a long, long time. It is a complex mixture of highs and lows that draws upon countless emotions buried within and on our surface.

Amid all the world-saving, super hero, special effect laden mega-blockbusters that seem to be the only movie fare available, this is an intimate picture. In fact, it seems almost like a play. There are only two main characters with the rest of the town's folk in small but crucial roles serving as something not unlike a Greek chorus ushering along the storyline. The dictionary defines banshee as a "female spirit in Gaelic folklore whose appearance or wailing warns a family that one of them will soon die." There's one of these too.

Now onto the perfect cast. In a completely surprising, unexpected wonderful turn is Colin Farrell (Padraic). Primarily a leading "modern actor" Farrell fits comfortably into this small-town vulnerable good guy role. His life is fulfilled with low expectations. He's buddies with a lifelong best friend. Visiting the local pub and downing pints of Guinness with his pal is a life well lived. Though the jury is out on whether he's dim or dumb … he is satisfied. He lacks an imagination to dream of better things. Still, it's hard to find fault with a satisfied person in this world. I for one was a little envious of that minimalist approach. But all that comes to an end when their friendship hits a stone wall.

That metaphorical wall is Padriac's friend Colm (Brendon Gleeson). What a face. Gleeson is one of those gifted actors whose expressions convey many things, sometimes more than one at the same time. Colm is a complex man caged by a simple life … and he wants out. You feel his angst but not the extreme expression of it. Be prepared.

I went with a lifelong buddy. Afterward I asked if he like it. He confessed he wasn't sure he understood it. He admitted he primarily goes to movies for entertainment and this was a bit of a challenge. That challenge is what I crave and for me is missing from many movies. However, I don't feel the two viewpoints have to be mutually exclusive. But to our friendships credit we had a great dinner talking over the interpretations of the film which was a feast for me and I think he enjoyed our talk too.
  
Two warnings you'll be glad I mentioned. Pay attention. The characters talk with an Irish brogue. Have faith that your ear will attune to it quickly. In fact, the screenplay author had enough sense to allow characters to repeat certain phrases as an aural footnote to help you get the point or joke. I'll even help. In the beginning is the phrase, "Did you have a row." The pronunciation of row is like nothing I've ever heard but you quickly get it as it's repeated by nearly everyone in the pub. The second warning is of a scene of self-harm. I won't go beyond that. Go see the film if you want to get my reference or, read some other reviewer who has no compunction about including spoilers in their reviews. That shall not pass here.

Martin McDonagh teams back up with his "In Bruges" stars Colin Farrell & Brendan Gleeson, to bring "The Banshees of Inisherin" a touching & bitterly funny tale about the break-up of friendship, loneliness & personal grudges. As always with Martin McDonagh's work there's the perfect balance of emotion, humour & strong performances with Colin Farrell & Brendan Gleeson are both outstanding deserving all the praise they been getting as does Kerry Condon & Barry Keoghan, who are both outstanding in their support roles.

This is for arthouse sophisticated types who have a strong stomach,
Saddest movie I've ever seen...but I loved it!

It's not a comedy in the American sense though there are funny bits throughout if you enjoy dry humor (I do). Rather, it is largely a drama filled with dark/taboo humor. Banshees has a gifted cast with an absolute standout performance by Barry Keoghan as Dominic, the only character I was able to truly have empathy for. Kerry Condon as Siobhan (sister to protagonist Colon Farrell's Padraic) delivers an excellent performance and approaches being an empathetic character except the story is not about her. It could be. Retelling the story of an isolated life on an Irish island from Siobhan's POV with the dark antics or Padraic and antagonist Colm (Brendan Gleeson) would have been a more compelling story and still allowed the filmmaker to explore the themes of mortality, friendship, and contentment. As it is, though, the film is dark, not breathtaking in its cinematography, and slower than it needs to be to convey the mood or setting. The moments of comedic relief are genuinely funny for those who enjoy dry humor as I mentioned. But the story meanders along and gives too much attention to certain set details that add no value to the story itself. It's not a majestic piece of cinematography that will stun you though the setting is beautiful. It's not a dark comedy that keeps you on the edge of being uncomfortable yet still delivers morose humor. It isn't entirely a drama because the story and a particular disturbing plot element border on the ridiculous (I left early after one gruesome and inexplicably weird moment). And while the characters have the potential for depth and whose performances are the only thing that kept me in my seat as long as I did, their arcs are never fully realized and they don't become dimensional or empathetic characters save Dominic. Ultimately, I don't feel the elements came together.

No, this film is not for everyone.  It helps if you are familiar with Martin McDonagh's work.  Now that we've got that straight:
Banshees of Inisherin is a Master Class for every part of filmmaking.  It is gorgeous to watch, the acting is flawless and the plot is intriguing.  Even the smallest roles are important to this film and the actors realize this.  
If you want a feel-good film, this isn't the film for you.  If you are really into all types of films (even the raw, difficult-to-watch ones), this is a must-see.

The Banshees Of Inisherin is a darkly funny film that explores depression, pride and the futility of life and the conflicts we have between friends. The screenplay is extremely witty and filled with individual details for each character, making the scenes that are shared by two or more people feeling more dynamic and engaging. All of the performances are stellar and the actors give so much personality to them, making the fictional island of Inisherin feel populated and alive. The cinematography and production design does a lot to capture the life and beauty of the town, with a nice focus on natural lighting from candles, fire and leaking sunbeams. Carter Burwell's score is playful and communicates the conflicting tone of comedy and despair that permeates the film. It's an overall very well constructed and performed tragicomedy that leaves you thinking.

I understand that this movie isn't for everyone, but I loved it. In true Irish tradition, it's a very slow, sad story. The location where the movie was filmed is beautiful, stark, desolate and shows how living in such isolation can affect mental health. I thought the acting was fantastic and the filming was absolutely gorgeous.

This was the best movie that I've seen all year. That being said, it's not for everyone. Humorous at times and you'll laugh a couple of times, but this is no comedy. Not even close. Beautifully filmed and always interesting. I won't rave about Brendan Gleeson because he's always terrific. All the way back to Braveheart and later in Calvary, In Bruges, and The Guard. All the actors are terrific, and every main character is interesting in their own way. Sometimes bleak and sad, but always interesting. This movie is about profound loneliness and isolation. Friendship and the fragility of friendships. Pettiness and the tragic results of pettiness escalated in a very narrow world. Self-introspection and the transference of disappointment onto others. One character in the movie actually comes up with the courage to leave and find her happiness off the island in the bigger world. A very intelligent film. You won't see any super-heroes flying around, but this movie is well worth seeing and it will stick with you when you leave the theater.

The cinematography and acting are outstanding; the cruelty, boundless. People hurting each other, people hurting themselves, people hurting animals (albeit inadvertently). Anyone able to view the traumatizing behaviors as symbolic may appreciate the power of the performances and imagery, and overlook the void at the center of this film. Perhaps it tries to convey a useful message about meaningfulness in life--but it fails. The entire core of the movie is more like the empty heart and soul of a senselessly abusive person: cruelty and heartlessness result in more cruelty and heartlessness. Those of us who experience depictions of abuse (shunning, neglect, severe child beating, and horrific self-mutilation) as triggering should avoid this film. I started crying before 20 minutes, and had to step outside for air after about an hour. I had been looking forward to visiting Ireland someday; now I'm  going to have to try to de-associate the images of beautiful scenery with emotional agony. From what I've read, Ireland experienced decades of pain, betrayal, and an endless variety of injuries both psychic and physical, all inflicted by brother on brother. Perhaps this film is the perfect expression of those scars, but I'm not convinced it needed to be so traumatic. One of the professional critics said he might call this a horror film--keep that in mind before you see a film about friendship and kindness morphing into depravity.

Martin McDonagh isn't the most prolific director, but his films are certainly worth the wait.  The Banshees of Inisherin is a movie about the frayed threads that hold friendships together and, more so, the human desire to leave behind some sort of legacy.  Set during the Irish Civil War on a desolate island off the coast of Ireland, Colm (Brendan Gleason) calmly advises his longtime friend Padraic (Colin Farrell) that he no longer wants anything to do with him.  Similar in many ways to McDonagh's In Bruges from fourteen years earlier, The Banshees of Inisherin is filled with memorable dialogue, original ideas, strong performances throughout, lovely landscapes and stunning cinematography.  Other than the most jaded contrarian, it's hard to imagine anyone finding fault with McDonagh's latest offering.

Martin McDonagh's follow-up to the 2017 critical darling "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is tight, relatable and — I think — an even better movie. Full stop. In fact, with Martin McDonagh being one of the few filmmakers whose filmographies I've seen in its entirety, I'd say this is easily his best film since "In Bruges," which says a whole lot. "The Banshees Of Inisherin" is simple, yet layered. Beautiful, yet ugly. Hilarious, yet horrific. If there's any work in this filmmaker's oeuvre that I think is the perfect, most simple distillation of his voice/tonal DNA, it has to be this. Beyond that, you have the acting, which is stupendous, the cinematography, which is magical and the overall experience, which is lasting and satisfying. Terrific work here from everyone involved.

This movie is fantastic. Taking place on a remote Island off of Ireland, in 1923 during the Irish Civil War. We are introduced to two friends in this very small town where word travels fast. Once the conflict of between Colm and Padraic starts, you can truly feel their uncomfortableness for each other. Colin Farrell's worrying about his friend and what has happened is wonderfully done. Also Brendan Gleeson's commit to try to avoid his ex friend is a sight to see. The supporting cast are very well balanced, adding to the unorthodox nature of the friendship's chaos. Also the very traditional Irish slang and conversations are such a delight to behold that keeps you engaged throughout the whole film.

Padraic (Colin Farrell) is a kind man. He loves his home, his farm and his friend. His world falls apart when his best friend decides he doesn't want to associate with him any more. The treatment he suffers from all around him turns him into a bad man. This film is deeply touching. As funny as it is sad. A lesson in how depressive people are so wrapped up in themselves they hurt those who love them. A lot to unpack in this film......and the miniature donkey.....bless the miniature donkey.

Sometimes the simplest of films can become one of the best of its consecutive year, or even an already great filmmaker's finest work. Martin McDonagh is one of my favourite working directors today. Whether you're talking about his excellent and hilarious debut with In Bruges back in 2008, or his award-worthy Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri in 2017, he is a filmmaker that hasn't made a single film that wasn't at least very, very good, at least to me. The Banshees of Inisherin marks his latest directorial effort and arguably his best. It's been a while since I went to the theatre and felt the filmmaking just leaping off the screen, but this one did that for me. 

The Banshees of Inisherin follows Pádraic (Colin Farrell) as he lives a straightforward life on a small island in Ireland called Inisherin. Drinking at the local pub on a daily basis and only having one lifelong friend in Colm (Brendan Gleeson), he quickly learns that Colm no longer wishes to be his friend. Colm has his reasons, but they really don't make any logical sense, thus sparking Pádraic's confusion and curiosity. Colm's one request is that Pádraic just stop talking to him altogether, otherwise he is threatening to harm himself. That's it, that's the only story to this film, other than the very incredible dialogue that makes it all worth it.

This film is a masterwork in how well a movie can work if you have great characters. Pádraic and Colm are both very well written and Farrell and Gleeson both give arguably their best performances here. They both had me laughing hysterically and feeling awful at the same time. There were multiple occasions where the film was too funny to not laugh, but the subject matter was very dark, so I felt bad for doing so, and that to me was the brilliance of this film. The dialogue was the driving force here and that aspect was perfection to me. 

Martin McDonagh also wrote the screenplay for this film, which really makes me believe he won't ever make a bad movie. He has a knack for writing some of the most clever dialogue out there and his work throughout the years only seems to improve. He can also work exceptionally well with actors, which is why a film like this turns out so well with him behind the wheel. Everything from the camerawork to the subtle score, The Banshees of Inisherin, although dark and funny, is a masterwork of filmmaking, especially when it's such a simple premise. This is also a much darker film than any of his previous work, but that made the final act feel authentic to this story. I really don't have anything to complain about here.

Production would have been greatly complicated to train the actors in Irish dialogue and then subtitle it.

When Colm decides to take action to put his remaining years on a better and to him more constructive course, all H breaks loose and all four people are in a different spot. Zero. Great acting. A well made film. So, why did I think it was such a bore. Because it was! It was painful to watch. The donkey lucked out. He got out before I did. Please. Give the Irish a break. No one can be that stupid and boring. I’m in no hurry to meet any of M. McD’s friends.
This was quite a film.  Everything about this film was excellent.  The script, the acting, the cinematography, etc., were all top notch.  Should be up for an Academy Award or two.

It was a movie I’d have to watch one in a while due to the effects it leaves you with. I think in a way somehow we know someone in a or was in a situation similar to how it was portrayed in the movie. Keeps you yearning for more through to the end.

Everything about this movie was beautifully done -except the story. It was so dark and depressing that it made me sad that I went to the movies to see it. Love these two actors so much and the cast was absolutely brilliant but the story was so disappointing. The best movie I have seen in a long while. The is no fault to be found here only some acting is better that others. some of these actors gave extraordinary performances. The story reminds me of the best shorts stories from classic anthologies: simple, dark  intense.

Even though the acting, scenery and costumes are fantastic, the story is SO Awful.  It is hard to explain how bad this movie is because I’m still in shock.  And it’s dumb.  I’ve seen Martin McDonagh stories before and I’m not sure what happened with this one. Terrible!

there was good acting. the theme of the movie was bad(at least for me). I only went because my adult daughter wanted to see a movie set in Ireland area. Not a very happy ever after movie AT ALL. there was pretty scenery and the mini donkey was cute. nothing else good to say about it.

I had heard very mixed reviews so was ready to be disappointed….I was far from it! Amazing acting and scenery portraying a very bleak time in Ireland. You probably would have to have been born in or before the 1970's to appreciate it otherwise it would seem like utter fiction!! But rural Ireland back then was so insular and incestious people really did live such small and sad lives and ultimately went mad! I saw a comment saying, there was no real ending…. The ending was the madness probably continued to a tragic end that still lives on through generations in Ireland
All over the feckin' shop.

I love me some Martin McDonagh. He does dark storytelling and black humor with great skill, balancing intensity and delicacy. The Banshees of Inisherin finds two long-time best friends of sort no longer mates as one, Brendan Gleeson's Colm, has had his fill of Colin Farrell's Pádraic. Seems Pádraic is one boring fella when it comes to the chatting, and Colm now wants to make more of his time and sitting with this dull bloke at the pub or wherever they're conversing. Namely, he wants to work on composing more on his fiddle. 
The two begin to have a sort of clash, which is analogous with the civil war currently occurring on the mainland of Ireland. As with wars, things begin with small skirmishes and build up to full-on assaults. Colm threatens to hack off a digit if Pádraic doesn't cease and desist with all his talking to him. He does so briefly before launching into an angry rant at Colm, which then leads the latter to indeed follow through with his amputation.
As dark and miserable as this all sounds, it's a Martin McDonagh film, so the humor's gonna be there, but you have to sense it at times, cuz this is not stuff that hits you over the head. Dark/black humor is more subtle, and indeed works best if you have a good bit of it already in your reserve along with a lot of experience in using and appreciating it. 
The supporting cast is excellent. Kerry Condon as Pádraic's suffering sister who is told 'no one likes (her). Shortt's bartender, Pearse as the priest, along with Kenny and Lydon flesh out key parts so well. And then there's Sheila Fitton as the ominous, seer type Mrs. McCormick and Barry Keoghan as another oddball outcast. Both are very effective in their specific characters. Fitton brings s cold, callous sense to Mrs. McCormick, who annoys as much as puts off her fellow islanders. Keoghan nearly steals whole scenes at times with his combination of convincing dullard and all his nervous fidgeting facial expressions. 
And the island itself is something of a character, with its blanket of lush green fields and yards, the small rural homes, JJ. Devine's pub, and the verging sea. 
Great stuff by McDonagh, cast, and crew. 3.8 stars
There is only so much despair to go around and this movie sucked up all the despair in the world into itself.
Very sad, and very tragic, but also very true to life in many ways and quite beautiful.
Great acting by entire cast.
I enjoyed the creative side of the movie but my wife and I were extremely disappointed in the movie in general.
Always love McDonaghs sense of real life and real oeople and dark sense of humor acting was excellent, Colin Farrell was exceptional!
A slow burn meditation on the Ill effects of grief with stellar turns by Barry Keoghan, Kerry Condon, Brendan Gleason and especially Colin Farrell.
entertaining but bad ending

An excellent film with a lot to say about the nature of friendship, communication and loneliness.
A masterpiece ..great acting by all ..Colin for the Oscar
