Incredible. Beautiful. Acting, scenery 5 stars. But the metaphor of clinical depression in a friendship is exquisitely done. So many things you could pull out of this extending to humanity as well. Plus you will laugh even amidst the darkness.
Great movie with well-developed characters. It's the kind of movie that I could see film courses doing a character study on. Highly recommend.
A wonderful movie. Beautifully written and acted. Very moving and engaging.
If you are craving a good story in a novel setting, highly recommend.

What transpired was the most frikin' depressing movie I've seen since Manchester By The Sea back in 2016.   I had been seeing humorous clips online for a couple weeks but the comedic moments did not dig this movie out of what was a depressing hole.  What a lonely existence it must have been for the inhabitants of this remote Irish island in the early 1900s.  
All that said, we continued to chuckle about the movie throughout dinner and the character development and acting was superb.   I guess that those types of stories must also be told.

A spectacular piece of cinema. Absurd dramedy of the highest caliber. 

The writing goes seamlessly between light-hearted wit on the surface to outbursts of emotion underneath that fall like an anvil. The cinematography is breathtaking, both in the gorgeous, wide-panning scenery shots and in the up close portraits. The acting is poignant, with just the right blend of funny, tortured and cynical - especially from Farrell. 

And, lastly, there's the many underlying meanings left after you peel all that away. The despair of meaninglessness, the rage in trying to escape it, and the passion with which people find ridiculous things to fill the time and cling to. 

Cannot recommend enough. Watched it twice. One of my favorite movies in a long time. Hope it gets an Oscar
Wonderful acting, beautiful cinematography. Too bad all movies can't be this well done.

Martin McDonald's finest piece of writing and directing yet.    Being Irish, I'm thoroughly familiar with the unique eccentricities of the Irish.  Set this on a small island off the Irish coast and those personalities become amplified.  Gleeson and Farrell give incredible and sensitive performances as does the supporting cast. It's as funny as it is horrifying and never fails to entertain.   The narrative moves along quickly even in the quiet moments.  The gloomy Irish skies grow grayer with each act until the last moment.   No spoilers but I can assure you, you have never seen a story like this.
It was a wet dull Sunday afternoon in Cornwall when I saw this wet and dull film. I walked out after an hour. I couldn't find anything funny, interesting or worth staying till the end for.

The people in this small village "watched" the warring factions across the water in the mainland, but they showed how the violent, ridiculous, hurtful-to-all wars are within all of us.  Too much is lost.  Some die.  Some escape.  But some will continue to marinate and stagnate - even when they SEE the remnants of a mutually recognized kindness that used to bind them.  My, my.  Great acting by all and fabulous music.  I recommend it.

This was my most anticipated film of the year and... it delivered. This is a hilarious tale of two friends reviewing their lives. Martin Mcdonagh is still outstanding as a scriptwriter but this is definitely his best work as a director. With each film, he becomes more decisive with each frame of the work, and the banshees absolutely show that. From the tiny detail that in the background that symbolizes the dialogue, to how the terrain displays the character's way of life, he really has mastered it. The score is great as it effectively captures the sound of the mystery of the events and the island of inisherin. The cinematography is also excellent at exhibiting the beauty of Ireland. I did find it to be a slower film than Mcdonagh's previous works, but in this case, it is needed, this isn't a story of just any old friendship, this is the story of two best friends splitting. Colin Farrell perfectly encapsulates Padric, using everything in his acting arsenal to get down to very intricate details. Brendan Gleeson rises as Colm, portraying a man trying to look more sophisticated than he actually is. Everyone is perfectly cast in this and does everything in their power to contribute to this great movie. This was truly a great film for Mcdonagh and just makes me more excited for what he has next, which we will probably see in 5 years.

Beautiful filmography, this is a must see in a theater. The views of the Irish west coast are stunning. The story is hilarious and sad. Lonely people who are incapable of articulating their own sense of isolation while living a little too closely together. You will find yourself laughing and crying at the same time. Brilliant!

Riveting.  All the actors are exceptional.  Barry Keoghan's character will break your heart.  His dreams disslove in front of our eyes so delicately as he plays the battered son who takes welts and melts our hearts   He even slips in  a touch of the (oh my he knows how to be a good lover when he reaches for unrequited love.    Colin Farrel - one forgets his movie star looks -  because he knows his character so well. He is delightful and painful to watch as his character arc takes us on an unexpected turn - he is a master!      And Brendon Gleeson - has us wrapped around his permanently bruised thumbnail!   Kerry Condon's trembling chin, of what might have been, and her duty to the dead and the conflict she balances makes us long for more.  She sorely  missed when she leaves the screen.   Every character in this movie rings true   Not a false moment.  And all of the actors know these characters inside and out.    Fantastic film.   Brilliant directing.   Brilliant acting.   Compelling script.   Bravo.      There are Banshees.

Absolutely Stunning! Mcdonagh is a man of vision and he writes an amazingly funny, yet dark take on male loneliness , despair and the individual ways that each person impacts our life and the way we see it. Sometimes there is no reason why, just the reason.
Brutally honest, silly, and endearing!
Much more drama than comedy.  Worth seeing!

There is violence and then there is violence against animals which is a whole other thing.  If you have pets and/or  love animals be warned. There needs to be warning about depictions of animal cruelty in films just as there is for nudity, drugs use or whatever. What started off as an interesting and unique story degenerated quickly into a bloodbath culminating in a scene which made us leave and want to forget we ever saw the film.  It didn't have to turn out like that, I could think of a dozen different story lines  that would have made the film more rewarding. Self mutilation and animal cruelty is the last thing we need to see on the big screen right now.
Fascinating movie set in Ireland.  Great cast and great plot.  It was not possible to see where the movie was going.

I loved it! The pacing was great. Starts out funny and becomes darker in a very unforced way. Great actors. All the roles were spot on. Good scenery is part of the movie. Wonderfully made with good humor great directing, and acting and surprisingly sad

I loved this movie.  The acting was superb.
Beautiful setting and I loved the way they talked but I never understood the motive behind one of the characters there are unanswered questions and i felt confused and unsatisfied at the ending.

Absolutely dreadful a sore excuse of a movie!
A transfixing and poetic meditation on division and alienation that is not only an absolutely gorgeous feast for the eyes, but for the soul as well.

Acting phenomenal 
Your chance to be in the real and mythical Ireland

As good as McDonaugh's previous movies, In Bruges and Three Billboards.

Then proceeds to mutilate himself to prove the point. In the meantime he accidentally kills his ex-friends miniature donkey when it chokes on his mutilated fingers. An amazing gothic film that perfectly analogizes the sectarian conflict in Ireland. Martin McDonagh is much stronger exposing his home than rural Missouri.
The film was darker than I expected, and that caught me by surprise. Performances were outstanding, plus a creative and original script. Terrific cinematography too.
Absolutely brilliant film! A must see. These two together are fantastic!
The acting and actor chemistry were outstanding. Built slowly to a profound fly moving climax

The beautiful cinematography and few laughs were not worth the depressing story.. An utterly miserable film with an unhinged main character. I stuck it out hoping something worthwhile would happen. It did not.

The movie was a little slow, but it truly showed how their relationship devolved into something completely different and evil over something so incredibly petty.  I thought there might be more humor but I was perfectly fine with the direction the movie took and enjoyed the surprise of the journey.
Stellar cast. Colin Farrell was so fabulous. He was able to give so much emotion without saying a word
Superb story, writing, and acting.  It WILL be nominated for multiple Academy awards.

The pain I feel for this movie... I sorta fell in love, just to have that love torn asunder.

Incredible cinematography! The story is much heavier than the previews indicate but there's plenty of authentic Irish humor. Great performances by the entire cast. I'll see this one again to catch some things I'm sure I missed.
People of the in the moive 5 stars
Hilarious and sad, beautiful and whimsical, and with great performances and cinematography.

Poignant, funny, even shocking— in just a couple hours, you’ll explore loneliness, friendship, loss, and our reasons for living. A lofty review can’t do it justice. Somehow, with all the heavy themes, Farrell and Gleeson deliver humor and heart. Colin Farrell in particular delivers such an endearing sweetness through all his character’s pain. This is one to see, then ruminate on.

Well, it's no In Bruges.
Honestly, it's probably McDonagh's weakest film, but it's still good.

It's got great performances (hell, even Barry Keoghan was tolerable, which is better than I've been able to say about him in most anything else he's done), and it's an entertaining basic idea. It's just a bit dreary and doesn't really go anywhere in the end.

Slow, bleak and depressing seeing two pals slowly ruin their lives for no reason in November made you feel cold inside, there're no comedy moments maybe 2 at best. one main character wanted to leave the island and I wanted to join her and leave the film early

The story was based in Ireland around 1922 with two main characters whose friendship just ended, one or two scenes had a giggle but overall it was rather dull just like the character.

Not what I was expecting. It’s more of a bleak drama than a comedy as it’s being advertised as. Great performances held my interest throughout. Though well-done, it’s a downer of a movie about the death of a friendship.

DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE: "The Banshees of Inisherin"(2022)! (IT IS NOT WORTH YOUR TIME to GO SEE a MOVIE and PAY($) to see a MOVIE!) (I saw this movie at 3:45pm(CT) Sunday October 30, 2022; when I went to a movie and paid($) to see a movie in Austin, Texas, U.S..) Hard to understand all the dialog.  Was touted as a comedy yet only had a few humorous moments, but much gore.  ACTING WAS GOOD but the script was not!

Although the acting was really great, if you're looking for sheer entertainment I'd look somewhere else.  But if you want to see something to pass the time, have at it.  I personally left the film confused and unfulfilled.

I can't imagine real people ever acting the way the two principals behaved in the story.  It defies logic.  The photography was excellent and the acting was great if you can suspend disbelief at the absurd premise of the main story line.   I need a lot more believabiliy to a story.  Nothing crazy like this ever happened ... or ever will.

Everything about this movie is a five! It’s perfect, the scenery, the music, the acting, the script- clean, pure! I know that everybody in the audience got a different meaning from the film, each one would tell you it was about some thing different. To me, it’s that kind of depth that makes a masterpiece! ( but it takes the right acting and direction to pull it off.)

Stunning, moving, intense acting. Five stars!
All though the movie is a bit slow, creative great humor that had the theatre laughing out loud, unreal performances by all the leads. very emotional scenes. Must see drama.

I realy love the movie,
Hard to say anything without given away too much.
But not an easy watch at times but funny in parts.
This one puts you through a full array of emotions. Incredibly funny and sad at the same time in a perfect balance.

Ireland is a bittersweet land. A small island with some of the friendliest people in the world, riven by petty disputes, and political divisions. The Banshees of Inisherin is possibly the best evocation of this that I have ever seen. (I have lived in Belfast all my life.) 
Set against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, the fall out between to old friends captures the futility of a long feud, with no real beginning and no end.
Colin Farrel gives a career-defining performance, supported by the brilliant Brendan Gleeson and the wonderful Kerry Condon. The priest and policeman's power are well defined, as is the undercurrent of the misuse of that power. Barry Keoghan is superb as the young lad faced with a lifetime in this village. The scenery of the West of Ireland is beautiful, but not an antidote to the life of poverty in 1920s Ireland. 
Martin McDonagh has captured so much of what makes Ireland both wonderful and horrific in this magnificent work of art. Watching it I would not have been surprised had the source material been one of Ireland's great short story authors.

It was beautifully acted and the cinematography was gorgeous. But there was no context for the relationships and conflicts. Yes, loneliness and the loss of friendship is heartbreaking, but why not let us get to know Colm and Padraic and show us the depth of their friendship so that we understand what each man lost when it ended? Why not show us more about Siobhan and how she is different from others on the island, so we get a better sense of why she would leave? And the business about Colm's fingers was absurd. For a film that wants to be grounded in the relationships between the characters, the gore was ridiculous, not credible, and just distracting. I wanted to love the movie but I found it confusing and frequently unpleasant.

Acclaimed playwright and director Martin McDonagh delivers another masterful ensemble piece to audiences with his latest film "The Banshees of Inisherin". The black comedy reunites leads Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson with McDonagh, who directed them both in his 2008 Oscar-nominated film "In Bruges". After it's world premiere at this year's Venice International Film Festival, the film went on to receive a rapturous 15-minute standing ovation, five minutes longer than McDonagh's previous film "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri". 

The film takes place in 1920s Ireland, against the backdrop of the Irish Civil War, on the fictional island of Inisherin and tells the story of two friends Pádraic (Farrell) and Colm (Gleeson). One day, Colm decides to abruptly end his long-running friendship with Pádraic, claiming the man is ‘too dull' for him to spend the rest of his life around. An escalating battle then begins between the two friends, and it soon becomes the talk of the village, with many just as confused as Pádraic with Colm's decision. As the growing tensions between the two grow, it's not long before it boils over and results in devastating consequences for both feuding men. 

Colin Farrell leads an uber-talented cast comprised of some of Ireland's greatest talents like Brendan Gleeson, Kerry Condon, and Barry Keoghan, all delivering knockout performances. Farrell's work is almost certain to land him a spot in this year's Best Actor line-up as he plays Pádraic, the harmless easy-going farmer, until he finally snaps and becomes a ruthless man out for revenge, and perhaps that's what makes his performance so fascinating to watch unfold on the big screen. The friendship Farrell shares with his co-star Brendan Gleeson elevates both performances making them feel much more authentic and believable. The pair share a hilarious back and forth that's embellished by McDonagh's screenplay. Gleeson's role as Colm, a man who finds himself in the later years of his life wishing to be more creative, and have more interesting conversations with those around him, is terrific and perfectly compliments Farrell's performance. The film's other standout performance, alongside Farrell's, comes from Kerry Condon. The Irish actress, probably best known for voicing ‘Friday' in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, gives a marvellous turn as Pádraic's sister, Siobhan. Condon ends up acting as a mediator between the two men, trying to keep them apart to prevent Colm from resorting to drastic action. Condon boosts every scene she's in to a whole other level and she ends up being one of the best parts of the film. 

Director Martin McDonagh pens a screenplay that balances side-splitting hilarity with tear-jerking emotion and reminds you exactly why he has two Oscar-nominations for writing under his belt. It's sharp, witty, and brilliantly tells the story of what happens when a friendship turns sour. McDonagh does a skilful job blending the comedic tones at the start of the film with the tragedy and drama that becomes more dominant towards the end. This balance, combined with McDonagh's sensational directorial effort, makes "The Banshees of Inisherin" such a unique and entertaining film. Perhaps what else makes the film so good, and sets it apart from a large majority of this year's awards contenders, is that it isn't an intricate biopic about a famous figure or some overbearing think piece, but is instead a rich, amusing film about friendship. 

"The Banshees of Inisherin" brings some delightful visuals to the screen alongside the engaging narrative and likeable characters. Cinematographer Ben Davis, who worked with McDonagh on "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", uses the scenic Irish coastlines to his advantage to effortlessly enhance the natural beauty of the film.

"The Banshees of Inisherin" easily sets itself up to be one of 2022's best and most entertaining films. With shining performances from the cast, and a simple plot with changing tones, the film is a solid original dark comedy from acclaimed director Martin McDonagh. A simple, yet distinctive depiction of the end of a friendship, "The Banshees of Inisherin" is beautifully tied together, while also being incredibly charming and amusing, and a brilliant follow up to "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri".
Laugh out loud funny moments, sadness and drama. It ends without a complete ending leaving contemplation. Highly enjoyable.

The Banshees of Inisherin tells the silent fight between the characters who decide to change or have to change on a boring island. In the film, in which no idea is glorified or criticized, the effect of knowledge on people is examined. The movie, in which the centuries-old fight between people who read and people who don't read is reenacted on a small island, shows us that we need to make radical decisions, even if it sometimes upsets some people or frightens us. When Einstein said that people are divided into two, the good and the bad, he didn't say that the good should be boring. The main priority in this life is ourselves, and to make ourselves happy, we should be in places where we will be satisfied and do things that make us happy. While Siobhan sees the benefits of his radical decision, Colm, unfortunately, has to struggle with Padraic's obsessions and manages to reach the happiness he seeks, even if a few fingers are missing.

I loved the relationship, or lack thereof, between Colm and Padraic. Being Irish, I could almost understand it. I could see Colm's reasons, although I also thought he was nuts. He simply wanted to do something better than sit in the put just "chatting,." I also felt sad for Padraic, who was basically a good guy but didn't offer much in intellectual stimulation.. Colin Ferrell and Brendan Gleeson were perfect in their parts. II expected to both laugh and cry more, but the emotional wrenches of the movie were deeper than to just produce laughter or tears and stayed with you after the movie ended. The cinematography and film editing were excellent, and the pace of the movie fitted the story perfectly, although I think it was much too slow for the average moviegoer.

Allegory for Irish civil war taking place seemingly a world away from this remote island, where the end of friendship is more important than in other situations.  Colin Farrell has never been better, and Kerry Condon is fantastic as well.  Martin McDonough, with his script and direction, immerses you in this world.

Irish writer-director Martin McDonagh returns to his homeland after his Oscars success with his last film 5 years ago and it's a triumphant return, with a profound and exceptionally crafted screenplay that works on multiple levels, whether it's simply a story about the dramatic fallout after a life-long friendship breaks up out of the blue, or a deep dive into a character's battle with despair and mortality, or even as a metaphor for Ireland and their troubles since the Civil War, which coincidentally plays in the background of this film as an ominous reminder that constantly haunts its characters. Reuniting Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson from McDonagh's own In Bruges, they're the two central contrasting characters living on a remote island village off the Western coast of Ireland in 1923, whose friendship is unilaterally terminated by Gleeson's Colm to the horrors and bafflement of Farrell's Padraic. Easing us in with lively interactions sprinkled with laugh-out-loud Irish humour and stereotypes, and Ben Davis' calming and sumptuous cinematography that makes the best out of the picturesque landscape available, it builds on its engaging and straightforward premise organically, evolving incrementally in a dramatic and increasingly serious manner, before reaching a vicious yet melancholic conclusion. Basically, it begins as Father Ted but ends in Sunday Bloody Sunday and every laugh feels infused with pathos and the funniest characters wind up inhabiting the most tragic arc. Conveying complex emotions brilliantly, Farrell and Gleeson are on top form here, while Kerry Condon and Barry Keoghan's scene-stealing support will not go unnoticed. Accompanied by an exquisite score by Carter Burwell that goes beyond Irish diddly music, this is an elegant and graceful film that one can enjoy and appreciate on so many different levels, it literally is the definition of thought-provoking.

Gleeson who plays Colm looks back at his life seeking out what he has accomplished and when he find that there is little and that he will be forgotten after his death he descends into a state of despair which reults in the collapse of his great friendship with Padraic, Farrell.

Martin McDonagh has made an extraordinary film in so many ways, starting with the brilliant theatrical script and the performances of all the main actors involved: Colin Farrell, Brendan Gleeson, Barry Keoghan, and Kerry Condon. This also applies to all the supporting roles.

The humour is brilliant, the film is extremely funny but also meaningful and difficult to interpret, at times shocking and quite unpredictable. It is hard not to empathise with the characters and their vicissitudes. At the end of the screening, more then receiving answers, I felt I had learnt and witnessed something important, even though I couldn't immediately point what. A beautiful film that triggers deep reflection.

Wholly immersive thanks to the beautiful photography, excellent dialogues and a cast of memorable, perfectly chosen faces helmed by the great duo of Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson, it's perhaps McDonagh's most antithetical film: the first half is surprisingly hilarious to the point of bordering on farce, while the second is considerably grimmer as the characters are driven to extremes that work symbolically as portrayals of their worldview and relationship but contextually seem far-fetched.
